set forth in the affidavit, the court shall authorize the issuance of a search
warrant permitting access to and inspection of that part of the premises on
which the nuisance or violation may exist, the towing of a specific vehicle, or
such other actions as the court deems appropriate. (Ord. 3707, 2-8-2021)
CHAPTER 12
RECORDS RETENTION POLICY
SECTION:
1-12-1: Policy
1-12-2: Local Records Act
1-12-3: Definitions Of Public Records
1-12-4: Records Retention Schedule
1-12-5: Disposal Of Records
1-12-6: Assistance
1-12-7: Tempering With Public Records
1-12-8: Suspension Of Policy In The Event Of Litigation
1-12-1: POLICY:
It is a policy of the City of Marion to fully comply with the Local Records Act
and to promote efficiency and economy in the record keeping practices of our
local government. (Ord. 3757, 11-8-2021)
1-12-2: LOCAL RECORDS ACT:
The Local Records Act (50 ILCS 205) regulates the preservation or disposal of
the public records of all units of local government in Illinois. The Act's
purpose is to maintain a mechanism for the retention of those records that are
necessary for the proper functioning of government, the destruction of obsolete
and valueless records and the archival preservation of those records that have
long-term research values but are not necessary for the routine operations of
local government. By disposing of useless records and by preserving archival
materials, valuable storage space can be freed for the ever-increasing
quantities of current records, which are vital for the daily business of local
officials. (Ord. 3757, 11-8-2021)
1-12-3: DEFINITION OF PUBLIC RECORDS:
This policy adopts the definition of "public records" as stated in the Local
Records Act, which is currently defined as:
   A.   Any book, paper, map, photograph, born-digital electronic material,
digitized electronic material, electronic material with a combination of
digitized and born-digital material, or other official documentary material,
regardless of physical form or characteristics, made, produced, executed or
received by any agency or officer pursuant to law or in connection with the
transaction of public business and preserved or appropriate for preservation by
such agency or officer, or any successor thereof, as evidence of the
organization, function, policies, decisions, procedures, or other activities
thereof, or because of the informational data contained therein.
   B.   Library and museum material made or acquired and preserved solely for
reference or exhibition purposes, extra copies of documents preserved only for
convenience of reference, and stocks of publications and of processed documents
are not included within the definition of public record.
   C.   Reports and records of the obligation, receipt and use of public funds
of the units of local government and school districts, including certified
audits, management letters and other audit reports made by the Auditor General,
County Auditors, other officers or by licensed Certified Public Accountants
permitted to perform audits under the Illinois Public Accounting Act and
presented to the corporate authorities or boards of the units of local
government, are public records available for inspection by the public. (Ord.
3757, 11-8-2021)
1-12-4: RECORDS RETENTION SCHEDULE:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of the clerk and various department
supervisors to establish and maintain a Records Retention Schedule.
   B.   Submission shall be made to the appropriate records commission, lists
or schedules of public records in their custody that are not needed in the
transaction of current business and that do not have sufficient administrative,
legal or fiscal value to warrant their further preservation.
   C.   They shall also submit lists or schedules proposing the length of time
each records series warrants retention for administrative, legal or fiscal
purposes after it has been received by the municipality. The appropriate
records commission shall determine what public records have no administrative,
legal, research or historical value and should be destroyed or otherwise
disposed of and shall authorize destruction or other disposal thereof.
   D.   Police misconduct records. Notwithstanding any other provision of law
to the contrary, all public records and nonpublic records related to
complaints, investigations and adjudications of police misconduct shall be
permanently retained and may not be destroyed.
   E.   Only the Local Records Commission and Local Records Commission of Cook
County can determine how long an agency must retain records. (Ord. 3757, 11-8-
2021)
1-12-5: DISPOSAL OF RECORDS:
   A.   In Illinois, no public record may be disposed of without the approval
of the appropriate records commission. The Records Management Section of the
Illinois State Archives is responsible for assisting state and local government
agencies with the disposal of records.
   B.   Each agency must submit an Application for Authority to Dispose of
Local Records (Application) to the appropriate Local Records Commission prior
to the destruction of any record.
   C.   After the Application has been approved by the Local Records
Commission, it will become the Records Retention Schedule.
   D.   A Local Records Disposal Certificate must be submitted to the Local
Records Commission authorizing the destruction at least 30 days before the date
the agency wishes to dispose of the records. This form can be found at: http://
www.cyberdriveillinois.com/publications/pdf_publications/lr4.pdf.
   E.   Records can then be disposed of after the minimum retention period
listed for each records series is met, provided no litigation is pending or
anticipated and providing all audit requirements have been met. (Ord. 3757, 11-
8-2021)
1-12-6: ASSISTANCE:
   A.   A records archivist from the State Archives' Local Records Unit will
provide the Application for an agency that is on file, or guide the agency
through the records inventory process to prepare the Application to the
appropriate Local Records Commission.
   B.   The records archivist can also assist with preparation of the first
Local Records Disposal Certificate.
   C.   This assistance is provided at no charge.
   D.   Frequently asked questions and answers for local government agencies
can be found at:
http://www.cyberdriveillinois.com/departments/archives/records_manage_ment/
faqlocal.html.
   E.   For more information and helpful insight, the Illinois Secretary of
State publication: Managing Your Records and the Local Records Act: A Quick
Guide for Disposing of Local Records can be found at: http://
www.cyberdriveillinois.com/publications/pdf_publications/lr34.pdf. (Ord. 3757,
11-8-2021)
1-12-7: TAMPERING WITH PUBLIC RECORDS:
Pursuant to 720 ILCS 5/32-8, a person who knowingly and without lawful
authority alters, destroys, defaces, removes or conceals any public record
commits a Class 4 felony. (Ord. 3757, 11-8-2021)
1-12-8: SUSPENSION OF POLICY IN THE EVENT OF LITIGATION:
If a lawsuit is filed or appears imminent, this policy must be suspended to
require that documents relating to the lawsuit or potential legal issue(s) be
retained. (Ord. 3757, 11-8-2021)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Created
2-1-2: Composition; Appointment; Term
2-1-3: Organization
2-1-4: General Powers
2-1-1: CREATED:
A city plan commission is hereby created. (2013 Code)
2-1-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The plan commission shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by
the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. Each member shall
serve a term of two (2) years or until a successor is appointed. The city
administrator shall be an ex officio member of the commission. (2013 Code)
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Chair: The mayor shall designate a member of the plan commission to
serve as chair.
   B.   Rules Of Procedure: The commission shall establish and adopt rules of
procedure for the conduct of the business thereof. (2013 Code)
2-1-4: GENERAL POWERS:
   A.   Official Comprehensive Plan:
      1.   The plan commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council
a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of
the city.
      2.   Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or
functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official
comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the city.
      3.   The plan may include reasonable requirements with reference to
streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements.
      4.   Such plan may be implemented by ordinances:
         a.   Establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and
of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein
defined.
         b.   Establish reasonable requirements governing the location, width,
course and surfacing of public streets, ways for public service facilities,
school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater
drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection
and treatment.
      5.   The plan commission shall recommend changes from time to time in the
official comprehensive plan.
   B.   Improvements: The plan commission shall prepare and recommend to the
city council from time to time plans for specific improvements in pursuance of
the official comprehensive plan.
   C.   Other Powers: The plan commission shall exercise such powers as may be
conferred by the city council. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 2
GREATER EGYPT REGIONAL PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-2-1: Mayor As City Representative; Term
2-2-2: Payment Of Assessment
2-2-1: MAYOR AS CITY REPRESENTATIVE; TERM:
The mayor of the city is hereby designated to serve as the municipal
representative member for the city on the greater Egypt regional planning and
development commission, and his term shall begin and end in accordance with the
amended resolution for establishment of the commission or the bylaws or other
resolutions of the commission. (Ord. 875, 3-14-1977)
2-2-2: PAYMENT OF ASSESSMENT:
The city shall pay its assessment to the commission as the same becomes due and
payable throughout the term of the city's membership in the commission. (Ord.
875, 3-14-1977)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-3-1: Definitions
2-3-2: Board Created; Appointment And Term
2-3-3: Membership Restrictions; Removals
2-3-4: Authority
2-3-5: Meetings
2-3-6: Officers And Advisers
2-3-7: Governing Rules
2-3-8: Procedures For Appointment, Promotion And Removal Of Police And Fire
Personnel
2-3-9: Annual Report
2-3-10: Facilities And Funds
2-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
APPOINTMENT COMMITTEE: Shall consist of the mayor, the commissioner of public
health and safety, the merit board, the human resources and risk management
director and the chief of the appropriate department.
BOARD: The board of fire and police commissioners of the city of Marion.
FIREFIGHTER: Any person holding a position in the Marion fire department,
except as modified in this chapter.
OFFICER: Any sworn officer holding a position in the Marion police department,
except as modified in this chapter. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
2-3-2: BOARD CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
There is hereby created, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1 and
article VII, section 6 of the Illinois constitution, a board of fire and police
commissioners which shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by
the mayor, with the approval and consent of a majority of the city council. The
term of office shall be three (3) years, and members shall serve until their
successors are appointed and have qualified. No appointments shall be made by
any mayor within thirty (30) days of the expiration of his/her term of office.
(Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. Ord. 3548, 8-24-2020)
2-3-3: MEMBERSHIP RESTRICTIONS; REMOVALS:
No person holding an office in the city shall be a member of the board. The
acceptance of any such office by a member of the board shall be treated as a
resignation of his/her position as a member of the board. Members are subject
to removal for cause by a majority vote of the city council. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-
2003)
2-3-4: AUTHORITY:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the duty and authority to
compile the register of eligible names resulting from the examination process
for original appointment in the classified services of the fire and police
departments; the promotional eligibility register for promotional appointments;
and shall serve as the body to hear appeals from any suspension, demotion or
termination which may be imposed by the city against any police officer or
firefighter, and to hear appeals as a result of complaints brought against a
member of the police or fire department by a member of the public. The board
shall have the authority to discipline or discharge police officers or
firefighters. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-5: MEETINGS:
   A.   Notice; Closed Sessions: Notice of regular or special meetings shall be
posted in accordance with the open meetings act and open to the public. During
any regular or special meeting, a closed session may be held upon a proper
motion made by a member of the board. Closed sessions may be limited to board
members and such invited persons as the board may deem necessary.
   B.   Quorum: Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for
the conduct of all business.
   C.   Chairperson And Vice Chairperson: The board shall elect a chairperson
to serve during the fiscal year. The chairperson shall serve for one year or
until a successor is duly elected and qualified. The board may designate one
member to serve as vice chairperson. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. Ord. 3648, 8-
24-2020)
2-3-6: OFFICERS AND ADVISERS:
   A.   Secretary: The board shall elect a member as secretary to keep the
minutes of the board's proceedings and who shall be custodian of all records
pertaining to the business of the board and who shall keep a record of all
examinations held.
   B.   Attorney For Board: The city attorney shall represent the board and
handle all matters before the board upon behalf of the city. In the event that
the city attorney shall represent the board, the city may employ an attorney of
its choosing to serve as prosecutor before the board. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-7: GOVERNING RULES:
   A.   Formulate And Distribute: The board shall formulate rules to carry out
the purposes of these provisions. All rules and revisions thereto shall be made
available for distribution but not more than ten (10) days from the date of
adoption.
   B.   Substance And Application: The governing rules shall apply only to the
examination process for certification to the eligibility list and promotional
register and to the appeals process which may be filed by an officer or
firefighter as a result of a suspension, demotion or termination imposed by the
city.
   C.   Limitation Of Rules: No governing rules of the board shall apply to the
operation of the police or fire department or the conduct of each department's
members.
   D.   Examination Process: The board of fire and police commissioners shall
have the authority to promulgate rules governing the examination process for
original appointment and promotion in the classified service of the fire and
police departments. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-8: PROCEDURES FOR APPOINTMENT, PROMOTION AND REMOVAL OF POLICE AND FIRE
PERSONNEL:
   A.   Application Process:
      1.   Application Forms: Application forms for positions in the police or
fire department shall be available in the city clerk's office. Completed forms
shall be kept on file pending publication of the test date. Upon publication of
the test date, the clerk shall notify, by mail, those persons who have
completed an application form that said form will be available in the clerk's
office during regular business hours. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   Time For Filing; Preemployment Agreement: Applications for positions
in the police or fire department shall consist of a completed application form
provided by the city. Applications shall be submitted to the city clerk's
office by the deadline determined by the board with respect to each
examination. Such dates shall be included in the publication of the examination
notice. In addition, each person submitting an application shall submit a
signed preemployment agreement on the form provided by the city clerk.
      3.   Informational Booklet: Upon submission of a completed application
form and the signed preemployment agreement, each applicant shall receive a
written explanation of the testing procedures for original appointment to the
police or fire department. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
   B.   Appointments: The board, upon compilation of an eligibility list for
original appointment to either the fire department or police department, shall
deliver to the mayor an alphabetical list of names of all qualified and
eligible persons for the positions. The mayor, in conjunction with the
appointment committee, shall make all appointments to the fire and police
departments from the list of eligible candidates, or the mayor, in conjunction
with the appointment committee, may appoint a former employee of the fire or
police department who was in the employment of the city within the immediate
preceding three (3) years. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003; amd. Ord. 2028, 8-1-2005)
   C.   Promotions:
      1.   The board, upon completion of an eligibility register for
promotional appointments to either the police department or fire department,
shall deliver to the appointment committee an alphabetical list of the names of
all qualified and eligible people for said positions. The appointment committee
shall make all promotional appointments to the police and fire departments from
the list of eligible candidates. Any certificate of appointment issued to any
officer or member of the police or fire department shall be signed by the
mayor. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
      2.   If a candidate does not wish to be certified as one of the eligible
candidates for promotion, then his name will be dropped from the eligibility
list, or if the certified letter is returned from the post office as
undeliverable, then the board of police and fire commissioners will remove the
name of the unavailable candidate from the eligibility list. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-
2003; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   Review Of Disciplinary Action:
      1.   Appeals Board: The board has no authority in disciplinary matters
involving police officers and firefighters other than to serve as an appeal
board from any disciplinary action taken by the chief of that department.
      2.   Criteria For Appeal: Any police officer or firefighter who has been
suspended, demoted or terminated by action of a chief may appeal that action to
the board.
      3.   Decision: The board is hereby granted the authority to affirm,
modify, or reverse the decision by the chief. The chief may appeal any decision
of the board to reverse his decision to the circuit court pursuant to the
administrative review law.
      4.   Application Of Disciplinary Action: The provisions of this
subsection shall apply only to full time firefighters and full time police
officers who hold the rank of patrol officer or firefighter or above and not to
any other personnel of the city or the police or fire chief. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-
2003)
2-3-9: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall provide to the mayor an annual report of its activities and of
the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
2-3-10: FACILITIES AND FUNDS:
The city shall allow reasonable use of public buildings for meetings and for
the holding of examinations and shall provide adequate funds in the annual
appropriation for the operation of the board. (Ord. 1925, 10-6-2003)
CHAPTER 4
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD
SECTION:
2-4-1: Established
2-4-2: Composition; Election
2-4-3: Rules And Regulations
2-4-4: Revenues
2-4-5: Penalty
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED:
There shall be established in the city a board known as the foreign fire
insurance tax board. (Ord. 2291, 11-23-2009)
2-4-2: COMPOSITION; ELECTION:
The seven (7) member foreign fire insurance tax board shall be elected in whole
by the city fire department and shall consist of the fire chief, who shall hold
office by virtue of rank, and six (6) members, who shall be elected at large by
the sworn members of the department. (Ord. 2291, 11-23-2009)
2-4-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The foreign fire insurance tax board shall make needful rules and regulations
with respect to the management and operation of the board. (Ord. 2291, 11-23-
2009)
2-4-4: REVENUES:
   A.   Duties Of Board Treasurer: The treasurer of the foreign fire insurance
tax board shall receive the appropriated funds and shall administer the funds
paid to him pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 et seq., for
the maintenance, use and benefit of the city fire department, as determined and
authorized by a majority who are, as their principal occupation, directly
engaged in fire suppression, fire inspection or fire prevention.
   B.   Annual Audit: The funds of the foreign fire insurance tax board shall
be annually audited as part of the city's annual audit. (Ord. 2291, 11-23-2009)
2-4-5: PENALTY:
Any person, corporation, company or association which violates any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord.
2291, 11-23-2009)
CHAPTER 5
JOINT EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEMS BOARD
SECTION:
2-5-1: Established
2-5-2: Composition
2-5-3: Compensation
2-5-4: Terms Of Office
2-5-5: Powers And Duties
2-5-1: ESTABLISHED:
   A.   As authorized by 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750 et seq. (hereinafter
the act), the county of Williamson, state of Illinois, a unit of local
government (hereinafter the county) and the city of Herrin, state of Illinois,
a municipal corporation (hereinafter Herrin), did on November 22, 1993, enter
into an intergovernmental agreement establishing a joint emergency telephone
systems board (hereinafter the board).
   B.   The city of Marion (hereinafter Marion), did on April 4, 1994,
establish its own emergency telephone system board.
   C.   The act has been amended from time to time by the Illinois legislature
requiring changes in the process and appointment of board members and other
matters. Most recently, pursuant to public act 99-6, the legislature created a
mandatory requirement of only one joint board for Williamson County.
   D.   The county, Herrin, and Marion must comply with the law and join
together to form only one emergency telephone systems board for Williamson
County.
   E.   The corporate authorities, being the county, Herrin, and Marion, shall
provide pursuant to the act for the manner and number of appointees to the
board, as long as there are at least five (5) members appointed to the board,
and one member shall be a member of the county board of Williamson County, one
member shall be a public member who is a resident of the local exchange service
territory included in the
9-1-1 coverage area, and the other members shall be representatives of
9-1-1 public safety agencies (as defined by the act) within the
9-1-1 coverage area and who participate in emergency
9-1-1 services, including, but not limited to, police departments, fire
departments, emergency medical services providers, and emergency services and
disaster agencies, and appointed on the basis of their ability or experience.
   F.   The corporate authorities being the county, Herrin, and Marion, shall
determine the powers and duties of the board, pursuant to the act, and this
joint agreement shall define such powers and duties.
   G.   Illinois Statutes 1  require auditing of governmental entities which
expend public funds and the concept of transparency of government being of
extreme importance. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; 50 ILCS 310/1 et seq.
2-5-2: COMPOSITION:
   A.   The board will be comprised of nine (9) members.
      1.   Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by Herrin pursuant
to its rules. Two (2) members shall be from public safety agencies (as defined
by the act) within Herrin who participate in emergency
9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience. One member shall be a
public member who is a resident of the local exchange service territory as
required by the act. If at any time one of Herrin's members resigns from the
board during their term, Herrin shall appoint a new representative, based on
ability and experience, within Herrin, to complete the remainder of that term.
If the public member resigns, that member shall be replaced with a public
member, and if a representative from the public safety agency resigns, that
member shall be replaced by another representative from a public safety agency.
Consideration shall first be given to a member of the Herrin public safety
answering point (PSAP) agency.
      2.   Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by the county
pursuant to its rules. Two (2) members shall be from public safety agencies (as
defined by the act) within Williamson County who participate in emergency
9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience, and the remaining
member shall be a county commissioner. If at any time one of the county members
resigns from the board during their term, the county shall appoint a new member
based on ability and experience to complete the remainder of the term. If a
commissioner resigns, that member shall be replaced with another commissioner,
and if a representative from a public safety agency resigns, that member shall
be replaced by another representative from a public safety agency.
Consideration shall first be given to a member of the county public safety
answering point (PSAP) agency.
      3.   Three (3) members of the board shall be appointed by Marion pursuant
to its rules. Two (2) members shall be from public safety agencies (as defined
by the act) within Marion who participate in emergency
9-1-1 services and based on their ability and experience, and the remaining
member may be either a city commissioner or another member of a public safety
agency. If at any time one of Marion's members resigns from the board during
their term, Marion shall appoint a new representative, based on ability and
experience, to complete the remainder of the term. If a commissioner resigns,
that member shall be replaced with another commissioner, and if a
representative from a public safety agency resigns, that member shall be
replaced by another representative from a public safety agency. Consideration
shall first be given to a member of the Marion public safety answering point
(PSAP) agency.
   B.   In the event a member serving on the board, who was appointed from a
public safety agency who participates in emergency
9-1-1 services, terminates their employment with the public safety agency,
their appointment to the board will also be terminated effective the same date
of termination from employment with the public safety agency. The corporate
authority who originally appointed that member to the board shall appoint a new
member from a public safety agency (as defined by the act) within the
9-1-1 coverage area who participates in emergency
9-1-1 services to serve the remainder of the term. If that member was appointed
from a PSAP, then another person from the PSAP shall be appointed to serve the
remainder of the term. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-3: COMPENSATION:
Members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed
for their actual and necessary expenses. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-4: TERMS OF OFFICE:
All members appointed to serve on the board shall serve three (3) year
staggered terms pursuant to the act, with one-third (1/3) of the members' terms
set to expire January 1, 2016, one- third (1/3) set to expire January 1, 2017,
and remaining board members' terms to expire January 1, 2018. Members may be
reappointed at the expiration of their term. All reappointments or new
appointments made thereafter will be for three (3) years from the date of
expiration of the previous term. The one-third (1/3) shall be determined as one
member from each corporate authority. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
2-5-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The powers and duties of the board shall be in accord with those set
out in 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/15.4 as current and as amended in the
future.
   B.   The board may create bylaws, which will become effective upon approval
of a majority vote of the board, and a copy of which shall be submitted to the
Williamson County board of commissioners, the Herrin city council, and the
Marion city council.
   C.   The county, Herrin, and Marion being required by law to submit annual
audits for any governmental entity spending funds of those governments and
being responsible for establishing the powers and duties of the board and in
the interest of transparency in government, require that the board conduct an
annual audit as set forth in 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 310 et seq.
   D.   Any and all funds collected for the
9-1-1 system shall be kept in the
9-1-1 fund, which is overseen by the county treasurer. The board treasurer
shall work with the county treasurer and
9-1-1 coordinator on investment of JETSB funds and payments of all
9-1-1 bills. All
9-1-1 funds currently in the possession of the city of Marion are to be
combined into the fund with county and Herrin
9-1-1 funds pursuant to the joining of two (2) former boards into one joint
board.
   E.   The sheriff, the Herrin police chief, and the Marion police chief will
continue to operate and staff their
9-1-1 dispatch PSAP centers.
   F.   Pursuant to 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/40(b) and beginning
October 1, 2016, and every October 1 thereafter, the board shall report to the
department of state police audited financial statements showing total revenue
and expenditures for the previous fiscal year. The statements shall include a
detailed summary of revenue from all sources, operating expenses, capital
expenditures, cash balances, and any other financial information deemed
relevant by the department of state police. (Ord. 3271, 8-10-2015)
CHAPTER 6
CULTURAL AND CIVIC CENTER BOARD
SECTION:
2-6-1: Created; Purpose
2-6-2: Composition; Appointment And Terms; Removals
2-6-3: Organization
2-6-4: Powers And Duties
2-6-5: Budget And Annual Report
2-6-1: CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is created the Marion cultural and civic center board, hereinafter
referred to as the "board", which shall have the duty of administering the
operation and maintenance of the building and facility known and referenced as
the "Marion Cultural And Civic Center". The primary purpose of the board is to
encourage and promote a continuing program for the development and propagation
of the arts and of cultural and civic activities that will inure to the benefit
of all the citizens of the city. (1977 Code §§ 2.44.010, 2.44.020; amd. 2013
Code)
2-6-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS; REMOVALS:
The board shall consist of thirteen (13) members, twelve (12) to be appointed
by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. The twelve (12)
members first appointed to the board by the mayor and council shall be
appointed to serve terms as follows: four (4) for a term of three (3) years,
four (4) for a term of two (2) years and four (4) for a term of one year. All
subsequent appointments by the mayor and council shall be for a term of three
(3) years, except in the event of a vacancy, in which case, an appointment
shall be for the time remaining in the unexpired term in which the vacancy
occurs. The thirteenth member shall be a senior at Marion High School appointed
annually to a term of one year by the high school faculty. Any member may be
removed from the board upon three- fourths (3/4) of the city council voting for
such removal. (1977 Code § 2.44.030)
2-6-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Bylaws And Rules; Quorum: The board shall adopt bylaws and such rules
as may be deemed necessary to conduct the affairs of the board and the
operation of the center in an orderly manner; provided, that a quorum shall not
be less than a majority of the members appointed to the board. (1977 Code §
2.44.080)
   B.   Officers: The officers of the board shall consist of a chair, vice
chair, secretary and treasurer. Each of the officers shall be elected annually
by the members of the board except the chair, who shall be appointed by the
mayor annually, with the advice and consent of the city council. (1977 Code §
2.44.040)
   C.   Meetings: The board shall meet regularly on a designated day each
month, and more often as the occasion requires at the call of the chair. Such
meetings shall be held in the civic center building. (1977 Code § 2.44.050)
2-6-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board is empowered and authorized to manage and administer the center in
keeping with and for the purposes set forth in this chapter; to maintain the
center building and equipment in a state of good repair; to conduct the
operation of the center on sound economic principles consistent with the
primary purpose for its establishment; and to employ such personnel as may be
reasonably necessary to accomplish those things the board is authorized and
empowered to do. (1977 Code § 2.44.060)
2-6-5: BUDGET AND ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall prepare and present to the city council an annual budget on or
before the first Monday in April and shall, at the same time, present to the
city council a report of the activities and presentations conducted at the
center during the preceding year. (1977 Code § 2.44.070; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 7
SENIOR CITIZENS' COUNCIL
SECTION:
2-7-1: Created; Purpose
2-7-2: Composition; Appointment And Terms; Removals
2-7-3: Organization
2-7-4: Powers And Duties
2-7-5: Budget And Annual Report
2-7-6: Free Admission To Center
2-7-1: CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is created the Marion senior citizens' council, referred to in this
chapter as the "council", the primary purpose of which is to encourage and
promote a continuing program for the development and propagation of activities,
programs and projects at the Marion Senior Citizens' Center that will inure to
the benefit of all the senior citizens of the city. (1977 Code §§ 2.54.010,
2.54.020)
2-7-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS; REMOVALS:
The council shall consist of nine (9) members, to be appointed by the mayor,
with the advice and consent of the city council. The nine (9) members first
appointed to the council by the mayor and city council shall be appointed to
serve terms as follows: three (3) for a term of three (3) years, three (3) for
a term of two (2) years and three (3) for a term of one year. All subsequent
appointments by the mayor and city council shall be for a term of three (3)
years, except in the event of a vacancy, in which case, an appointment shall be
for the time remaining on the unexpired term in which the vacancy occurs. Any
member may be removed from the council upon three- fourths (3/4) of the city
council voting for such removal. (1977 Code § 2.54.030)
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Bylaws And Rules; Quorum: The council shall adopt bylaws and such rules
as may be deemed necessary to conduct the affairs of the council and the
operation of the center in an orderly manner; provided, that a quorum shall not
be less than a majority of the members appointed to the council. (1977 Code §
2.54.090)
   B.   Officers: The officers of the council shall consist of a chair, vice
chair, secretary and treasurer. Each of the officers shall be elected annually
by the members of the council except the chair, who shall be appointed by the
mayor annually, with the advice and consent of the city council. (1977 Code §
2.54.040)
   C.   Meetings: The council shall meet regularly on a designated day each
month, and more often as the occasion requires at the call of the chair. Such
meetings shall be held in the Marion Senior Citizens' Center building. (1977
Code § 2.54.050)
2-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The council is empowered and authorized to manage and administer the center in
keeping with and for the purposes set forth in this chapter; to maintain the
center building and equipment in a state of good repair; to conduct the
operation of the center on sound economic principles consistent with the
primary purpose for its establishment and the funds available; and to employ,
as funds are available, such personnel as may be reasonably necessary to
accomplish those things the council is authorized and empowered to do. The
council shall not and is not empowered to make any commitment of the city's
credit. (1977 Code § 2.54.060)
2-7-5: BUDGET AND ANNUAL REPORT:
The council shall prepare and present to the city council an annual budget on
or before the first Monday in April and shall, at the same time, present to the
city council a report of the activities and programs conducted at the center
during the preceding year. (1977 Code § 2.54.080; amd. 2013 Code)
2-7-6: FREE ADMISSION TO CENTER:
Admission to the senior citizens' center building and facilities shall be free
to all senior citizens of the city, although moderate and reasonable fees may
be charged for meals provided through a nutrition program, materials used in
handicraft projects, and for other programs or projects of a special nature.
(1977 Code § 2.54.070)
TITLE 3
FINANCE AND TAXATION
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL FINANCE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Fiscal And Municipal Years
3-1-2: Signatures On Checks
3-1-3: Annual Audit
3-1-4: Acceptance Of Offered Funds
3-1-5: Cash Reserve Balance Policy
3-1-1: FISCAL AND MUNICIPAL YEARS:
The fiscal year and the municipal year for the city shall hereafter commence on
May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of each succeeding year. (1977 Code §
1.16.010)
3-1-2: SIGNATURES ON CHECKS:
All checks for payment of money by the city shall be signed by one of the
authorized city commissioners and either the city treasurer or the assistant
city treasurer. (Ord. 3366, 2-3-2017)
3-1-3: ANNUAL AUDIT:
An annual audit of all city funds shall be conducted by an independent state
licensed auditor as soon as practicable after April 30. (2013 Code)
3-1-4: ACCEPTANCE OF OFFERED FUNDS:
In the unlikely event that any funds should be offered or made available to the
city without affecting the city's credit and without the city incurring any
liability or obligation whatsoever, the mayor and no less than two (2) of the
city commissioners are hereby authorized to do those things and to perform such
lawful acts as may be necessary to accept and receive such funds on behalf of
the city. (Ord. 1241, 7-11-1988)
3-1-5: CASH RESERVE BALANCE POLICY:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this section is to establish a cash reserve
balance policy tailored to the needs of the city to ensure against unforeseen
events that would adversely affect the financial condition of the city and
jeopardize the continuation of necessary public services. This section will
ensure the city maintains an adequate cash reserve balance in the city's
general fund to provide the ability to:
      1.   Provide sufficient cash flow for daily financial needs.
      2.   Support the highest possible bond rating.
      3.   Offset significant economic downturns or revenue shortfalls.
      4.   Provide funds for unforeseen emergency expenditures.
   B.   Definition: Cash reserve balance is the term that will be used to
represent the general fund cash set aside from operating funds to be used for
the purposes as described in subsection A of this section.
   C.   General Policy:
      1.   The cash reserve balance for the general fund shall be maintained at
a minimum level equal to or greater than twenty five percent (25%) of the
general fund current year budgeted expenditures including transfers from the
general fund less capital outlays supported by specific revenue sources.
      2.   The cash reserve balance shall be reviewed annually during the
budget process.
      3.   If at any time during or after the budget process, the city council
determines that a portion of the twenty five percent (25%) reserve must be
used, the city council will take all necessary actions to increase the cash
reserve balance to the twenty five percent (25%) threshold in future years.
(Ord. 3004, 10-10-2011)
CHAPTER 2
BUDGET OFFICER FINANCE SYSTEM
SECTION:
3-2-1: Budget Officer
3-2-2: Compilation And Contents Of Budget
3-2-3: Passage Of Annual Budget
3-2-4: Capital Improvement, Repair Or Replacement Fund
3-2-5: Revisions To Budget
3-2-6: Funds For Contingency Purposes
3-2-7: Public Inspection, Notice And Hearing On Budget
3-2-1: BUDGET OFFICER:
   A.   Position Created And Designated; Term: There is created hereby the
position of budget officer in the city, who shall be designated by the
commissioner of accounts and finances, with a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the city
council. The budget officer shall serve at the pleasure of the city council.
   B.   Oath And Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the
budget officer shall take oath and post bond as provided by statute.
   C.   May Hold Another Office: The budget officer may hold another municipal
office, either elected or appointed.
   D.   Compensation: The budget officer shall not receive compensation for
this office.
   E.   Powers And Duties: The budget officer shall have the following powers
and duties:
      1.   To permit, encourage, and establish the efficient planning,
budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting, and other fiscal management
procedures in all municipal departments, commissions, and boards.
      2.   To compile an annual budget in accord with 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-2-9.3.
      3.   To examine all books and records of all city departments,
commissions, and boards which relate to monies received and paid out by the
city, its departments, commissions, and boards, and debts and accounts
receivable, amounts owed by or to the city and its departments, commissions,
and boards.
      4.   To obtain such additional information from the city and its
departments, commissions, and boards as may be useful for purposes of compiling
a municipal budget; such information to be furnished by the city and its
departments, commissions, and boards, in the form required by the budget
officer. Any department, commission, or board which refuses to make such
information as requested to the budget officer shall not be permitted to make
expenditures under any subsequent budget for the city until such department,
commission, or board shall comply in full with the request of the budget
officer.
      5.   To establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no
expenditures are made by the city or its departments, commissions, or boards
except as authorized by the budget. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-2: COMPILATION AND CONTENTS OF BUDGET:
The budget officer shall compile a budget which contains estimates of revenues
available to the city for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted,
together with recommended expenditures for the city and all of its departments,
commissions, and boards. Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations
shall be presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal
management practices. The budget shall be itemized in a manner to conform with
the chart of accounts utilized by the city's accounting system. The budget
shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two (2)
years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared.
Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated
expenditure shall be made. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-3: PASSAGE OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
   A.   Passage of the annual budget by adoption of an appropriate ordinance by
the corporate authorities shall be in lieu of passage of the appropriation
ordinance as required by statute.
   B.   The annual budget shall be published in the manner provided in section
3-2-7 of this chapter.
   C.   The annual budget shall be adopted by the corporate authorities before
the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-4: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT, REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT FUND:
   A.   In the preparation of the budget by the budget officer, an amount not
to exceed three percent (3%) of the equalized assessed value of property
subject to taxation by the city may be accumulated in a separate fund for the
purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs, and/or
replacement of specific types of municipal equipment or other tangible
property, both real and personal, to be designated as the "capital improvement,
repair or replacement fund".
   B.   Expenditures from the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund
shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair
or replacement will occur.
   C.   Upon the completion or abandonment of any project, or in the event any
surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of any project for
which the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund was instituted, then
such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair or replacement
shall be transferred to the general corporate fund of the city on the first day
of the fiscal year following such abandonment or completion, or discovery of
surplus funds. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-5: REVISIONS TO BUDGET:
Heads of city departments and boards may, with prior approval of the budget
officer and the city administrator, initiate transfers of funds between line
items within departments and may delete, add or change line items within
departments. Nothing herein shall prohibit any commissioner to initiate
transfers of funds between line items within his or her department and may
delete, add or change line items within his or her department. All other
revisions by transfer, deletion or adding or changing budgeted items require
approval by the city council by a two-thirds (2/3) vote. However, under no
circumstances shall a revision be made to the budget which increases the budget
in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision.
Nothing in this section shall prohibit revision in the event funds are
available from any source including, but not limited to, loan proceeds, grant
funding, anticipated tax receipts or projected sales tax revenue. (Ord. 2376,
10-24-2011)
3-2-6: FUNDS FOR CONTINGENCY PURPOSES:
The annual budget may contain money set aside for contingency purposes not to
exceed ten percent (10%) of the total budget, which may be expended for
contingencies upon a majority vote of the city council. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
3-2-7: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE AND HEARING ON BUDGET:
   A.   The city council shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently
available to public inspection for at least ten (10) days prior to the passage
of the annual budget by publication in the journal of the proceedings of the
corporate authorities or in such other form as the city council may prescribe.
   B.   Not less than one week after the publication of the tentative annual
budget and prior to final action on the budget, the city council shall hold at
least one public hearing on the tentative annual budget, after which hearing or
hearings the tentative annual budget may be further revised and passed without
any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be given
by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least
one week prior to the time of the hearing. (Ord. 2376, 10-24-2011)
CHAPTER 3
DEBT MANAGEMENT POLICY
SECTION:
3-3-1: Purpose
3-3-2: Annual Review
3-3-3: Periodic Reviews
3-3-4: Debt Limits
3-3-5: Debt Features And Structures
3-3-6: Short Term Debt
3-3-7: Long Term Debt
3-3-8: Financial Professional
3-3-9: Capital Leasing
3-3-10: Investment Of Bond Proceeds
3-3-11: Modifications Of Provisions
3-3-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish guidelines for the issuance of
debt, including leases, financing of capital projects, infrastructure and other
projects deemed necessary by the city council. This policy will assist the city
council to:
   A.   Obtain financing only when necessary.
   B.   Reduce debt interest costs.
   C.   Take all practical precautions to avoid any financial decisions which
will negatively impact current credit ratings on future debt issues.
   D.   Secure and maintain the highest possible bond rating. (Ord. 3005, 10-
10-2011)
3-3-2: ANNUAL REVIEW:
During the preparation of the city's annual budget, the city council shall
perform the following tasks in relation to its debt:
   A.   Assess the benefits for financing of projects budgeted in the next
budget year.
   B.   Review outstanding debt for refunding (interest savings, eliminating
restrictive covenants, etc.) and/or consolidation.
   C.   Review compliance with applicable financing documents (including bond
ordinances, credit enhancement policies, continuing disclosure requirements,
etc.). (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-3: PERIODIC REVIEWS:
The city council or its designee, semiannually, shall review debt service
accounts to ensure they are maintained in accordance with their bond
ordinances. As conditions merit, the city council or its designee shall review
or identify outstanding debt issues for refunding for interest savings. (Ord.
3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-4: DEBT LIMITS:
As a home rule unit of government, the city is not subject to debt limits. It
has the ability to issue general obligation debt without limitation or
referendum. However, it is the intent of the city council to be prudent in its
issuance of debt. Debt repaid solely from collection of property taxes should
not exceed ten percent (10%) of the city's most recent equalized assessed
valuation. However, this does not apply to general obligation bonds issued by
the city that it intends to repay from sources other than property taxes. If
less than one hundred percent (100%) of the annual debt service associated with
any bond is to be paid from property taxes, the amount of property taxes
extended shall be discounted at the bond interest rate(s) to determine the bond
par amount to be considered general obligation debt for purposes of its self-
imposed debt limit (this calculation is not required if the bond's principal
amounts are identified and the corresponding debt service is equal to the
property tax levied). Debt intended to be repaid from sources other than
property taxes are excluded from this section, whether or not it is issued as
general obligation debt. On an annual basis, prior to abating the current
property tax levy associated with such general obligation bonds, the city
council shall identify and designate the funds to be used for the payment of
such bonds. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-5: DEBT FEATURES AND STRUCTURES:
Debt may be issued on the basis of: a) fixed or variable rate; b) taxable or
tax exempt; c) rated or nonrated; d) bank qualified or nonbank qualified; e)
credit enhanced or noncredit enhanced; f) term or serial maturities, including
balloon payments; g) callable and noncallable; h) private placements; and i)
restrictive covenants as required. Credit enhancement and ratings should be
used where applicable and there is cost benefit based on interest rate savings.
Long term debt should be callable with the earliest possible call feature that
does not impact the overall interest rate. The recommended maximum call feature
is a ten (10) year par call. Variable rate debt should be considered when
interest rates are expected to decline or remain flat. When possible, debt
should be issued as bank qualified. This section is not all encompassing and is
not intended to limit the city's debt structures. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-6: SHORT TERM DEBT:
For purposes of this policy, "short term debt" is defined as any debt incurred
whose final maturity is five (5) years or less. Short term debt may be used to
purchase equipment and for other purposes deemed necessary by the city council,
including the refunding of debt, as long as the purpose is not prohibited by
state statute. Short term debt issued for operating/cash flow purposes should
mature within the time frame in which the proceeds will be spent, but no longer
than one year after such time. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-7: LONG TERM DEBT:
For purposes of this policy, "long term debt" is defined as any debt incurred
whose final maturity is greater than five (5) years. Long term debt may be used
for the purchase of equipment, capital projects and/or any other purpose deemed
necessary by the city council (other than for operating purposes), including
refunding of debt, as long as the purpose is not prohibited by state statute.
Financing terms shall not exceed the useful life of the projects financed. Debt
issues should not exceed forty (40) years. When issuing long term debt, the
city council should consider the following debt types:
   A.   Alternate revenue debt obligations or general obligations debt to be
repaid from sources other than property taxes. These obligations require the
expected revenues to sufficiently meet debt service requirements for the life
of these obligations.
   B.   General revenue debt obligations to be repaid from property taxes. This
obligation is payable from a direct property tax levied and collected within
the city.
   C.   Private activity obligations. These obligations may be issued by the
city for the behalf of the issuer that provide special financing benefits to
qualified projects. These obligations are subject to internal revenue service
requirements and state volume caps to preserve tax exemption. The cost of
issuance of private activity obligations is usually higher than for
governmental purpose obligations. Typically, the city has no obligation to pay
debt service for private activity obligations; they are not a liability of the
city and do not count as city debt. They should be used to promote economic
development within the city.
   D.   Special service area and special assessment obligations. These
obligations may be issued by the city for the designated taxpayers receiving
the benefit. The taxpayers within the designated area are responsible for the
payment of debt service on such obligations and can be paid from property taxes
or a special assessment within the designated area. These obligations are
typically issued in response to property owners within the designated area
requesting infrastructure/utilities improvements. These obligations are not a
liability of the city and are not considered city debt. Alternate revenue debt
obligations or general obligations debt are to be repaid from sources other
than property taxes. These obligations require the expected revenues to
sufficiently meet debt service requirements for the life of these obligations.
   E.   Tax increment financing obligations. These obligations are used to
promote economic development within a designated tax increment finance
district. They are repaid from the incremental property taxes generated within
the district. Unless backed by the city, such obligations are not a liability
of the city and are not considered a city debt. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-8: FINANCIAL PROFESSIONAL:
When deemed necessary by the city council, it shall seek advice from a
financial professional. The financial professional to be used by the city
should have experience with debt structuring (including type and length) and
working with bond rating services and other services deemed necessary by the
city council. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-9: CAPITAL LEASING:
Capital leasing, when offered, is an option to finance the acquisition of major
depreciable assets. A capital lease is a long term lease that transfers to the
lessee most rights and obligations concerning the asset leased, and usually
transfers ownership at the end of the lease. The city council should consider
the advice of the city's finance professional or bond counsel when capital
leasing arrangements are used and when federal tax forms are prepared to ensure
that all federal tax laws are followed. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-10: INVESTMENT OF BOND PROCEEDS:
   A.   The investment of bond proceeds shall be dictated by the bond
indenture, state statutes and the city's investment policy. The city finance
director-treasurer, with the advice of the city's financial professional, shall
prepare the drawdown requirements for the bond proceeds which shall be used to
create investment parameters for the bond proceeds. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011;
amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Due consideration shall be given debt covenants and arbitrage
requirements, the purpose of which is to maintain compliance with both.
Investment adjustments shall be made as required.
   C.   Debt service reserve funds shall be maintained and invested, as
applicable, in compliance with the above. (Ord. 3005, 10-10-2011)
3-3-11: MODIFICATIONS OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter is not meant as all encompassing but rather a guideline, subject
to periodic (or at least annual) review by the city council, at which time it
may be modified and amended as the city council deems appropriate. (Ord. 3005,
10-10-2011)
CHAPTER 4
PURCHASING REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Purchasing Procedures
3-4-2: Purchasing Guidelines
3-4-3: Exceptions/Deviations
3-4-4: Subdivision Of Contracts
3-4-1: PURCHASING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Purchase Orders: All purchases, except for items listed in Section 3-4-
4, require the completion, submission, and approval of a purchase order before
any purchase can be made, Purchase orders shall be completed in accordance with
the attached instructions.
   B.   Departmental Purchasing Agent(s): Each department head and
superintendent are hereby designated as a departmental purchasing agent. Each
department head or superintendent may, at his/her discretion, appoint
supervisory employee(s) as departmental purchasing agent(s), who shall be
responsible for ensuring the completion and submission of the required purchase
order and supporting documentation. The departmental purchasing agent shall be
responsible for purchasing activities in the absence of the department head/
superintendent. The department head shall be responsible for ensuring proper
purchasing procedures are followed, that enough funds are budgeted for all
purchases, and that required documentation is kept in the department's files.
   C.   Responsibilities of the Mayor or Mayor's Chief of Staff/City Council:
The Mayor or Mayor's Chief of Staff shall have the authority to reject any
purchase order that has not been completed according to the stated procedures
or return to the department any purchase order that requires additional
attention. The Mayor or Mayor's Chief of Staff shall provide guidance to
departments on purchasing procedures and guidelines. Any questions or instances
not addressed by this procedure shall be referred to the Mayor or Mayor's Chief
of Staff for determination on whether to refer to the City Council for
consideration or amendment of the policy.
   D.   State or Federal Law: Any State or Federal law that is more restrictive
than this procedure shall supersede the affected portion of this procedure.
(Ord. 3529, 5-13-2019; amd. Ord. 4000, 1-27-2025)
3-4-2: PURCHASING GUIDELINES:
The following guidelines shall apply to purchases of items that have been
approved, either generally or specifically, in the budget.
   A.   The following departments shall have a $1,000.00 per purchase order
department approval limit:
      Mayor regarding his/her departments, City Clerk's Office, Code
Enforcement, Boyton Street, GIS/EMA, and Water Office.
      The departmental purchasing agent may make purchases in this category.
Such purchases do not require competitive quotes. However, the departmental
purchasing agent should ensure, when possible, that such items are acquired at
the lowest possible price, considering all relevant factors.
   B.   The following departments shall have a $3,000.00 per purchase order
department approval limit:
      Information Technology, Cemetery, Hub Recreational Center, Safety, Civic
Center, Library, Pavilion, Treasurer's Office, and Senior Citizen's Center
      It is recommended but not required that three bids be obtained for
purchases more than $1,000.00. If bids are obtained, they should be documented
on the purchase order or on a document attached to the purchase order.
   C.   The following departments shall have a $5,000.00 per purchase order
department approval limit:
      Fire Dept., Police Dept, Outside Water, Sewer Dept and Street Dept.
      Animal Control is under the Police Department and thus is subject to the
Police Department spending limit and must be approved by the Police Chief.
      The departmental purchasing agent may make purchases in this category. It
is recommended but not required that three bids be obtained for purchases more
than $1,000.00. If bids are obtained, they should be documented on the purchase
order or on a document attached to the purchase order.
   D.   For purchases over the department's spending limits but not over
$15,000.00 the departmental purchasing agent must obtain the approval of the
Mayor, the department's City Commissioner or in their absence the Mayor's Chief
of Staff. It is recommended but not required that 3 bids be obtained. If bids
are obtained, they should be documented on the purchase order or on a document
attached to the purchase order.
   E.   Purchases Over $15,000.00--City Council Approval. Purchases in this
category require approval of the City Council before the purchase is made.
Unless required by state statute, the City Council at its discretion will
decide if bids should be taken and by what method the bids should be obtained.
(Ord. 3529, 5-13-2019; amd. Ord. 3575, 10-14-2019; Ord. 4000, 1-27-2025)
3-4-3: EXCEPTIONS/DEVIATIONS:
The following situations may require deviation from the stated procedures.
   A.   Emergency Purchases: Emergency situations allowing emergency purchases
shall be defined as those in which the operation of a department/division would
be hampered, or when the protection and preservation of public property or life
would not be possible without action requiring an emergency purchase, and
required procedures are not possible. If an emergency purchase is required,
then the approval discussed above may be obtained after the emergency purchase
has been made. Such purchases, not exceeding the department purchasing limit
may be made by the departmental purchasing agent after department head
approval. The department head shall be responsible for determining the extent
of the emergency and the need for their department's Commissioner, or Mayor, or
in their absence the Mayor's Chief of Staff approval for any emergency
purchases over the department's spending limit but not more than $7,500.00. Any
emergency purchase more than $7,500.00 must be approved by the Commissioner, or
the Mayor or in their absence the Mayor's Chief of Staff and shall have the
responsibility of requiring Council action as necessary.
   B.   The following items may be approved by the departmental purchasing
agent even if the amount is over $15,000.00:
      I.   Utilities.
      2.   Payments on contracts previously approved by the City Council.
   C.   Purchase orders are not required for items paid with Petty Cash Funds.
   D.   Purchase orders are not required for purchases up to the spending
authority established herein except when interdepartmental purchases are made.
When an interdepartmental purchase is made that exceeds $100.00, the benefiting
department head shall sign off on a purchase order. (Ord. 3529, 5-13-2019; amd.
Ord. 4000, 1-27-2025)
3-4-4: SUBDIVISION OF CONTRACTS:
No purchase, agreement, or contract for services may be subdivided to avoid the
requirements of this policy. (Ord. 3529, 5-13-2019; amd. Ord. 4000, 1-27-2025)
CHAPTER 5
TAXES
ARTICLE A. MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
3-5A-1: Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
3-5A-2: Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax
3-5A-3: Home Rule Municipal Use Tax
3-5A-4: Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax
3-5A-5: Municipal Grocery Retailers' Occupation Tax And A Municipal Grocery
Service Occupation Tax
3-5A-1: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate; Exclusions: The Corporate Authorities of the
Municipality shall and do hereby impose a tax upon all persons engaged in the
Municipality in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than
an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of
the State of Illinois, at retail in the Municipality at the rate of 2.25
percent on and of the gross receipts from those sales made in the course of
such business. This tax shall only be imposed at the rate of 2.25 percent as
authorized by the Act, which is at the same rate that the Municipality imposes
a Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax under the Home Rule Municipal
Service Occupation Tax Act. Under the Act, this additional tax may not be
imposed on the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off
the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and
food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and
nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing
materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics and otherwise or hereafter
required by applicable law.
   B.   Collection And Enforcement: The tax imposed by the Municipality under
this section and the Act and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident of the tax shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department
of Revenue.
   C.   Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize
the Municipality to impose a tax upon the privilege of engaging in any business
which under the Constitution of the United States may not be made the subject
of taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to the
contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with
the Act as it shall from time to time be in effect.
   D.   Effective Date: Pursuant to the Municipality's home rule authority,
sections 1-2-4 and 4-5-13 of the Illinois Municipal Code shall not apply to
this section. This section shall become effective immediately upon its adoption
and approval and the tax under subsection A of this section shall be given
effect in the time and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 3674, 3-20-2017;
amd. Ord. 3563, 9-23-2019; Ord. 3564, 9-23-2019)
3-5A-2: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate; Exclusions: The Corporate Authorities of the
Municipality shall and do hereby impose a tax upon all persons engaged in the
Municipality in the business of making sales of service at the rate of 1.50
percent of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by
such servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form
of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. This tax shall only be
imposed at the rate of 1.50 percent of the selling price, as authorized by the
Act which is at the same rate that the Municipality imposes a Home Rule
Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax under the Home Rule Municipal Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act. Under the Act this additional tax may not be imposed on the
sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises
where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has
been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription
medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials,
syringes and needles used by diabetics and otherwise or hereafter required by
applicable law.
   B.   Collection And Enforcement: The tax imposed by the Municipality under
this section and the Act and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident of the tax shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department
of Revenue.
   C.   Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize
the Municipality to impose a tax upon the privilege of engaging in any business
which under the Constitution of the United States may not be made the subject
of taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to the
contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with
the Act as it shall from time to time be in effect.
   D.   Effective Date: Pursuant to the Municipality's home rule authority,
sections
1-2-4 and 4-5-13 of the Illinois Municipal Code shall not apply to this
section. This section shall become effective immediately upon its adoption and
approval and the tax under subsection A of this section shall be given effect
in the time and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 3675, 3-20-2017)
3-5A-3: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate: The Corporate Authorities of the City shall and do
hereby impose a tax at the rate of one percent (1.00%) upon the privilege of
using, in the City, any item of tangible personal property which is purchased
at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered at a location
within the corporate limits of the City with an agency of the government of the
State of Illinois. The tax shall only be imposed at the rate of one percent
(1.00%) and based on the selling price of such tangible personal property, as
"selling price" is defined in the Use Tax Act 1 , as authorized by the Act.
(Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001)
   B.   Collection And Enforcement:
      1.   The City's population is seventeen thousand one hundred twenty nine
(17,129) under the most recently adjusted figures of or supplementing the 2000
Federal census. Under the Act, in home rule municipalities with less than two
million (2,000,000) inhabitants, the tax shall be collected by the City
imposing the tax from persons whose Illinois address for titling or
registration purposes is given as being in such City. (Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001;
amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   The tax imposed by the City under this section and the Act and all
civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident of the tax shall be
collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue, to the extent
authorized by applicable law, if at all, and otherwise shall be collected and
enforced by the City. The City acknowledges that under present law, the
Illinois Department of Revenue does not collect or enforce this tax.
   C.   Limitations: Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize
the City to impose a tax upon the privilege of engaging in any business which,
under the Constitution of the United States, may not be made the subject of
taxation by the State of Illinois. Notwithstanding anything herein to the
contrary, this section shall be given effect in such a manner as to comply with
the Act as it shall, from time to time, be in effect.
   D.   Effective Date: Pursuant to the City's home rule authority, 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-4 and 5/4-5-13 shall not apply to this section. This
section shall become effective immediately upon its adoption and approval, and
the tax under subsection A of this section shall be given effect in the time
and manner as provided in the Act. (Ord. 1815, 9-10-2001)

   B.   Tax Imposed; Rate And Restrictions:
      1.   The corporate authorities of the city hereby impose a tax upon all
persons engaged in the city in the business of renting, leasing or letting
rooms in a hotel at a rate of three percent (3%) of the gross rental receipts
from such renting, leasing or letting, excluding, however, from the gross
rental receipts, the proceeds of such renting, leasing or letting to permanent
residents of that hotel.
      2.   Persons subject to the tax imposed pursuant to this section may
reimburse themselves for their tax liability for such tax by separately stating
such tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in
a single amount, with state tax imposed under the Hotel Operators' Occupation
Tax Act. However, the tax shall not be levied and imposed upon any permanent
resident or to a person who works and lives in the same hotel or motel.
      3.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the city to
impose a tax upon the privilege of engaging in any business which, under the
constitution of the United States, may not be made the subject of taxation by
the State of Illinois.
   C.   Registration Requirements:
      1.   Each hotel located within the boundaries of the city shall file a
"certificate of registration" within the office of the City Clerk, whose office
is located at Marion City Hall, 1102 Tower Square, Marion, Illinois.
Registration forms shall be available to each hotel operator through the office
of the City Clerk's Office.
      2.   It is the duty of the hotel operator to update the "certificate of
registration" form on an annual basis. The final date for filing and updating
this certificate of registration shall be December 15 of each year, commencing
December 15, 2011, following the effective date hereof. Any new business coming
under license to do business as a hotel within the city shall file a
certificate of registration no later than thirty (30) days following the first
day of operation as a new hotel business.
   D.   Report Required: Each Lessor shall file an "occupancy tax report" each
month following the effective date hereof. The report shall contain the total
dollar gross receipts received from room occupancy rentals along with the total
amount due and payable to the city as required by this section. Occupancy tax
reports shall be available to each hotel operator and Lessor through the office
of the City Clerk.
   E.   Duty to Collect: It shall be the duty of every Lessor of every Hotel
within the City to collect the tax from the Lessee at the time the Lessee pays
for the privilege of occupying all or part of a Hotel Transient Occupancy
Rental Unit, and to remit to the City the tax under procedures provided for in
this chapter or otherwise prescribed by the City. If more than one Person is
the Lessor as related to a particular transaction, the Lessors are jointly and
severally responsible for collecting and remitting the tax. The Lessor
receiving the revenue from the Lessee is responsible for
   F.   Due Date; Late Payment Penalty: All taxes due the city shall be paid
and remitted to the city on or before the last day of the month immediately
following the month of collection. A one percent (1%) late penalty will be due
and payable to the city should any hotel Lessor fail to file an occupancy tax
report by the end of each given month, and an additional one percent (1%) each
month thereafter.
   G.   Remittance Of Taxes; Disposition And Use Of Funds:
      1.   All taxes due and owing the city under this section shall be made
payable by or on behalf of the Lessor to the "City Clerk of the City of Marion,
Illinois", and shall be due and payable monthly to the City Clerk on or before
the tenth day of each month after the effective date hereof. The finance
director- treasurer shall transfer such funds, by the fifteenth of the month
following collection, into a separate fund established for the city tourism
fund.
      2.   The amounts collected by the city pursuant to this section shall be
expended by the city solely to promote tourism and conventions within the city
or otherwise to attract nonresident overnight visitors to the city.
      3.   No funds received pursuant to this section shall be used to
advertise for or otherwise promote new competition in the hotel business.
   H.   Interpretation And Effective Date:
      1.   This section incorporates chapter 6 of this title concerning the
local government taxpayers' bill of rights act.
      2.   This section shall be effective immediately upon its adoption,
approval and publication in pamphlet form; provided, that the hotel tax imposed
by this section shall not become effective until the later of: a) June 22,
2011; or b) the date that the Illinois finance authority's qualified 501(c)(3)
not for profit revenue bonds (Williamson County events commission project),
series 2003, are not outstanding. Pursuant to section 6 (powers of home rule
units) of article VII (local government) of the constitution of the state of
Illinois, sections 1-2-4, 8-1-7 and 4-5-13 of the Illinois municipal code shall
not apply to this section. (Ord. 2356, 6-13-2011; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3216, 9-
8-2014; Ord. 3730, 5-24-2021; Ord. 3882, 5-8-2023)
3-5A-5: MUNICIPAL GROCERY RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND A MUNICIPAL GROCERY
SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Municipal Grocery Retailers' Occupation Tax Imposed. A tax is hereby
imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling groceries at retail
in this municipality at the rate of 1% of the gross receipts from such sales
made in the course of such business while this Ordinance is in effect. The
imposition of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of
Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24).
   B.   Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax.
      1.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this
municipality in the business of making sales of service, who, as an incident to
making those sales of service, transfer groceries as an incident to a sale of
service.
      2.   The rate of this tax shall be the same rate identified in division
A. of this section, above. The imposition of this tax is in accordance with and
subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-24).
   C.   Illinois Department Of Revenue To Administer Both Taxes: The taxes
hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident
thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the
State of Illinois. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 4021, 3-24-2025)
ARTICLE B. SIMPLIFIED TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX
SECTION:
3-5B-1: Definitions
3-5B-2: Tax Imposed; Rate
3-5B-3: Exclusions
3-5B-4: Collection By Retailers
3-5B-5: Returns To Department
3-5B-6: Resales
3-5B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
AMOUNT PAID: The amount charged to the taxpayer's service address in the city
regardless of where such amount is billed or paid.
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois department of revenue.
GROSS CHARGE: The amount paid for the act or privilege of originating or
receiving telecommunications in the city and for all services and equipment
provided in connection therewith by a retailer, valued in money, whether paid
in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and property of every
kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the
cost of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor, or
service costs or any other expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the
amount thereof shall be included only as and when paid. "Gross charges" for
private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel termination
point within the city and charges for the portion of the interoffice channels
provided within the city. Charges for that portion of the interoffice channel
connecting two (2) or more channel termination points, one or more of which is
located within the jurisdictional boundary of the city, shall be determined by
the retailer by multiplying an amount equal to the total charge for the
interoffice channel by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of
channel termination points that are located within the jurisdictional boundary
