and general welfare and to restrict such sales to casual and/or occasional
occurrences only, in keeping with the character of the neighborhood where this
activity is carried on. The intent of this article is to eliminate perpetual,
prolonged, and extended garage and yard sales in the R-1, R-2, M-H, C-1, C-
2 and Industrial zones. Such sales, if continued indefinitely, tend to become
retail businesses in residential zones, create a nuisance and violate the
zoning regulations. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
4-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:
 
GOODS:   Any goods, warehouse merchandise or other personal property capable of being the object of a sale
         regulated hereunder.
PERSONS: Individuals, partnerships, family groups, voluntary associations and corporations
YARD,    A.   The sale or offering for sale of new, used or secondhand items of personal property at any
GARAGE,  one (1) residential premises at any one (1) time.
RUMMAGE  B.   Includes all sales in residential areas entitled “garage sale,” “yard sale,” “tag sale,”
AND      “porch sale,” “lawn sale,” “attic sale,” “basement sale,” “rummage sale,” “flea market sale” or
SIMILAR  any similar casual sale of tangible personal property.. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
SALE:
 
4-15-3: CONDUCT OF SALES:
   A.   No one (1) yard, garage, rummage or similar sale shall continue for
longer than three (3) consecutive days.
   B.   No continuous or back-to-back sales shall be permitted and a minimum of
fifteen (15) days shall pass between each individual yard, garage, rummage, or
similar sale.
   C.   No sale shall be conducted before 6:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m.
   D.   Any and all items that remain from the sale after the third day must be
removed or stored in an enclosed area within 24 hours after said sale.
   E.   All parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all
applicable laws and codes. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
4-15-4: SIGNS:
   A.   Only the following specified signs may be displayed in relation to a
pending Yard, garage, rummage or similar sale:
      1.   Two (2) signs permitted. Two signs of not more than four (4) square
feet each are permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where
the yard sale is being conducted.
      2.   Directional signs. Two (2) signs of not more than four (4) square
feet each are permitted, provided that the premises upon which the yard sale is
conducted is not on a major thoroughfare and written permission to erect said
signs is received from the property owners upon whose property such signs are
to be posted.
   B.   No sign or other form of advertisement, other than newspaper
publications, shall be exhibited for more than three (3) days prior to the day
such sale is to commence.
   C.   Signs must be removed at the close of the yard sale activities or by
the end of daylight, whichever first occurs.
   D.   Any sign placed on right of way will be removed. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
4-15-5: RESPONSIBILITIES OF TENANT AND/OR OWNER:
The owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted
shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order
and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such
individual shall permit any loud or boisterous conduct on said premises nor
permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the
area of such premises. All such individuals shall obey the reasonable orders of
any member of the Police, Fire, or Building and Code Departments of the City of
Marion in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. A police
officer, code officer, firefighter or any other official designated by the City
to make inspections shall have the right of entry to any premises showing
evidence of a yard sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection of this
Section. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
4-15-6: EXEMPTIONS:
This article shall not be applicable to:
   A.   Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   B.   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials.
   C.   Any person selling a single item of personal property which is
specifically named or described in an advertisement offering the item for sale.
   D.   Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication or other
communications media which publishes or broadcasts anything in good faith
without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character or without
knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been met.
   E.   Any public auction conducted by a licensed auctioneer. (Ord. 3737, 7-
26-2021)
4-15-7: PENALTY:
Anyone who violates this Section shall be subject to the penalties as stated in
Title 1, Chapter 4 of this Code (
1-4-1, et seq.). Each day that a violation continues may be deemed a separate
offense. (Ord. 3737, 7-26-2021)
CHAPTER 16
SPECIAL EVENTS
SECTION:
4-16-1: Definition
4-16-2: Special Event Permit Required; Procedures
4-16-3: General Requirements
 
4-16-4: Penalty
4-16-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
 
               A. Any outdoor event held on public property, private property,
               or a combination of public and private including, but not
               limited to, parades, festivals, fairs, athletic events,
               concerts, or other public meeting or an event deemed to
               significantly impact the city, which meet some or all of the
               following criteria:
               1. Closure of streets.
               2. Issuance of multiple permits or licenses, e.g. special event
               liquor license.
               3. Use of amplified sound/outdoor entertainment.
               4. Use of City-owned property.
               5. Use of City resources/ personnel.
SPECIAL EVENT: 6. Use of food trucks.
               B. A special event does not include:
               1. An event hosted by the City;
               2. Events hosted by other units of government, held wholly on
               that government's property or where the government is acting
               within its scope of authority;
               3. Events hosted by liquor licensees where such events are
               confined wholly within the Licensee's property and;
               4. Events which are confined wholly within the walls of the
               Marion Cultural and Civic Center or the Pavilion Events Center;
               or
               5. Any event held solely on private property and for which no
               city resources will be needed. (Ord. 4058, 8-25-2025)
 
 
4-16-2: SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT REQUIRED; PROCEDURES:
A.   A special event requires a special event permit approved by the City.
B.   An application for a special event permit must be filed with the City
Marketing Director not less than two weeks prior to the first day of the
special event. The Marketing Director may contact the event host for more
information before coordinating the review of the application with all affected
departments.
C.   The Mayor, or his designee, shall review all applications submitted and
will have final approval before any permit is issued. (Ord. 4058, 8-25-2025)
4-16-3: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Applicant shall comply with all applicable city ordinances, codes,
requirements and conditions;
B.   Applicant shall sign and agree to a hold harmless agreement, agreeing to
indemnify the city of Marion against any and all actions arising from, during
or as a result of the event;
C.   The Mayor, Fire Chief, or Police Chief, or their designee, shall have
authority to shut down an event, otherwise approved, if there becomes a risk to
life safety; and
D.   City personnel shall have the authority to perform a site inspection for
all events permitted under this Section.
E.   Temporary signs for said special event shall be permitted as provided for
in the sign ordinance of the city or as otherwise approved by the City Council.
(Ord. 4058, 8-25-2025)
4-16-4: PENALTY:
In addition to the penalties provided for in section
1-4-1 of this Code, any person violating this ordinance by sponsoring or
promoting a special event without a permit as required hereunder shall be fined
no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per occasion. Any person
sponsoring or promoting an unpermitted event that results in a call for service
for the City, including emergency and non-emergency requests, may result in a
fine of up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) plus restitution for the
actual cost for the City to respond. (Ord. 4058, 8-25-2025)
TITLE 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL HEALTH AND SANITATION PROVISIONS
SECTION:
5-1-1: Prohibited Sewage Disposal Systems
5-1-2: Combustible Materials Near Buildings
5-1-1: PROHIBITED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
No person, firm or corporation shall erect, place or maintain any privy or
water closet within the corporate limits of the city. (1977 Code § 8.20.010;
amd. 2013 Code)
5-1-2: COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS NEAR BUILDINGS:
No person, firm or corporation shall strew or leave any shavings, straw,
papers, excelsior or other like combustible material in and around or near any
building or other structure within the corporate limits of the city so as to
endanger or be likely to endanger the same in case of fire. (1977 Code §
8.24.010)
CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:
5-2-1: Definition
5-2-2: Specific Nuisances Enumerated; Nonexclusive
5-2-3: Notice To Abate
5-2-4: Abatement By City
5-2-5: Complaint By Citizen
5-2-6: Failure To Comply With Notice
5-2-7: Lien For Unpaid Expenses
5-2-8: Foreclosure Of Liens
5-2-9: Aggravated Public Nuisances
5-2-9-1: Definitions
5-2-9-2: Aggravated Public Nuisance Prohibited
5-2-9-3: Notice/Abatement Conference
5-2-9-4: Filing A Complaint
5-2-9-5: Judgment/Penalties
5-2-9-6: Enforcement/Lien
5-2-1: DEFINITION:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
NUISANCE: Any condition or use of premises or building exteriors which
constitutes a blighting factor, which is detrimental to the property of others,
which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other
property in the neighborhood in which the premises are located, which causes a
condition that taints the air, causes an offensive smell or renders the air
unwholesome or disagreeable to others, or which causes a condition that may
harbor mosquitoes, flies, insects, rodents, nuisance birds or other animal
pests that are offensive, injurious or dangerous to the health of individuals
or the public. Nuisance includes, but is not limited to, the keeping, the
depositing on, or scattering over the premises of any of the following:
   A.   Lumber, junk, yard waste, obnoxious growths, trash or debris;
   B.   Abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as furniture,
stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans or containers. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-2016)
5-2-2: SPECIFIC NUISANCES ENUMERATED; NONEXCLUSIVE:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and to be against the health, peace, and
comfort of the city, for any person, firm or corporation within the limits of
the city to permit the following; but the enumeration of the following
nuisances shall not be deemed to be exclusive or a limitation on the nuisances
defined above or as determined under other provisions of this code:
   A.   Filth: To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth
or noisome substance to be collected, deposited or to remain in any place, to
the prejudice of others.
   B.   Deposit Of Offensive Materials: To throw or deposit any offal or other
offensive matter, or the carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake,
pond, spring, well or common sewer, street or public highway.
   C.   Corruption Of Water: To corrupt or render unwholesome, or impure, the
water of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of
others.
   D.   Highway Encroachment: To obstruct or encroach upon public highways,
private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places, and ways to burying
places.
   E.   Noxious Odors: To erect, continue or use any building or other place
for the exercise of any trade, employment, or manufacture which, by occasioning
noxious exaltations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous
to the health of individuals, or of the public.
   F.   Litter On Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to allow trash,
paper, cardboard, wire, dirt, rock, stone, glass, brick, lumber, wood or litter
of material objects of any size or description to fall upon city streets from
any moving vehicle, or to be thrown from a moving vehicle, and to remain
thereon.
   G.   Accumulations Of Junk And Trash: To deposit, or pile up any rags, old
rope, paper, iron, brass, copper, tin, aluminum, ashes, garbage, refuse,
plastic, brush, litter, weeds, building material, appliances, slush, lead,
glass bottles or broken glass upon any lot, piece or parcel of land, or upon
any public alley, street or public way within the city.
   H.   Rodents: To cause or permit any condition or situation to exist that
shall attract, harbor or encourage the infestation of rodents.
   I.   Offensive Liquids: To keep any nauseous, foul or putrid liquid or
substance or any liquid or substance likely to become nauseous, foul, offensive
or putrid, nor permit any such liquid to be discharged, placed, thrown or to
flow from or out of any premises into or upon any adjacent premises or any
public street or alley, nor permit the same to be done by any person connected
with the premises.
   J.   Grass And/Or Leaf Blowing Regulated: No person, landscape or mowing
service shall blow or cause to blow leaves and/or grass clippings into the
streets, sidewalks, curb lines or ditches of the city of Marion.
   K.   Junk Storage Prohibited:
      1.   Definitions:
    ABANDONED AUTOMOBILE: A motor vehicle, whether on public or private
property, with no current valid state registration, a motor vehicle left
unattended on a highway or public property for a period in excess of seventy
two (72) hours, a motor vehicle not removed after its involvement in a
collision, an unattended motor vehicle located on a highway or public property
which has sustained acts of vandalism, a motor vehicle, wherever located, from
which, for a period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other
parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have
been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of
being driven under its own motor power. This shall not include registered
historic vehicles or a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business
engaged in ordinary service, storage or repair operations for a reasonable
period of time.
   JUNK, TRASH AND REFUSE: Includes any and all waste matter, whether reusable
or not, which is offensive to the public health, safety or to the aesthetics of
the neighborhood, which is not within a closed building and/or a privacy fence,
and is specifically intended to include, but not be limited to, wrecked,
disabled and/or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors, machinery and/or motor
vehicles of any kind, any parts thereof, old refrigerators, stoves, washers,
dryers and/or other appliances.
      2.   Storing Of Junk Declared A Nuisance: The storing of junk, trash and
refuse on private property within the city which is not within a closed
building and/or a privacy fence, where such storage is not authorized is
declared a nuisance.
      3.   Automobile On Private Property: The city may apply to the court
having jurisdiction for an order giving it the authority to have any automobile
parked on private property in violation of this chapter removed from such
property.
   L.   Generally: To commit any offense which is a nuisance according to the
common law of the land or made such by statute of the state. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-
2016)
5-2-3: NOTICE TO ABATE:
Whenever the code enforcement department or any other person so designated by
the mayor or city council finds that a nuisance exists, a written notice shall
be served on the party responsible for the nuisance and on the owner, occupant
or lessee on whose property the nuisance exists ordering that the nuisance be
abated within seven (7) days after such notice has been duly served. The notice
to abate shall contain:
   A.   A description of the nuisance;
   B.   The location of the nuisance;
   C.   A statement of what condition or state of affairs must be achieved in
order for the nuisances to be deemed abated;
   D.   The date by which abatement must be completed;
   E.   A statement indicating that if the nuisance is not abated by the date
prescribed, the city will abate the nuisance and assess the costs of abatement
and/or impose a fine; and
   F.   Service of the notice provided for herein may be effected by any of the
following methods:
      1.   Directed to the owner of record of the property on which said
nuisance occurs, as shown in the records of the recorder of deeds of Williamson
County, or to the occupant of said property, or to both.
      2.   By handing the same to the owner, occupant or lessee of the premises
or to any member of his or her household of the age of fifteen (15) years or
older found on the premises;
      3.   By mailing such notice to the last known residence address of the
owner, occupant or lessee; or
      4.   By posting the notice upon the premises. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-2016)
5-2-4: ABATEMENT BY CITY:
If the person ordered to abate a nuisance fails to do so, or if the nuisance
poses an emergency, the city may perform the required action to abate. Any city
official who is authorized to abate any "nuisance" as defined in this chapter
shall have authority to engage the necessary assistance and to incur the
necessary expenses therefor. The official who abates a nuisance shall keep an
accurate account of the expenses incurred. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-2016)
5-2-5: COMPLAINT BY CITIZEN:
Any citizen of the city who observes a violation of this chapter may report to
the code enforcement department the location and the name of the owner or
occupant of the property on which such nuisance is alleged, and the code
enforcement department shall make an investigation of such charge, and if such
nuisance exists, shall issue a notice to the owner or occupant of the property
as provided in this section.
Any person who by reason of another's violation of any provision of this
chapter suffers special damage to himself or herself different from the
suffered by other property owners throughout the city generally may bring an
action to enjoin or otherwise abate an existing violation. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-
2016)
5-2-6: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH NOTICE:
If the person notified to abate a nuisance shall neglect or refuse to comply
with the requirements of such notice by abating such nuisance within the time
specified, such person shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. The city
authorities shall not be required to issue another notice where the condition
or violation is at first abated, but later resumed and/or repeated.
Failure to abate a nuisance under provisions of this chapter after notice shall
be punished by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for each offense. Each day that the nuisance continues unabated after notice
shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the fine assessed
hereunder, the violator will be liable for the cost and expense incurred by the
city for abating the nuisance including reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 3350,
9-12-2016)
5-2-7: LIEN FOR UNPAID EXPENSES:
Expenses for the abatement of said nuisance under this chapter shall be a lien
upon the premises. Whenever a bill for such expenses remains unpaid for more
than sixty (60) days, after it has been rendered, the code enforcement
department may file with the recorder of deeds of Williamson County a statement
of lien claims. The statement shall obtain a legal description of the premises,
the expenses and costs incurred and the date the nuisance was abated, and the
notice that the city claims a lien for such account. Notice of such lien claim
shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address is known; provided,
however that failure of the city to record such lien claim or to mail such
notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect
the right to foreclose the lien for such charges as provided in the following
section. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-2016)
5-2-8: FORECLOSURE OF LIENS:
Property subject to a lien for unpaid expenses for the abatement of a nuisance
shall be sold for nonpayment of same and the proceeds of such sale shall be
applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as in the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be maintained in the
name of the city. The city attorney is authorized and directed to institute
such proceedings, in the name of the city and any court having jurisdiction
over such matter, against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid
sixty (60) days after it has been incurred. (Ord. 3350, 9-12-2016)
5-2-9: AGGRAVATED PUBLIC NUISANCES:
5-2-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
CANNABIS:     As defined in the Cannabis Control Act found at 720 ILCS 550/3.
COMMIT or     Means knowingly causing, allowing, aiding or concealing the fact of such act
COMMISSION:   or activities.
CONTROLLED    As defined in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act found at 720 ILCS 570/
SUBSTANCE:    102.
DELIVER or    Means the actual, constructive or attempted transfer of possession of a
DELIVERY:     controlled substance, cannabis, or methamphetamine, with or without
              consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship.
              Means a house, apartment building, mobile home, trailer, or other structures
DWELLING:     used or intended for use for human habitation, and includes common areas
              within the structure which houses more than one (1) dwelling unit.
              Means a person knows, or acts knowingly or with knowledge of:
              A.   The nature or attendant circumstances of his/her conduct, described by
              the section defining the offense, when he/she is consciously aware that his/
              her conduct is of such nature or that such circumstances exist. Knowledge of a
              material fact includes awareness of the substantial probability that such fact
KNOWLEDGE:    exists.
              B.   The result of his/her conduct, described by the section defining the
              offense, when he/she is consciously aware that such result is practically
              certain to be caused by his/her conduct.
              C.   Conduct performed knowingly or with knowledge is performed willfully,
              within the meaning of a section using the latter term, unless the section
              clearly requires another meaning.
              Has the same meaning as set forth in Section 720 ILCS 646/10 of the
MANUFACTURE:  Methamphetamine Control and Community Protection Act and Section 720 ILCS 570/
              102(z) of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act.
              Means a person is negligent, or acts negligently, when he/she fails to be
              aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk that circumstances exist or a
NEGLIGENCE:   result will follow, described by the section defining the offense; and such
              failure constitutes a substantial deviation from the standard of care which a
              reasonable person would exercise in the situation.
              Means any person who lives in or has possession or holds an occupancy interest
OCCUPANT:     in a dwelling unit, or any person residing or frequenting the premises of the
              dwelling with the actual or implied permission of an owner or lessee.
              Means any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or
              equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
OWNER:        state, county or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise
              having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any
              such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if
              ordered to take possession of real property by a court.
              Means a person is reckless or acts recklessly when he/she consciously
              disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that circumstances exist or
              that a result will follow, described by the section defining the offense; and
RECKLESSNESS: such disregard constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of care which a
              reasonable person would exercise in that situation. An act performed
              recklessly is performed wantonly, within the meaning of the section using the
              latter term, unless the section clearly requires another meaning. (Ord. 3766,
              1-10-2022)
 
5-2-9-2: AGGRAVATED PUBLIC NUISANCE PROHIBITED:
An "Aggravated Public Nuisance" is:
   A.   A dwelling where the owner(s) or occupant(s) of the dwelling conduct or
commit the following activities within a dwelling unit, on the premises of a
dwelling, or within one hundred feet (100') of the property line of the
premises of the dwelling of which the owner or occupant has control within a
three hundred sixty-five-day (365) period:
      1.   Two (2) or more forcible felonies as defined in 720 ILCS 5/2-8 of
the Illinois Criminal Code; or
      2.   Two (2) or more state or federal criminal offenses related to the
illegal sale, delivery, possession or manufacture of controlled substances,
cannabis or methamphetamine; or
      3.   Two (2) or more offenses involving a firearm or other deadly weapon
as defined in 720 ILCS 5/24, et. seq.; or
      4.   Three (3) or more violations of the Marion City Code Titles 5, 6, or
10 or a combination thereof issued by a Marion Code Officer that fail to be
abated or corrected within ten (10) days; or
      5.   Five (5) or more of any of the combination of the following:
         a.   Any of the offenses described in paragraphs 1. through 4. above
and any of the following offenses as defined in the Illinois Criminal Code:
            i.   Disorderly Conduct
            ii.   Battery, Excluding Domestic Battery
            iii.   Assault and Aggravated Assault
            iv.   Criminal Damage to Property
            v.   Mob Action
            vi.   Underage Possession or Consumption of Alcohol by Minors
   B.   VIOLATION: No owner of real property shall recklessly, knowingly, or
negligently allow or permit an aggravated public nuisance or allow or permit an
aggravated public nuisance to exist upon real property or part thereof,
including individual dwelling units, owned by that person. (Ord. 3766, 1-10-
2022)
5-2-9-3: NOTICE/ABATEMENT CONFERENCE:
   A.   The city shall provide the owner of the place at which the aggravated
public nuisance is located, or the agent of the owner, written notice of the
violation. The notice shall be served with process reasonably calculated to
give them actual notice, including, as appropriate, service by first class
mail, to the address shown in the property records of Williamson County or the
registered address as shown in the Secretary of State records, or by personal
service upon any owner or registered agent of the owner.
   B.   The notice shall specify the violation providing the dates, times, and
locations of the violations and attaching any relevant reports or citations.
   C.   The owner or owner's agent has fifteen (15) days from the mailing of
the notice to contact the City Attorney's Office to schedule a meeting to
discuss the facts constituting the aggravated public nuisance, specific actions
that can be taken and the possibility of entering into a written abatement
agreement. The abatement agreement may impose one or more of the following
conditions upon the owner:
      1.   Commencement of an eviction of identified individuals from the
dwelling in question and continued follow through in good faith.
      2.   Issuing and serving a ban or trespass notice upon any individual not
authorized to be present upon the property in question and filing a copy with
the Marion Police Department.
      3.   Utilization of written leases containing provisions requiring
eviction for criminal activity and repeated code violations committed upon or
within the leased dwellings or common areas.
      4.   The completion of improvements upon the property which have the
impact of mitigating crime, including, but not limited to, the erection of
fences, installation of working security cameras and devices and increased
lighting.
      5.   Any other reasonable condition or requirement designed to abate the
aggravated public nuisance. (Ord. 3766, 1-10-2022)
5-2-9-4: FILING A COMPLAINT:
   A.   The City Attorney may file a complaint alleging a violation of this
chapter under the following circumstances:
      1.   The owner or owner's agent does not contact the City Attorney's
Office to discuss abatement of the aggravated public nuisance.
      2.   The owner or owner's agent fails to sign an abatement agreement or
fails to comply with the terms of the abatement agreement.
      3.   The aggravated public nuisance continues to exist or has not been
abated after notice.
   B.   In any proceeding brought under this chapter, the court shall consider
at least the following in determining whether or not the defendant has
recklessly, knowingly, or negligently allowed or permitted an aggravated public
nuisance to exist:
      1.   Evidence of notice by the city or by any person to the defendant,
notifying the defendant of the existence of any of the activities set forth in
section
5-2-9-2 of this chapter;
      2.   Actions or lack of actions taken by the owner to mitigate the
criminal activity or the existence of nuisances upon and in the vicinity of the
property;
      3.   Actions or lack of actions taken by the owner to remove persons who
commit criminal offenses or nuisances from tenancy or occupancy or to prohibit
the entry of such persons onto the premises of the dwelling;
      4.   Whether the nuisance was repeated or continuous;
      5.   The gravity of the problem and danger posed to the public.
   C.   Proof of the commission of any of the offenses or existence of any of
the circumstances set forth in section
5-2-9-2 of this chapter shall be by a preponderance of the evidence.
   D.   The finding of or judgment of guilty in any court against an individual
for an offense enumerated in section
5-2-9-2 of this chapter shall be prima facie evidence of the commission
thereof. (Ord. 3766, 1-10-2022)
5-2-9-5: JUDGMENT/PENALTIES:
Any owner found to be in violation of this chapter can be ordered:
   A.   To pay fines of up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per day
that the nuisance existed beginning the first day the owner received knowledge
of the nuisance; and
   B.   To pay costs and fees of the filing of the nuisance abatement case; and
   C.   To immediately abate and correct the nuisance that gives rise to the
violation or take immediate action necessary to begin correction; and
   D.   To immediately complete improvements upon the property to help mitigate
nuisances and crime such as erecting fences, installation and use of operable
security cameras and devices, and increased lighting. (Ord. 3766, 1-10-2022)
5-2-9-6: ENFORCEMENT/LIEN:
   A.   Any fine, other sanction, or cost imposed remaining unpaid after the
exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial review or appeal are a debt
due and owing the City of Marion and may be collected with applicable law.
   B.   In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by a
municipality to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's
fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure,
after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer,
shall be a debt due and owing the municipality and may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
   C.   Upon being recorded in the Williamson County Clerk and Recorder's
Office, a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both,
of the defendant in the amount of any debt due and owing the municipality under
this section. The lien may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien
pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 3766, 1-10-
2022)
CHAPTER 3
WEEDS, GRASS AND VEGETATION
SECTION:
5-3-1: Height Restrictions; Unhealthy, Noxious Vegetation Prohibited
5-3-2: Exemptions
5-3-3: Notices To Abate
5-3-4: Issuance Of Citation
5-3-5: Abatement By City; Charges
5-3-6: Failure To Pay Charges
5-3-1: HEIGHT RESTRICTIONS; UNHEALTHY, NOXIOUS VEGETATION PROHIBITED:
Except as provided in section
5-3-2  of this chapter, no owner and no person in control of any lot, place or
area within the city, and no agent of such owner or person in control, shall
permit on such lot, place or area or upon any abutting area between the right
of way line/property line and street surface or pavement, any weeds or grass
over eight inches (8") in height, or deleterious, unhealthy growths or other
noxious matter that may be growing, lying, or located thereon. (Ord. 2206, 6-
30-2008; amd. Ord. 3909, - -2023)
5-3-2: EXEMPTIONS:
The following are generally exempted from the provisions of this chapter: Lands
zoned agriculture as designated and shown on the official zoning map of the
city unless used for nonagricultural purposes. For purpose of this section,
"agricultural use" shall be construed to mean vacant land or the production of
products such as field crops, livestock, fowl and other conventional
agricultural pursuits. Provided, however, that the portions of those lands
exempted by this section which are within forty feet (40') of the right of way
of a public street or alley maintained for traffic or within forty feet (40')
of the property line of adjacent lands used for nonagricultural or nonforestry
purposes (for example, church, school, store, factory, house, apartment
building, offices, etc.) shall not be exempted from the provisions of this
chapter (Ord. 2206, 6-30-2008; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3909, - -2023)
5-3-3: NOTICES TO ABATE:
   A.   Annual Public Notice: The city clerk, or his designee, annually, at or
near the commencement of the growth season, shall notify, by publication in a
newspaper of general circulation within the city, all owners or persons in
control of real estate to cut, destroy, or remove any such weeds, grass, other
vegetation, or matter found growing, lying or located on such properties and
areas regulated by section
5-3-1  of this chapter.
   B.   Individual Notice: The city code enforcement officer, after determining
that a particular lot or parcel of real estate is in violation of section
5-3-1  of this chapter, shall post a notice on such lot or parcel of real
estate in substantially the following form:
   NOTICE
   To the owner or person in control of the real estate located at
                     in the City of Marion, Illinois
   Weeds, grass or other vegetation of a height of eight inches (8") or more
exist on such real estate in violation of Section
5-3-1 of the City Code.
   Unless such weeds, grass, or other vegetation is cut to permissible height,
or less, or is otherwise removed within seven (7) days after the posting of
this notice the owner or person in control may be fined not more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation exists will constitute
a separate offense.
   Posted:
      CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER
      CITY OF MARION, ILLINOIS
      TELEPHONE: 993-2422
   (Ord. 2206, 6-30-2008; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3909, - -2023)
5-3-4: ISSUANCE OF CITATION:
If there is a violation of section
5-3-1 of this chapter regarding weeds, grass or other vegetation, the code
enforcement officer may issue to the owner or person in control of the real
estate upon which there is such a violation a ticket and file said ticket for
prosecution in the office of the circuit court of the county. (Ord. 2206, 6-30-
2008; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3909, - -2023)
5-3-5: ABATEMENT BY CITY; CHARGES:
   A.   Upon the failure of the owner or person in control of a lot or parcel
of real estate in violation of section 5-3-1 of this chapter, the code
enforcement officer or his designee, after publication of notice as provided in
subsection 5-3-3A of this chapter and posting of notice as provided in
subsection
5-3-3B of this chapter, may enter upon such real estate to cut and remove such
weeds, grass or other vegetation.
   B.   The charge for cutting and removing weeds, grass or other vegetation
shall be as follows and presented by the code enforcement officer:
      $250.00 for each parcel
      Necessary brush hogging may require additional fee. (Ord. 2206, 6-30-
2008; Ord. 3909, - -2023)
5-3-6: FAILURE TO PAY CHARGES:
   A.   Suit: Should the person so charged fail to pay the amount charged
within fourteen (14) days, the city is authorized to file suit against such
person for collection of the same in the circuit court of the county.
   B.   Lien: The Building and Code Services Department is authorized to file a
lien against the real estate from which the city cut or removed weeds, grass or
other vegetation, the amount of the lien to include, but is not limited to,
administrative and legal fees, filing and service of process fees and the
appropriate charges designated in subsection
5-3-5B of this chapter. (Ord. 2206, 6-30-2008; Ord. 3909, - -2023)
CHAPTER 4
GARBAGE AND DEBRIS
SECTION:
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: Accumulation Of Garbage And Debris Prohibited
5-4-3: Determination Of Offensive Condition
5-4-4: Notice Of Violation; Time For Abatement
5-4-5: Lien For City Abatement Costs
5-4-6: Penalty
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
DEBRIS: Any material of whatsoever nature considered to be junk, refuse or
without any reasonable expectation of beneficial use in the usual course of
human endeavor including, but not limited to, dilapidated or nonoperable
fixtures or appliances, cans, paper, bottles, tools, lawn maintenance
equipment, children's toys and recreation appliances, offal or any material
that may pose a threat of fire.
GARBAGE: Refuse produced from organic material including, but not limited to,
fruits and vegetables. (Ord. 2043, 10-3-2005)
5-4-2: ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE AND DEBRIS PROHIBITED:
In order to promote health and suppress disease, it is determined to be
necessary and expedient to prohibit the accumulation and maintenance of
garbage, other material that may be offensive to the senses of a reasonable
person, and debris upon any real estate in the city, and such accumulation and
maintenance is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 2043, 10-3-2005)
5-4-3: DETERMINATION OF OFFENSIVE CONDITION:
The city code enforcement officer, the police chief or the fire chief may
determine that a condition exists in violation of this chapter. A written
report of such determination shall be filed with the city clerk. (Ord. 2043,
10-3-2005; amd. Ord. 2207, 6-30-2008; 2013 Code)
5-4-4: NOTICE OF VIOLATION; TIME FOR ABATEMENT:
   A.   Issuance Of Notice; Contents: The city clerk shall prepare a written
notice in substantially the following form to be served on the owner or person
in control of such real estate by personal service or certified mail:
TO:                               
As the owner or person in control of the real estate located at
                               in the City of Marion, Illinois.
You are notified it has been determined there is an accumulation of garbage or
debris or both upon the above specified real estate in violation of Title 5,
Chapter 4 of the City Code.
Such garbage or debris must be removed within seven (7) days after receipt of
this notice.
Violation of the provisions of Title 5, Chapter 4 of the City Code may subject
you to a fine not to exceed Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day a
violation continues is a separate offense.
(Ord. 2207, 6-30-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Time For Compliance: The owner or occupant of the real estate
determined to have an existing condition in violation of this chapter shall be
advised to terminate such condition seven (7) days after receipt of notice to
do so. (Ord. 2043, 10-3-2005)
5-4-5: LIEN FOR CITY ABATEMENT COSTS:
   A.   Filing Lien: If, within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense of
removal of garbage and debris is incurred, the city or the person performing
the service by the city's authority, in his or its own name, files a notice of
lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds, such costs and expense
shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens
and encumbrances, except tax liens.
   B.   Notice Of Lien: The notice of lien provided in this section shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out a description of the real estate
sufficient for identification thereof, the amount of money representing the
costs and expenses incurred, and the date when such costs and expenses were
incurred. (Ord. 2043, 10-3-2005)
5-4-6: PENALTY:
A violation of this chapter that continues more than seven (7) days after
service of the aforementioned notice may subject the owner or occupant of the
real estate to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and each day the violation continues is a separate offense.
(Ord. 2043, 10-3-2005; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 5
LITTER CONTROL
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definitions
5-5-2: Littering Prohibited
5-5-3: Penalty
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
LITTER: Any discarded, used or unconsumed substances or waste. "Litter" may
include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish,
grass clippings, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper
containers, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, and nauseous or offensive
matter of any kind, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature,
which has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, company, corporation or other legal
entity. (Ord. 1844, 4-15-2002)
5-5-2: LITTERING PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, or leave, or cause
or permit the dumping, depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of
litter upon any city street or street right of way in the city.
   B.   No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard or otherwise
dispose of litter from any motor vehicle upon any city street or street right
of way in the city. (Ord. 1844, 4-15-2002)
5-5-3: PENALTY:
Persons who violate any provision of section
5-5-2 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1844, 4-15-2002; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 6
BURNING RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
5-6-1: Definition
5-6-2: Burning Prohibitions And Restrictions
5-6-3: Recreational Fires
5-6-4: Penalty
5-6-1: DEFINITION:
The word "person", for the purposes of this chapter, includes, but is not
limited to, any individual, group, firm or company as well as any agent of any
individual, group, firm or company. (1977 Code § 8.12.010)
5-6-2: BURNING PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Natural yard waste (leaves, lawn clippings, small limbs) may be burned
within the corporate limits of the city during daylight hours between nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.:
      1.   Only upon the premises on which such yard waste is generated or has
fallen.
      2.   When atmospheric conditions will readily dissipate contaminants.
      3.   If such burning does not create a visibility hazard on roadways,
railroads, or airfields.
   B.   No burning shall be left unattended.
   C.   No burning shall occur in or upon a city street.
   D.   No burning shall occur within twenty feet (20') of a residence or
building. (Ord. 2250, 5-11-2009)
   E.   No domicile waste garbage, trash or refuse, or agricultural waste shall
be burned. (Ord. 2250, 5-11-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
   F.   No building materials shall be burned at any time including sawed
lumber.
   G.   No one shall burn at any time the wind velocity, to a prudent person,
is such as to cause the burning to be a hazard to life or property. A violation
of this subsection shall be presumed if, but not limited to, burning leaves are
blown from the immediate area in which they are being burned or atmospheric
conditions allow contaminants to be blown onto the property of another causing
both damage to real property and creating a nuisance to another person(s).
(Ord. 2250, 5-11-2009)
5-6-3: RECREATIONAL FIRES:
   A.   Recreational fires shall consist of the burning of fuels for a
legitimate campfire, recreational and cooking purposes, or in a domestic
fireplace in areas where such burning is consistent with other laws; provided,
that no garbage, trash or refuse shall be burned in such case. (Ord. 2250, 5-
11-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Fires shall occur in a cleared, open area, and the area shall be no
less than a twenty foot (20') radius.
   C.   Fires shall be in an appliance designed for such burning, a burn pit,
or an area surrounded by noncombustible material.
   D.   No fires shall be allowed when winds are such as to cause a hazard to
life or property. (Ord. 2250, 5-11-2009)
5-6-4: PENALTY:
Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 7
UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS
SECTION:
5-7-1: Definition
5-7-2: Regulations
5-7-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the word "person" includes, but is not limited
to, an individual, group of individuals, partnership, firm or corporation as
well as any agent thereof. (Ord. 1072, 5-13-1985)
5-7-2: REGULATIONS:
No person shall bury, place or maintain any underground storage tanks or piping
within the corporate limits of the city other than as follows:
   A.   Hydrotesting Tanks:
      1.   Existing Tanks: All existing underground storage tanks and piping
which have been buried for more than five (5) years at the effective date
hereof shall be hydrotested within one year from said effective date. All
underground storage tanks and piping shall be hydrotested thereafter once every
three (3) years.
      2.   New Tanks: All new underground storage tanks and piping shall be
hydrotested before being covered and placed in service.
      3.   Results: Results of hydrotesting shall be sent to the city fire
department.
      4.   Certified Tester: Persons testing shall be certified within last two
(2) years.
   B.   Emptying Tanks: No underground storage tanks or piping shall be emptied
unless the fill line, gauge opening, and pump connection are secured against
tampering. All vent lines shall remain open, and the tanks and piping shall be
pumped completely dry and filled completely with water.
   C.   Abandoned Tanks: All underground storage tanks and piping out of
service for more than ninety (90) days shall be removed with all vent lines,
piping, valves, and fittings dismantled and purged and all contaminated ground
soil removed. The tank and all connecting lines shall be completely cleaned of
all material including any "heel" removed. No burning of surface contamination
shall be permitted. In lieu of removal, upon ten (10) days' notice to the city
fire department, the entire tank shall be exposed and examined for
contamination, split end to end, and filled completely with sand. The city fire
department may request the addition of "no flash". All remaining underground
piping shall be capped. Suction, inlet, gauge and vent lines shall be
disconnected and removed. (Ord. 1072, 5-13-1985; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 8
VEHICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS AND PRIVATE PROPERTY
ARTICLE A. ABANDONED, DERELICT VEHICLES
SECTION:
5-8A-1: Public Policy
5-8A-2: Definitions
5-8A-3: Derelict Vehicles
5-8A-4: Abandoned Vehicles
5-8A-5: Notice To Police Of Abandoned Or Derelict Vehicle; Removal
5-8A-6: Records Searches To Identify Owner; Notices
5-8A-7: Review Of Determination Of Abandoned Or Derelict Vehicle
5-8A-8: Towing And Impounding Of Vehicles; Reclamation And Disposal
5-8A-9: Emergency Tows
5-8A-10: Nonliability Of Police And Towing Service
5-8A-11: Fee For Removal Of Contaminants
5-8A-12: Provisions Nonexclusive
5-8A-1: PUBLIC POLICY:
The city council finds that abandoned and derelict vehicles constitute a safety
hazard and a public nuisance; are detrimental to the health, safety and welfare
of the general public by harboring disease, providing breeding places for
vermin, inviting plundering, creating fire hazards, and presenting physical
dangers to children and others; produce scenic blights which degrade the
environment and adversely affect land values and the proper maintenance and
continuing development of the city; represent a resource out of place and an
energy loss to the economy; and require local governmental attention in order
to assure the expeditious removal of these abandoned and derelict vehicles. The
city council declares, therefore, that it is the policy of the city to prohibit
the abandonment of vehicles and the retention of derelicts and to enforce such
prohibition by law. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
herein ascribed, except as the context may otherwise require:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle or other vehicle, boat, trailer, or mobile
home which is in a state of disrepair, partially dismantled, wrecked, or
otherwise inoperable so as to render the vehicle incapable of being driven or
used in its condition; or any motor vehicle or other vehicle, boat, trailer, or
mobile home which has not been moved or used for ten (10) consecutive days or
more and is apparently deserted. The term "abandoned vehicle" shall not be
construed to include, for the purposes of this article, any such vehicle, boat,
trailer or mobile home which is kept in an enclosed building; on the premises
of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary
to the operation of such business enterprise; or in an appropriate storage
place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city or
other party.
DERELICT VEHICLE:
   A.   Any inoperable, currently unregistered, discarded motor vehicle,
regardless of title, having lost its character as a substantial property or
left unattended without justification contrary to the public policy expressed
in this article. "Inoperable" means any motor vehicle from which, for a period
of ten (10) days, the engine, wheels, or other parts have been removed, or on
which the engine, wheels, or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own motor power.
   B.   This definition shall not include a motor vehicle which has been
rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in
order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. Nothing in this
definition shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when
not in use, to historic vehicles over twenty five (25) years of age or to a
motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in wrecking or
junking of motor vehicles.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a street or highway, whether subject to or exempt
from registration; except, however, bicycles, snowmobiles and devices used
exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. The term shall include, for the
purposes hereof, any motor vehicle or other vehicle, boat, trailer, or mobile
home. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008)
5-8A-3: DERELICT VEHICLES:
   A.   Nuisance Declared; Penalty; Impoundment: The parking of all derelict
motor vehicles, or parts thereof, whether on public or private property and in
the view of the general public, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any person
who fails to obey a notice received from the city which states that he is to
dispose of any derelict motor vehicle under his control shall commit a nuisance
and may be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, or a police officer may authorize that the vehicle, or part
thereof, shall be removed after seven (7) days from the issuance of the
municipal notice. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008; 2013 Code)
   B.   Storage Within Enclosed Buildings: Automotive vehicles, trucks or
trailers of any kind or type without current license shall not be parked or
stored on any property other than in completely closed buildings or carports.
(Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-4: ABANDONED VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any motor vehicle or other vehicle,
boat, trailer, or mobile home, or any part thereof, to be abandoned on private
or public property, including, without limitation, any street within the city,
or otherwise be considered an abandoned or derelict vehicle. Any such abandoned
or derelict vehicle is hereby declared a nuisance whether on private or public
property. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-5: NOTICE TO POLICE OF ABANDONED OR DERELICT VEHICLE; REMOVAL:
   A.   When any abandoned or derelict vehicle comes into the temporary
possession or custody of any person in the city, not the owner of such vehicle,
such person shall immediately notify the police department when the vehicle is
within the corporate limits of the city.
   B.   Upon receipt of such notification, the chief of police, or his
designated representative, shall authorize a towing service to remove and take
possession of the abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other
vehicle. The towing service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents
and maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or
any other person legally entitled to possession thereof.
   C.   When a vehicle removal from either public or private property is
authorized by the police department, the owner of the vehicle will be
responsible for all towing costs. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-6: RECORDS SEARCHES TO IDENTIFY OWNER; NOTICES:
   A.   Identifying And Tracing Vehicle Ownership: Upon receiving notification
of or otherwise discovering an abandoned or derelict vehicle, the police
department shall, if it does not already know the identification of the
registered owner or other person legally entitled thereto, cause the vehicle
and license registration records of the secretary of state of the state of
Illinois, or a foreign state if applicable, to be searched utilizing the
vehicle identification number and license plate year and number displayed on
the vehicle, if any. The owner of such vehicle, as disclosed from the search,
shall be the owner of such vehicle for the purposes of the disposition of such
vehicle. The city police department shall further cause the motor vehicle files
of the Illinois state police to be searched by a directed communication to the
Illinois state police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the
Illinois state police files are searched with negative results, the information
contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files shall be
searched in accordance with state law by the Illinois state police. When the
registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of a
vehicle cannot be identified from the registration files of the state of
Illinois or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable, the
city police department shall so notify the Illinois state police for the
purpose of identifying the vehicle owner or other person legally entitled to
the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the Illinois state
police shall be immediately forwarded to the city police department.
   B.   Notice To Owner:
      1.   When the identity of the owner or other person legally entitled to
an abandoned or derelict vehicle is known or has been determined in accordance
with subsection A of this section, the chief of police, or his designee, shall
cause such owner or other person to be given notice that such vehicle has been
determined to be an abandoned or derelict vehicle in violation of this article
and that unless such vehicle is removed within seven (7) days from the date
such notice is mailed, postage prepaid, by certified mail, the vehicle will be
towed and impounded in accordance herewith, and the owner will be charged with
having violated this article. The chief of police, or his designee, may cause,
but is not required, to personally serve such notice on such owner or other
person, and need not establish whether such notice is actually received if
mailed. In those instances where the certified notification specified herein
has been returned by the postal authorities to the city police department due
to the addressee having moved, being unknown at the address obtained from the
registration records of the state of Illinois, or having refused delivery, the
sending of a second certified notice is not required. A copy of such notice
shall also be served upon any lienholder if the same has been disclosed by the
title search required herein. The notice required by this subsection B1 may be
in substantially the following form: (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. 2013 Code)
      CITY OF MARION
      1102 Tower Square Plaza
      Marion, Illinois 62959
      (618)993-2422 – Fax (618)997-2028
                               
      Code Enforcement Officer
TO:    
RE: Abandoned/Derelict Vehicles, Marion City Code Title 5, Chapter 8, Article A
DATE:    
This letter will serve notice to you that you are in possession of a "derelict
or abandoned vehicle." The enclosed notice containing full details requires
your response within seven (7) days from the date of this letter.
As set forth in City Code Section
5-8A-1: Public Policy:
The city council finds that abandoned and derelict vehicles constitute a safety
hazard and a public nuisance; are detrimental to the health, safety and welfare
of the general public by harboring disease, providing breeding places for
vermin, inviting plundering, creating fire hazards, and presenting physical
dangers to children and others; produces scenic blights which degrade the
environment and adversely affect land values and the proper maintenance and
continuing development of the city; represent a resource out of place and an
energy loss to the economy; and require local governmental attention in order
to assure the expeditious removal of these abandoned and derelict vehicles.
The Marion City Council declares, therefore, that it is the policy of the City
to prohibit the abandonment of vehicles and the retention of derelicts and to
enforce such prohibition by law.
I have also included a list of useful information that will assist you in
disposing of the vehicle. A full copy of Title 5, Chapter 8 (Including Articles
A, B and C) of the City Code will be available to you upon request at the cost
of $3.00.
If you have any questions or require assistance, please feel free to contact me
at (618)993-2422.
      Sincerely yours,
                                  
      Code Enforcement Officer
      Enclosures
   (Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   When the identity of the owner or other person legally entitled to
an abandoned or derelict vehicle is not known and has been determined in
accordance with the provisions hereof, and in addition to the notice required
in subsection B1 of this section, when the identity of the owner or other
person legally entitled to a vehicle is known, the chief of police, or his
designee, shall cause a prominent notice to be placed on the abandoned motor
vehicle stating that the vehicle has been determined to be abandoned in
accordance with the abandoned or derelict vehicle regulations of the city of
Marion and that it will be towed and impounded unless removed within seven (7)
days from the date the notice was posted. The date the notice is posted shall
be endorsed on the notice, along with the name of the officer posting such
notice, and the telephone number of the city police department at which
information may be obtained relative to the notice. The chief of police, or his
designee, shall cause the owner or other party in possession of private
property on which the vehicle is located to be informed that the vehicle will
be towed and impounded after seven (7) days, unless such vehicle is located on
private property of the owner of such vehicle or such private property owner
notified the city police department of such abandoned or derelict vehicle. Such
private property owner shall have all rights of review under this article if
such private property owner is a person legally entitled to such vehicle.
Notice to the owner or party in possession is informational only and not
jurisdictional. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008; 2013 Code)
5-8A-7: REVIEW OF DETERMINATION OF ABANDONED OR DERELICT VEHICLE:
When a vehicle has been determined to be an abandoned or derelict vehicle
within the meaning of this article, the owner thereof or other person legally
entitled thereto shall have the right to have such determination reviewed in
accordance with this section.
   A.   Chief Of Police: Any owner of or other person legally entitled to a
vehicle determined to be an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of
this article may, within seven (7) days of the notification required under
subsection 5-8A-6B of this article is mailed or personally delivered, as the
case may be, file a written request with the chief of police that he review
such determination, stating the reason or reasons why such vehicle is not an
abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this article. Within seven
(7) days of such written request, the chief of police shall review such
determination, giving the owner or other person an opportunity to personally be
heard and present whatever information as such owner or other person considers
pertinent. After reviewing such determination, the chief of police shall render
a written decision thereon which shall be promptly mailed, postage prepaid, by
certified mail, to such owner or other person, or delivered personally as
stated heretofore.
   B.   Mayor: If the owner of or other person legally entitled to such vehicle
does not agree with the decision of the chief of police after his review, such
owner or other person may, within ten (10) days after the decision of the chief
of police is mailed to such owner or other person, file a written request with
the mayor that the mayor review the original determination and the decision of
the chief of police stating the reason or reasons why such vehicle is not an
abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this article. Within seven
(7) days of such written request, the mayor shall schedule and conduct a
hearing to review such determination and such decision. At such hearing, the
mayor shall consider pertinent information presented by the city police
department and such owner or other person. The mayor may also personally
inspect such vehicle. The parties, personally or through counsel, shall also
have the right to cross examine each other's witnesses. After reviewing such
determination and such decision, the mayor shall render a written decision
thereon which shall be promptly mailed, postage prepaid, by certified mail, to
such owner or other person, or delivered personally as stated heretofore. If
such owner or such other person has not been charged with violating this
article, the review of the mayor shall be the final determination, and such
vehicle may then be towed and impounded if found to be an abandoned vehicle. If
such owner or such other person has been charged with violating this article,
then the right of judicial determination shall apply as hereinafter provided.
   C.   Judicial Determination: If the owner of or other person legally
entitled to a vehicle determined to be an abandoned or derelict vehicle within
the meaning of this article does not agree with the decision of the mayor, and
such owner or such other person has been charged with violating this article,
such owner or such person may, within seven (7) days after the decision of the
mayor is mailed to such owner or such other person, file a request with the
mayor that the vehicle not be towed or impounded pending the disposition of
such charge. If such request is filed, such vehicle shall not be towed and
impounded until such charge has been disposed of. After such charge is disposed
of, finding such owner or other person guilty, such vehicle shall then be towed
and impounded unless such nuisance has then been abated.
   D.   Stay Of Towing And Impounding: Pending any review of a determination
that a vehicle is an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the meaning of this
article, any such vehicle shall not be towed or impounded except as is
permitted for emergency tows. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008;
2013 Code)
5-8A-8: TOWING AND IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES; RECLAMATION AND DISPOSAL:
   A.   Towing And Impoundment; Records Kept: Subject to review of any
determination pursuant hereto that a vehicle is an abandoned or derelict
vehicle with the meaning of this article, such abandoned and derelict vehicle
may be towed and impounded after a waiting period of ten (10) days or more from
the date the notification required pursuant to section
5-8A-6 of this article has been mailed or delivered, as the case may be. The
chief of police, or his designee, shall authorize a towing service to remove
and take possession of the abandoned vehicle. The towing service shall safely
keep the towed vehicle and its contents and maintain a record of the tow until
the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally entitled to
possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this article.
When any vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the city police department
shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, year
of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body
style, vehicle identification number, and license plate year and number
displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also indicate the date and hour of
tow, the location towed from, the location towed to, the reason for towing, and
the name of the officer authorizing the tow. A record search of the vehicle
shall also be made. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2182, 1-28-2008)
   B.   Reclaiming Vehicles: At any time before a vehicle is sold at public
sale or disposed of as provided in this article, the owner or other person
legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the
city police department proof of ownership or proof of the right of possession
of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner thereof or other
person entitled thereto until and unless such owner or such person has paid all
towing and storage fees on account of such vehicle.
   C.   Disposal Of Unclaimed Vehicles: Abandoned or derelict vehicles which
have been towed or impounded shall be disposed of in accordance with this
subsection.
      1.   Disposal With Notice:
         a.   Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle, seven (7) years of age
or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered owner or other person legally
entitled to its possession for a period of thirty (30) days after notice has
been given by mail or delivered as provided in subsection 5-8A-6B of this
article, the city police department shall cause such vehicle to be sold at
public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale
shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the
sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10)
days prior to the sale, the city police department or the towing service where
the vehicle is impounded shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale
to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or other person known by
the city police department or the towing service to be legally entitled to the
possession of such vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of
the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled
person to reclaim the vehicle.
         b.   Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle more than seven (7)
years of age is towed or impounded, it may be sold as provided above or
disposed of as junk only at the discretion of the chief of police, or his
designee.
         c.   A vehicle classified as an antique (25 years of age or older) may
also be sold to any person desiring to restore same.
      2.   Disposal Without Notice:
         a.   When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally
entitled to the possession of an abandoned or derelict vehicle seven (7) years
of age or newer cannot be determined in accordance with section
5-8A-6 of this article, the vehicle may be sold as provided in subsection C1 of
this section, but without notice of the time and place of the sale being mailed
to the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of
the vehicle.
         b.   Whenever an abandoned or derelict vehicle is more than seven (7)
years of age and is towed and impounded, it may be sold as provided in
subsection C1 of this section or disposed of as junk only at the discretion of
the chief of police, or his designee.
      3.   Proceeds Of Sale: When a vehicle located within the city is
authorized to be towed, impounded and disposed of as set forth in this article,
the proceeds of the public sale or other disposition after the deduction of
towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the city treasury.
      4.   Police Reports: When a vehicle in the custody of the city police
department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled
person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as
provided in this article, a report of the transaction shall be maintained by
the city police department for a period of one year from the date of sale or
disposal. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-9: EMERGENCY TOWS:
Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, when a vehicle is
creating a traffic hazard because of its position in relation to a highway, its
physical appearance is causing the impeding of traffic, or it otherwise
presents a danger to the public health and safety on public or private
property, the chief of police, or his designee, may authorize and direct the
immediate towing and impounding of such vehicle without notice to the owner
thereof or other person legally entitled thereto. Immediately thereafter, the
owner or other person legally entitled shall be identified and notified in
accordance with this article. The determination may also be reviewed and the
vehicle disposed of in accordance with this article; provided, that if it is
concluded that such vehicle is not an abandoned or derelict vehicle within the
meaning of this article, such vehicle shall be released to the owner thereof or
other person legally entitled thereto upon payment of any charges incurred for
towing. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. 2013 Code)
5-8A-10: NONLIABILITY OF POLICE AND TOWING SERVICE:
Any police officer or towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner, or his legal representative, or any other
person legally entitled to the possession of a vehicle when the vehicle was
processed and sold or disposed of as provided in this article. All necessary
parties shall have the full right and authority to enter upon private property
for the enforcement of this article when any vehicle is in the view of the
general public. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8A-11: FEE FOR REMOVAL OF CONTAMINANTS:
Anyone in the business of receiving and storing abandoned or derelict motor
vehicles who is required by government regulations to remove from such vehicles
mercury or other contaminants may impose a service charge of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) to cover the costs of complying with such regulations. The
city is not obligated for any cost incurred in such removal. (Ord. 3041, 2-27-
2012)
5-8A-12: PROVISIONS NONEXCLUSIVE:
The provisions of this article shall be considered in addition to any
procedures established otherwise by law or ordinance for the removal and
disposition of abandoned or derelict vehicles. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
ARTICLE B. VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS
SECTION:
5-8B-1: Multiple Vehicles For Sale
5-8B-2: Enclosure Of Certain Vehicles
5-8B-3: Dismantling Vehicles Prohibited
5-8B-4: Parking Regulations
5-8B-5: Application Of Provisions
5-8B-1: MULTIPLE VEHICLES FOR SALE:
The offering of two (2) or more motor vehicles for sale at the same time on
private property located within a residentially zoned area is prohibited. At no
time and under no circumstances is the offering for sale of a derelict vehicle
or the sale of vehicle parts permitted in open areas on private property upon
which they are situated unless licensed by the city to permit such sale. For
the purpose of this section, a "For Sale" sign posted upon or adjacent to a
motor vehicle constitutes an offering for sale and is prohibited unless
specifically allowed herein. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8B-2: ENCLOSURE OF CERTAIN VEHICLES:
Unless otherwise provided herein, all unregistered, inoperable or derelict
motor vehicles shall be kept in a garage in a residential district. (Ord. 1759,
3-27-2000)
5-8B-3: DISMANTLING VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
Unless otherwise provided herein, no motor vehicle which is in a state of major
disassembly or disrepair or which is being stripped or dismantled shall be
permitted on any property located within a residential or a nonresidential
district unless the property is licensed for such use. The major repair or
demolition of motor vehicles shall not be permitted in residential areas. (Ord.
1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8B-4: PARKING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Generally: All vehicles parked in a residential district shall be
parked on a street, a clearly delineated driveway or within a garage. At no
time shall a motor vehicle be parked, stored or in any manner placed on the
front, side or rear yards or otherwise allowed to create a nuisance to
adjoining property owners by placing the vehicle in areas other than herein
provided.
   B.   Commercial Vehicles:
      1.   No person shall park, store or house more than one commercial
vehicle in a residential district.
      2.   The commercial vehicle parked, stored or housed within a residential
district must be owned by or assigned to the owner of the premises where the
vehicle is situated and must be located on the owner's lot in the residential
district.
      3.   The vehicle must not exceed seven feet (7') in height and shall not
be a school bus, tractor, trailer, dump truck, front loader, crane, tow truck
or similar vehicle.
      4.   The commercial vehicle shall be parked to the side or rear of a
building so as to be screened from view of the public right of way as much as
possible.
      5.   For the purpose of this subsection, a commercial vehicle is a
vehicle having been issued a B or a D license plate by the secretary of state.
All other commercial vehicles having greater than a D license plate shall not
be parked, stored, or housed within a residential district. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-
2000)
5-8B-5: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Recreational Vehicles: The provisions of this article shall not be
construed to amend or alter any provisions contained in other ordinances
regulating the parking and/or storing of recreational vehicles.
   B.   Trailers And Towable Vehicles: All provisions of this article shall
apply to trailers and towable vehicles. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
ARTICLE C. VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES AND REMEDIES
SECTION:
5-8C-1: Violations
5-8C-2: Penalty
5-8C-3: Noncompliance With Order
5-8C-1: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, alter, extend, repair,
remove, demolish, use or occupy any structure or equipment regulated by this
chapter when such conduct is contrary to or in conflict with or in violation of
any provisions stated herein. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
5-8C-2: PENALTY:
Any person, upon conviction of violating any provisions of this chapter, shall
be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. Any city police officer is authorized to
issue a citation for each day that a violation continues after due notice has
been served, and each citation shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000; amd. 2013 Code)
5-8C-3: NONCOMPLIANCE WITH ORDER:
In case there is not prompt compliance with any violation order, the chief of
police may request the city council to direct the city attorney to institute an
appropriate action or proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction to
collect the penalties provided in section
5-8C-2 of this article. (Ord. 1759, 3-27-2000)
CHAPTER 9
HAZARDOUS OPENINGS AND STRUCTURES
SECTION:
5-9-1: Definition
5-9-2: Prohibitions
5-9-3: Penalty
5-9-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the word "person" includes, but is not limited
to, any individual, group of individuals, partnership, firm or corporation.
(1977 Code § 8.16.010)
5-9-2: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   No person shall cause or allow to remain upon any lot or tract of real
estate within the city any open pit, well, basement or other similar opening,
nor shall any person cause or allow to remain upon any lot or tract of real
estate any building or other structure which has been partially or
substantially destroyed by fire or otherwise and is either uninhabited or
uninhabitable unless it is sealed in such a manner or kept in such condition as
to prevent it from being or becoming hazardous to the public health, safety or
welfare. (1977 Code § 8.16.020)
   B.   No person, firm or corporation shall keep or leave open, or permit or
allow to remain open without suitable safeguards therefor, any cellar door, or
well, or cistern, or grating of any vault, or other opening into any pit, hole,
or subterranean chamber, upon any public street, alley or sidewalk within the
corporate limits of the city. (1977 Code § 8.16.030)
5-9-3: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 10
CLEANUP OF METHAMPHETAMINE LABS
SECTION:
5-10-1: Purposes
5-10-2: Definitions
5-10-3: Notice To Other Authorities
5-10-4: Nuisance Declared
5-10-5: Occupancy Prohibited
5-10-6: Abatement Procedures
5-10-7: Authority To Modify Or Remove Nuisance Declaration
5-10-8: Penalty
5-10-1: PURPOSES:
The mayor and city council finds and declares that the purposes of this chapter
are to ensure that people are not unnecessarily exposed to the dangers of
chemicals used in the production of methamphetamine, and that proper steps are
taken to remove contaminants and assure appropriate tests are conducted in
affected structures to ensure they are sufficiently cleaned for human contact.
The mayor and city council finds that such sites may contain hazardous
