chemicals, substances, or residues that place people, particularly children or
adults of childbearing age, at risk of exposure should they inhabit or visit
the site. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
CERTIFIED INDUSTRIAL HYGIENIST: An individual who is certified by the American
Board Of Industrial Hygiene (ABIH) and is in good standing with that board.
ILLEGAL METHAMPHETAMINE LABORATORIES: The areas where methamphetamine has been
manufactured, processed, cooked, disposed of, or stored, and all proximate
areas that are likely to be contaminated as a result of such manufacturing,
processing, disposing, or storing.
OWNER: Any person, firm or corporation who holds record fee title, in whole or
in part, to the land, buildings or structures associated with an illegal
methamphetamine laboratory.
PROPERTY: Anything that may be the subject of ownership, including, but not
limited to, land, buildings, structures, mobile homes and vehicles. (Ord. 2364,
6-27-2011)
5-10-3: NOTICE TO OTHER AUTHORITIES:
Law enforcement or other authorities who identify the existence of an illegal
methamphetamine laboratory after the effective date hereof shall promptly
notify county department of public health and, if appropriate, child protection
services. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-4: NUISANCE DECLARED:
A property identified as the site of an illegal methamphetamine laboratory
shall be declared a public health nuisance and unfit for human habitation or
use. A warning sign shall be posted on the entrance of the affected part of the
property by law enforcement, the city fire chief, and the city code enforcement
officer or his designee. With respect to a vehicle, the warning sign shall be
posted on the front windshield. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-5: OCCUPANCY PROHIBITED:
Upon the issuance and posting of a declaration of public health nuisance, all
occupants of such building or structure shall immediately vacate the premises,
and such vehicles shall be impounded by the police. With the exception of
persons evaluating the contamination level, remediating the contamination, or
conducting fire or police activities, no person shall occupy or enter, or allow
occupancy or entrance, to a building or structure which has been declared a
public health nuisance, and no person shall occupy or drive a vehicle which has
been declared a public health nuisance until such declaration is revoked or
modified to allow occupancy. All who enter must have the required health and
safety training and wear appropriate personal protective equipment. Removal of
the posted declaration of public health nuisance by anyone other than the city
code enforcement officer, the fire chief or his designee or law enforcement
authorities is prohibited. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
5-10-6: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Notice To Owner: The city shall notify the property owner that the
property has been declared a public health nuisance, that the property owner
has the right to appeal the declaration to the mayor and city council, that the
city code requires cleanup according to the guidelines, and that the property
owner must contract with a certified industrial hygienist to assess the
contamination, oversee the cleanup, and provide a cleanup report; or that, in
the alternative, the property owner may demolish the building or structure.
   B.   Failure To Abate; Abatement By City: If, after ten (10) days following
notice, the city is unable to obtain any reasonable assurance or plan from the
property owner or occupant that the dwelling, structure or vehicle is being
properly vacated, cleaned, remediated and tested, and no appeal has been
requested:
      1.   A copy of the declaration of public health nuisance may be provided
to the lienholders and mortgage holders of the affected structure and/or
properties, and may be recorded with the clerk.
      2.   The city may seek to abate the nuisance itself and recover all costs
associated with such abatement.
      3.   The city may remove the structure or building and assess the whole
cost of such removal, including incidental costs, which assessment shall be a
lien against such property until paid.
   C.   Appeal: Any appeal shall be heard by the mayor and city council within
thirty (30) days. Upon a finding that the declaration was validly issued, the
property owner or occupant shall have ten (10) days to offer reasonable
assurance or a plan to the city that the dwelling or structure is being
properly vacated, cleaned, remediated and tested. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-7: AUTHORITY TO MODIFY OR REMOVE NUISANCE DECLARATION:
The code enforcement officer or the fire chief or his designee is authorized to
modify the declaration conditions or to remove the declaration of public health
nuisance only after the certified industrial hygienist submits his or her final
report to the city for review and acceptance, and the owner notifies the code
enforcement officer that cleanup has occurred. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011)
5-10-8: PENALTY:
Any person and/or entity violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code per day. (Ord. 2364, 6-27-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 11
DEPOSITS INTO, INTERFERENCE WITH WATERCOURSES AND DRAINAGE SYSTEMS
SECTION:
5-11-1: Acts For Which Permit Is Required
5-11-2: Prohibited Act
5-11-3: Correction Of Existing Conditions
5-11-4: No Permit Required
5-11-5: Procedure For Obtaining A Permit
5-11-6: Inspections
5-11-7: Acknowledgment And Responsibilities
5-11-8: Penalties And Corrective Action
5-11-1: ACTS FOR WHICH PERMIT IS REQUIRED:
Unless a permit has been issued as hereinafter provided it shall be unlawful
for any person, firm, entity or corporation to:
   A.   Place, deposit or permit to be placed or deposited any debris, fill,
sand, stone or other solid materials of any kind or nature, or construction of
any kind into or across any stream, ditch, culvert, pipe, watercourse or other
drainage system within the City of Marion, Illinois;
   B.   Construct and/or place any ditch, pipe, culvert or artificial
watercourse of any kind or nature which shall collect and direct the flow of
natural surface waters or drainage, or increase in intensity or quantity the
flow of surface waters or drainage from paved surfaces, structures, roads or
improvements directly into any stream, ditch, culvert, pipe or watercourse or
other drainage system in the City of Marion, Illinois;
   C.   Fill, obstruct, dam, divert or otherwise change or alter the natural or
artificial flow of waters or drainage, or the intensity or quantity of flow,
through any stream, ditch, pipe, culvert, watercourse or other improvements or
drainage system within the City of Marion, Illinois. (Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-2: PROHIBITED ACT:
No toxic waste or hazardous material shall be deposited in any such watercourse
or drainage system within the City of Marion, Illinois. (Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-3: CORRECTION OF EXISTING CONDITIONS:
Except as hereinafter provided, all existing obstructions, dams, diversions,
construction of any kind, deposits of debris, fill, sand, stone, logs, trees or
other solid materials, or other alterations or diversions of the natural flow
of water or the intensity or quantity of flow, through, across or to any
stream, ditch, culvert, watercourse or other drainage system within the City of
Marion, Illinois which:
   A.   Causes the flooding or inundation of real property and/or buildings on
other premises, or
   B.   Constitutes an undue burden upon the official drainage system or
hampers the proper present or future course of development of the official
drainage system, or
   C.   Presently constitutes or in the reasonably foreseeable future will
constitute a danger or hazard to the well-being, safety or general welfare of
the residents of the municipality of any property located therein; or
   D.   Obstructs the natural flow of water;
   E.   Shall be removed or corrected by the owners of the premises upon which
said obstructions, dams, diversion, construction, deposits or other alterations
of the natural flow of water are situated, within thirty days after written
notice to remove or correct same. (Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-4: NO PERMIT REQUIRED:
The requirement of a permit being issued before engaging in any of the acts
specified in Section
5-11-1 and Section
5-11-3 shall not apply to works to be done pursuant to the authority of an
agency of the state, federal or other government entity. (Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-5: PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING A PERMIT:
   A.   All applicants for a permit to do any of the acts set forth in Section
5-11-1 above shall submit a proposal to the City Building and Code Services. A
determination will be made if plans and specifications prepared by a licensed
professional engineer should be required. If it is determined such plans and
specifications are not required Building and Code Services may recommend to the
City Council that a permit be issued.
   If it is determined such plans and specifications should be required, the
Building and Code Services Officer, after review of plans and specification
submitted to him, may recommend to the City Council that the permit may be
issued.
   B.   When an application for a permit to do any of the acts set forth in
Section
5-11-1 above would affect land lying partly outside the area requiring approval
of subdivision or site development then a separate plan shall be prepared for
that affected land and filed with the City Building and Code Services for
review and, if need be, submitted to the City Designee.
   C.   If review by the City Designee is deemed appropriate the City Designee
shall report the results of his review to the Building and Code Services, if
deemed not appropriate the city shall require an elevation plan (at applicants’
expense) for recommendation to the City Council to approve or deny the
application. Upon approval by the City Council, the City Clerk shall notify the
Building and Code Services Office Manager of such action. After which the
Office Manager shall issue the permit upon receipt of a fifty-dollar ($50.00)
application fee.
   D.   All applications for dirt grading permits shall be submitted to the
Building and Code Services.
      1.   The application shall contain the following information:
         a.   Name, address and telephone number of applicant;
         b.   Number of loads (not to exceed 13 tons per load) to be hauled;
         c.   Approximate date when hauling is to occur;
         d.   The destination of the dirt;
         e.   Proposed grading plan.
      2.   The following shall be conditions of every permit issued:
         a.   Trucks shall be loaded in such a manner that there shall be no
spillage;
         b.   The permit shall specify the number of yards of dirt to be
hauled;
         c.   All loads shall be sprinkled to keep down the dust when
necessary;
         d.   The City streets shall be kept clean of spillage and wheel dirt
on allotted routes;
         e.   Crossing guards shall be provided at the expense of the applicant
when necessary in the opinion of the Street Department Superintendent or his/
her designee;
         f.   Grading shall not alter drainage pattern or intensity;
         g.   Shall maintain 1-2% drainage on building site at all times;
         h.   Change in surface/ground elevation cannot exceed 1' above current
gutter or curb elevation;
         i.   IEPA NPDES storm water permit is obtained when applicable. (Ord.
3627, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 3691, 12-14-2020)
5-11-6: INSPECTIONS:
As building and development progresses on a permitted project, periodic
inspections may be done by authorized City Personnel to ensure compliance with
all applicable provisions of Marion City Code. (Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-7: ACKNOWLEDGMENT AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
It shall be the understanding and responsibility of all property owners and
developers:
   A.   To ensure compliance with all State and Federal laws and regulations
and all applicable provisions of local Ordinance; and
   B.   Any obstruction, construction, alteration, or change that alters the
natural flow of water causing damage or flooding to other properties, in
addition to being in violation of local Ordinance, may subject the owner or
developer to civil liabilities to owners of said other properties so damaged.
(Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
5-11-8: PENALTIES AND CORRECTIVE ACTION:
Any person, firm, entity or corporation found to be violating any provisions of
this Ordinance shall be served with a written notice stating the nature of the
violation and provided a ten (10) business day time limit for the satisfactory
correction to be made. The offender shall, within the ten-day period stated in
such notice, correct and remove all violations. Any person, firm or corporation
who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for above,
shall be deemed guilty of an Ordinance violation of the City of Marion,
Illinois, and shall be fined in an amount not exceeding seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day the condition exists after the
ten-day notice is received shall be deemed a separate offense of this chapter.
(Ord. 3627, 6-22-2020)
CHAPTER 12
INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE
SECTION:
5-12-1: International Property Maintenance Code Adopted
5-12-1: INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE ADOPTED:
The 2018 edition of the International Property Maintenance Code is adopted,
(Attachment A to the ordinance codified herein) one copy shall be on file in
the Office of Building and Codes Services. Any person who violates any of the
provisions of the code adopted herein shall be subject to the General Penalty
under Chapter 4. (Ord. 3646, 9-28-2020)
CHAPTER 13
REGISTRATION OF VACANT BUILDINGS AND PROPERTIES
SECTION:
5-13-1: Purpose And Definitions
5-13-2: Registration And Maintenance Requirements; Fees; Marketing Requirements
5-13-3: Penalties; Procedures; Failure To Register Notice
5-13-4: Annual Inspection Requirements For Structures Or Properties Classified
As Chronic
5-13-1: PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS:
   A.   Purpose. Recognizing that vacant buildings and properties contribute to
blight in both residential and non-residential neighborhoods, discourage
economic development and hinder appreciation of property values, endanger
public health and safety, attract criminal activity, and create fire hazards,
it is the responsibility of property owners to prevent buildings from becoming
a burden to the neighborhood and community and a threat to the public health,
safety, and welfare. Maintenance of the public health, safety, and welfare thus
requires the City to maintain an accurate registration of all vacant buildings
and properties.
   B.   Definitions.
BUILDING:
A building, accessory structure, mobile or modular structure, or other
structure adapted to permanent occupancy for residential or commercial
purposes.
CITY:
The City of Marion.
CHRONIC VACANCY:
Any building or property vacant 1 year after initial registration.
COMMERCIAL:
Any "nonresidential structure or property" as defined in the Marion Code.
OWNER:
The person, persons or entity identified as the owner of the parcel with
Williamson County Property Records; or any agent identified by a nonresident
owner.
RESIDENTIAL:
Any "residential structure or property" as defined in the Marion Code.
UNSECURED:
Access to the building may be obtained through open, unlocked, broken or
missing doors or windows of such building.
VACANT BUILDING:
A building or property that is unattended or unoccupied and is not actively
used as a place of residence or business, has not had regular continuous water
service for six (6) months or more, or the building is frequently open or
unsecured so that unauthorized admittance may be gained without damaging any
portion of the property. A residential or commercial building or property will
be considered vacant when found to be in the above condition for more than six
(6) months and subject to the registration requirements found in Section 2.
Authorized admittance may only be shown by proof of a valid and current written
lease, agreement or contract. (Ord. 4040, 5-12-2025)
5-13-2: REGISTRATION AND MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS; FEES; MARKETING
REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Registration and maintenance requirements; fees.
      1.   All vacant buildings shall be registered with the City. If more than
one building exists on the same parcel or PIN, then a separate registration
shall be completed for each building.
      2.   The owner of a vacant building or property must register the
building with the City Building and Code Services Office within twenty (20)
days of written notice provided to the owner or the owner's resident agent of
the existence of the vacant building. Such notice shall be served on the owner
or resident agent by posting on the property, personal service or by certified
mail, return receipt requested. If the owner is a non-resident of Williamson
County, such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested.
All mailings shall be mailed to the address as stated on the county tax bill,
unless the owner has provided an updated address. If notice is returned
undelivered, or the owner cannot be located after a diligent search, then
notice may be made by publication in a local newspaper.
      3.   The City shall also accept notifications by mail or electronic
transmission of a building or property that meets the definition of a Vacant
Building or Property as defined in Section 1(b) and shall pursue registration
of said building/property in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
      4.   The required registration shall be submitted on the form provided by
the City available on the City's website or from Building & Code Services,
which form shall include the name, current mailing address, phone number, email
and any other contact information of the owner; the names and addresses of all
known mortgagees, lien holders and all other parties with a legal or equitable
ownership interest in the building; the common address of the building, as well
as the parcel tax identification and if requesting the fee waiver per Section 2
(b) it must also contain the sale or rental price. The form shall also include
the period of time the vacant building is expected to remain vacant, and a plan
and timetable for either:
         a.   Returning the vacant building or property to appropriate
occupancy or use; or
         b.   Demolition of the property by attaching a valid demolition
permit; or
         c.   Marketing the property pursuant to the requirements of subsection
B. of this Section.
      5.   Pursuant to the registration requirements of this subsection, for
every subsequent year a building remains vacant beyond the initial
registration, the owner of the vacant building must:
         a.   Re-register the building or property, including payment of the
appropriate fees, and
         b.   Submit an updated plan for either returning the vacant building
or property to appropriate occupancy or use, or marketing thereof.
      6.   Upon registration, the City may provide the following incentives
toward active marketing of residential or commercial buildings or properties:
         a.   Waive a portion of any City of Marion liens, if applicable, upon
sale of the property, to a maximum amount of fifteen hundred dollars
($1,500.00);
         b.   If the building requires remodeling, waive permit fees if
remodeling occurs within ninety (90) days of registration.
      7.   If the owner of the vacant building or property does not reside in
Williamson County for at least six (6) months a year, then they must provide
the information for a resident agent with authority to act with respect to the
property, including name, current mailing address, phone number, email and any
other contact information of the owner's agent.
      8.   Any subsequent owner of a vacant building or property must register
or re-register the building with the Building and Code Services Office within
thirty (30) days of any transfer of any ownership interest in the vacant
building.
      9.   The owner of a vacant building or property must keep the building
and any adjoining property secure, safe and maintained in compliance with all
federal, state and local ordinances and regulations and shall not allow
squatters to reside there in violation of local ordinances.
      10.   A registration fee, for vacant units not classified as chronic
vacancy, shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per residential building/ unit,
and one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per commercial building/unit, and shall be
collected by the Building and Code Services Office at the time of registration
or re-registration. If a building or property is vacant more than one (1) year
after initial registration it shall be classified as a Chronic Vacancy and
shall be subject to a fee of two-hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per year
for residential and five-hundred dollars ($500.00) per year for commercial/
industrial with a fifty dollar ($50.00) annual increase for each category.
Funds derived from said fee shall be used to offset the city's cost of annual
inspections and incentives as found in this chapter.
   B.   Marketing Requirements. The following vacant buildings or properties
shall be exempt, as described below, from the registration fee required
pursuant to Section 5-13-2, but must still comply with all other registration
requirements under this section:
      1.   All buildings which are actively marketed as "for rent" in a
newspaper or in a recognized online website listing at a fair market value
rental rate based upon market rental rates for comparable properties shall have
fees exempt for three (3) months. It is the obligation of the vacant building
owner to produce evidence of active marketing to claim this exemption. In the
event that active rental marketing ceases, the vacant building in question
shall be subject to the registration fees provided for above and shall
immediately be due and owing.
      2.   All buildings or properties which are being actively marketed as
"for sale", at a fair market value, by a licensed real estate broker or by the
owner and advertised as such in a newspaper or listed on a recognized online
website shall have fees exempt for six (6) months. The vacant building owner
has the obligation to produce evidence of active marketing in order to obtain
this exemption. In the event that the active "for sale" marketing ceases, the
vacant building in question shall be subject to the registration fees provided
for above and shall immediately be due and owing.
      3.   Any vacant residential building for which the owner executes a valid
affidavit on a form provided by the City attesting that the owner intends to
resume occupancy of the vacant building as a dwelling within 180 days shall
have fees exempt for six (6) months. Failure to actually resume use of the
vacant building as a dwelling within 180 days will result in imposition of the
registration fee that was exempted under this section which shall be
immediately due and owing;
         a.   If a request for an extension is made, the Building and Code
Office may grant a one-time extension of up to three (3) months after an
inspection is performed, with the inspection fee to be paid in advance, which
shows substantial compliance with the intent to resume occupancy.
      4.   An owner who acquires a vacant building or property for which the
registration fee has already been paid for the calendar year period shall
register the change of ownership with the City but is not liable for an
additional registration fee for that calendar year. (Ord. 4040, 5-12-2025)
5-13-3: PENALTIES; PROCEDURES; FAILURE TO REGISTER NOTICE:
   A.   Penalties; procedures.
      1.   Any owner who fails to register a vacant building under this
chapter, as required by Section 2, may be liable for a civil penalty of five-
hundred dollars ($500.00) per month for residential and seven-hundred and fifty
dollars ($750.00) per month for commercial buildings in addition to any other
penalty provided by Marion Code General Penalty (1-4-1).Citations may be issued
for such penalties.
      2.   In addition to the citation as stated above, if the building
continues to meet the definition of a vacant building for a period of ninety
(90) calendar days beyond the required registration or re-registration date,
and the owner fails to register or re-register such building, the City may
place a lien on the property for any amounts owed to the City of Marion from
such property to include the failure to register penalties, maintenance or
nuisance abatement costs, and administrative fees.
      3.   All penalties assessed shall be payable directly to the City unless
required to be paid through a court action
      4.   Any and all civil penalties assessed under this section shall be
billed to the owner or other responsible party. Failure or refusal to pay any
and all such penalties permits the City to pursue any and all available legal
remedies for the enforcement and collection of such penalties; including but
not limited to, civil actions being filed in district court, suits or actions
being maintained in any court of competent jurisdiction, abatement of nuisances
maintained in violation of this chapter, institution of injunction, mandamus,
or other appropriate action or proceedings to enforce the penalty provisions of
this chapter.
   B.   Failure to Register Notice.
      1.   Upon failure to register a vacant building, as required by Section
5-13-2, a Notice of Registration Penalty may be issued to the owner.
      2.   A separate Notice of Registration Penalty shall be issued for each
subsequent penalty that may be assessed pursuant to Section 5-13-3 A.
      3.   The Notice of Registration Penalty shall be served upon the owner by
posting upon the property, personal service, or certified mail, return receipt
requested, to the address as stated on the tax bill unless the owner has
previously provided an updated address. If the notice is not able to be served
in this manner, notice may be served by publication in a local newspaper.
      4.   This chapter in no way limits the penalties, actions or abatement
procedures which may be taken by the City for a violation of any other
ordinance of the City or statute of the State of Illinois. (Ord. 4040, 5-12-
2025)
5-13-4: ANNUAL INSPECTION REQUIREMENTS FOR STRUCTURES OR PROPERTIES CLASSIFIED
AS CHRONIC:
   A.   Annual inspection requirement for structures or properties classified
as chronic
      1.   The City designated officer or their appointee may inspect or cause
to be inspected any premises in the City for the purpose of enforcing and
assuring compliance with the provisions of this chapter and safeguarding the
health, safety and welfare of the general public. Upon the request of the City
designated officer, an owner shall provide access to all interior portions of
any vacant building or suspected vacant building in order to permit a complete
inspection.
      2.   The City Fire Chief is authorized to enter and inspect, or cause to
be inspected, all vacant buildings and premises for the purpose of conducting
an annual fire code compliance inspection. (Ord. 4040, 5-12-2025)
TITLE 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS
SECTION:
6-1-1: Appointment Of Police Chief And Fire Chief
6-1-2: Registry Lists
6-1-3: Preemployment Contract
6-1-4: Mandatory Retirement Age
6-1-5: Soliciting, Receipt Of Funds Or Equipment For Police Or Fire Department
6-1-1: APPOINTMENT OF POLICE CHIEF AND FIRE CHIEF:
The chief of police and the chief of the fire department shall be appointed by
the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, and said
appointments need not be made from the members of the police and fire
departments, respectively. (1977 Code § 2.08.040; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1-2: REGISTRY LISTS:
   A.   Commencing with the expiration of the current registry lists for
candidates for employment as city police officers or firefighters, the fire and
police merit board shall conduct examinations annually for candidates to be
enrolled in the registry lists.
   B.   The names of qualified candidates shall remain on the registry lists
for two (2) years.
   C.   The fire and police merit board shall have the discretion of selecting
names for employment from those on lists up to two (2) years or on the most
recently compiled lists. (Ord. 2253, 4-13-2009)
6-1-3: PREEMPLOYMENT CONTRACT:
   A.   Any applicant for a position in the fire department or the police
department must agree to the following conditions at the time of making
application for such position: that should he/she be hired as an employee of
the city police or fire department, he/she will not voluntarily or
involuntarily separate from the employ of the city for a minimum of thirty six
(36) months from the date of hire, otherwise, he/she will remunerate the city
for any and all costs incurred as enumerated in subsection B of this section at
the following rate: One hundred percent (100%), if separation is prior to
thirty six (36) months having elapsed from date of hire.
   B.   Schedule of costs which may be incurred by the city are: (Ord. 1744, 7-
6-1999)
      1.   Any preentry medical examination required by the city police and
firefighters' pension funds. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   Basic training, including Fire Fighter Recruit Academy and Police
Training Institute Recruit Academy, including lodging, meals and travel
expenses.
   C.   The obligations under the required agreement shall terminate after the
completion of thirty six (36) months from the date of hire. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-
1999)
   D.   The agreement shall contain a statement that the applicant understands
that employment with the city is contingent upon his/her completion of a
probationary period of twelve (12) months and continued performance to the
satisfaction of the city. Nothing contained herein shall be construed as a
promise or agreement by the city to retain the applicant as an employee of the
city for thirty six (36) months or any portion thereof or thereafter. (Ord.
1744, 7-6-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
   E.   The city does not, by the agreement, waive any of the rights,
privileges, or prerogatives it possesses now or hereafter in effect.
   F.   The applicant acknowledges that he/she has examined the agreement that
he/she has read and understands the agreement, and he/she has the right to
consult an attorney prior to entering the agreement. (Ord. 1744, 7-6-1999)
6-1-4: MANDATORY RETIREMENT AGE:
   A.   Established: There is established a mandatory retirement age for all
police officers and firefighters now in the service of the city and for all
police officers and firefighters who may hereafter enter the service of the
city. (1977 Code § 2.68.010)
   B.   Designated: The age at which such police officers and firefighters must
retire from the service of the city is designated to be sixty five (65) years.
(1977 Code § 2.68.020)
   C.   Time For Retirement: Any police officer or firefighter shall be retired
effective at the close of the first regular pay period after such police
officer or firefighter reaches his sixty fifth birthday. (1977 Code § 2.68.030)
6-1-5: SOLICITING, RECEIPT OF FUNDS OR EQUIPMENT FOR POLICE OR FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   No solicitation for money, directly or indirectly, in the name of or in
behalf of the city police department or the city fire department, expressed or
implied, shall be conducted within the city by mail, by telephone, in person or
otherwise without the prior approval of the city council.
   B.   Neither the city police department nor the city fire department nor the
personnel of either department may receive money or equipment for use by or use
in the respective departments from any individual, organization or entity
without the prior approval of the city council.
   C.   Personnel employed in the city police department or the city fire
department are prohibited from engaging in the solicitation of money or
equipment, directly or indirectly, for use in or by either department without
the prior approval of the city council. (Ord. 1702, 10-19-1998)
ARTICLE A. POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1A-1: Established
6-1A-2: Supervision
6-1A-3: Jurisdiction Of Police And Fire Merit Board; Exemptions
6-1A-4: Powers And Duties Of Chief
6-1A-5: Powers And Duties Of Department Members
6-1A-6: Police Pension Fund And Board
6-1A-7: Rules And Regulations Adopted
6-1A-8: Resisting, Hindering Police Prohibited
6-1A-9: Police Lieutenant
6-1A-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is established a police department of the city which shall consist of
such officers of the city as are by law clothed with police powers, a chief of
police, and such other police officers as the city council shall, from time to
time by ordinance or resolution, prescribe. (1977 Code § 2.24.010; amd. 2013
Code)
6-1A-2: SUPERVISION:
The police force of the city shall be under the immediate supervision of the
commissioner of public health and safety of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.100)
6-1A-3: JURISDICTION OF POLICE AND FIRE MERIT BOARD; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   All personnel in the city police department are certified to be subject
to and under the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board to the extent
provided by law. The offices of chief of police and assistant chief of police
remain exempt from and outside the purview of the jurisdiction of the police
and fire merit board. In the event any person holding the office of chief of
police returns to the ranks of sworn personnel, that individual will revert to
and be under the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board. (Ord. 1657,
6-23-1997; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Those employees of the city police department holding the supervisory
positions of chief and assistant chief are hereby specifically excepted and
exempted from any collective bargaining unit that is now or that may hereafter
be formed by the members of the department. (Ord. 1097, 12-30-1985; amd. 2013
Code)
6-1A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF:
   A.   Generally: The chief of police shall superintend the police force of
the city and have the custody, care and control of the public property of the
police department, subject to the directions of the commissioner of public
health and safety and the city council, and of all firearms and other equipment
thereof. It shall be his duty to preserve the peace, order, safety and
cleanliness of the city, and to this end, he shall execute or cause to be
executed and enforced all orders of the city council. He shall be charged with
the duty of protecting the rights of persons and property and cause to be
enforced all ordinances of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.020; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Health Duties: The chief of police shall execute or cause to be
executed all orders directed to him by the commissioner of public health and
safety so far as they relate to the preservation of the health and safety of
the people of the city. (1977 Code § 2.24.030; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Reports: The chief of police shall, at the first meeting of the city
council in May of each year, make an annual report in writing to the city
council of the state of the police force with a detailed report of the
transactions of the police department for the preceding year with such
statistics and suggestions in regard to the requirements of said department as
he may deem advisable, and shall also make reports of any matter or thing
concerning such department whenever requested by the commissioner of public
health and safety or by the city council. (1977 Code § 2.24.090)
6-1A-5: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   Serving Warrants: The chief of police and any regular or other police
officer shall have power and authority and it shall be his duty to serve and
execute within the city warrants and other processes for the apprehension and
commitment of persons charged with the violation of any city ordinance, or any
crime, misdemeanor or offense against the peace of the state of Illinois or the
city, or held for examination or trial, or taken on execution for the
commission of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any law or ordinance of
the city, and while serving or executing or assisting in the service or
execution of any such warrant or process as aforesaid, he shall be vested with
and have all the powers and authority conferred upon sheriffs by the common law
and laws of the state of Illinois. (1977 Code § 2.24.040; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Assist Fire Department: It shall be the duty of the police force to aid
the fire department by giving alarms in case of fire and by clearing the
streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of any fire so that the members of
the fire department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of
their duty. (1977 Code § 2.24.060)
   C.   Arrests: The several members of the police force are severally
authorized to arrest, with or without process or on view, any person who breaks
the peace or is found violating any ordinance of the city or any criminal law
of the state of Illinois, and to take such person before the proper judge or,
if necessary, detain such person in custody overnight or Sunday or any legal
holiday in the county jail or other qualified place of incarceration until he
can be brought before the proper judge for trial. (1977 Code § 2.24.070; amd.
2013 Code)
   D.   Court Duties: All police officers of the city making arrests shall
attend as witnesses before the court where the trial may be had and shall
procure all necessary evidence in their power and furnish a list of witnesses
to the court and the prosecuting attorney. (1977 Code § 2.24.080; amd. 2013
Code)
6-1A-6: POLICE PENSION FUND AND BOARD:
   A.   State Regulations Apply: The provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., "police pension fund - municipalities 500,000 and
under", are in force and effect in the city. (1977 Code § 2.60.010; amd. 2013
Code)
   B.   Board Of Trustees: The mayor of the city is authorized and directed to
appoint two (2) members to serve upon the board of trustees to administer the
police pension fund, one of whom shall serve until the second Tuesday in May
1955, and the other to serve until the second Tuesday in May 1956, and the two
(2) trustees so appointed shall call an election to be held as provided in the
act to choose the other members of the board of trustees. Each such trustee
shall serve a term of three (3) years which terms shall be staggered. (1977
Code § 2.60.030; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Treasurer:
      1.   The city finance director-treasurer shall be the treasurer and
custodian of the police pension fund and shall make disbursements therefrom
only at the direction of and on the authority of the board of trustees. (1977
Code § 2.60.040; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   The city finance director-treasurer shall set aside for the police
pension fund the monies provided to be set aside by the act designated in
subsection A of this section. (1977 Code § 2.60.020; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1A-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The rules and regulations of the police department, as set out in ordinance
1407, as amended, are hereby adopted by reference. A copy of said rules and
regulations is on file in the office of the city clerk for public use and
inspection. (2013 Code)
6-1A-8: RESISTING, HINDERING POLICE PROHIBITED:
Whoever, within the city, resists any member of the police force or any other
person duly authorized to do police duty, in the discharge of his duty, or in
any way interferes with, prevents or hinders in the discharge of his duty as
such member, or attempts to do so, or whoever in any manner assists any person
in the custody of any member of the police force to escape or to attempt to
escape from such custody, or attempts to rescue any person from such custody,
shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code § 2.24.050; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1A-9: POLICE LIEUTENANT:
   A.   There is hereby created the position of Lieutenant in the City Police
Department.
   B.   The personnel holding such position shall have such duties and
responsibilities as may be directed by the Police Chief of the Department as
well as those set out in the official Job Description for the position.
   C.   The position of Lieutenant shall be filled by final approval of the
City Council in open meeting after recommendation of the Police Chief and
Police Commissioner.
   D.   Wages and benefits for the personnel filling the position of Police
Lieutenant shall be as set by the Mayor and Council. (Ord. 3102, 4-29-2013,
amd. Ord. 3740, 8-9-2021)
ARTICLE B. FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1B-1: Jurisdiction Of Police And Fire Merit Board; Exemptions
6-1B-2: Firefighters' Pension Fund And Board
6-1B-3: Nonresident Fees For Department Services
6-1B-4: Hazardous Substances Spills/Vehicle Accidents
6-1B-5: Specialized And Technical Rescue Services
6-1B-6: Training
6-1B-7: Arson Investigator
6-1B-1: JURISDICTION OF POLICE AND FIRE MERIT BOARD; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   All personnel in the city fire department are certified to be subject
to and under the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board to the extent
provided by law. The office of fire chief remains exempt from and outside the
purview of the jurisdiction of the police and fire merit board. In the event
any person holding the office of fire chief returns to the ranks of sworn
personnel, that individual will revert to and be under the jurisdiction of the
police and fire merit board. (Ord. 1657, 6-23-1997; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   The city does hereby recognize the Marion Professional Firefighters
Local 2977 of the International Association Of Firefighters AFL-CIO-CLC as the
exclusive bargaining representative for all full time employees of the city
fire department, excluding the chief, for the purpose of collective bargaining,
and establishing and administering a written labor agreement covering wages,
rates of pay, hours of labor, and all other terms and conditions of employment.
(Ord. 1111, 3-31-1986)
6-1B-2: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND AND BOARD:
   A.   State Regulations Apply: The provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/4-101 et seq., "firefighters' pension fund - municipalities 500,000
and under", are in force and effect in the city. (1977 Code § 2.64.010; amd.
2013 Code)
   B.   Board Of Trustees:
      1.   Created; Composition: There is hereby created the board of trustees
of the firefighters' pension fund. The membership of the board shall be as
follows: the city finance director- treasurer, the city clerk, the fire chief,
the mayor, three (3) persons from the ranks of active firefighters and one
person who has retired under the firefighters' pension fund act of 1919.
      2.   Elected Members:
         a.   The members chosen from the active and retired firefighters shall
be elected by ballot at elections to be held on the third Monday in April of
the applicable years under the Australian ballot system, at such place or
places in the city, and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the
board.
         b.   No person shall cast more than one vote for each candidate for
whom he or she is eligible to vote. In the elections for board members to be
chosen from the active firefighters, all active firefighters and no others may
vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from retired
firefighters, the retired firefighters and no others may vote.
         c.   Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term
of three (3) years and until his or her successor has been duly elected and
qualified.
         d.   The board shall canvass the ballots and declare which persons
have been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In case of a tie
vote between two (2) or more candidates, the board shall determine by lot which
candidate or candidates have been elected and for what term or terms
respectively. In the event of the failure, resignation, or inability to act of
any board member, a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a
special election called by the board and conducted in the same manner as a
regular election.
      3.   President And Secretary: The board shall elect annually from its
members a president and secretary.
      4.   Compensation: Board members shall not receive or have any right to
receive any salary from a pension fund for services performed as board members.
(2013 Code)
   C.   Treasurer:
      1.   The city finance director-treasurer shall be treasurer and custodian
of the firefighters' pension fund and shall make disbursements thereof only at
the direction of and the authorization of the board of trustees. (1977 Code §
2.64.040; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   The city finance director-treasurer shall set aside for the
firefighters' pension fund the monies provided to be set aside by the act
designated in subsection A of this section from time to time as required by
law. (1977 Code § 2.64.020; amd. 2013 Code)
6-1B-3: NONRESIDENT FEES FOR DEPARTMENT SERVICES:
   A.   Established:
      1.   Any nonresident of the city who receives service from the city fire
department personnel and city emergency equipment, including the "jaws of
life", while within the corporate limits of the city shall pay a fee of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
      2.   Any nonresident of the city who receives service from the city fire
department personnel and city emergency equipment, including the "jaws of
life", outside the corporate limits of the city shall pay a fee of two thousand
dollars ($2,000.00).
   B.   Copies Of Provisions: Copies of reports of the providing of the
services indicated in subsection A of this section will be made available by
the fire department upon payment of five dollars ($5.00) for each copy. (Ord.
1568, 9-5-1995; amd. Ord. 3718, 4-12-2021)
6-1B-4: HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES SPILLS/VEHICLE ACCIDENTS:
   A.   Immediate Response Required: The city fire department is authorized and
directed to respond, immediately upon being notified, and to do all things
within its capabilities to contain, remove and dispose of any material
hazardous to public health and safety that is leaked, spilled or otherwise
improperly released within the corporate limits of the city or within a
reasonable distance thereof.
   B.   Contract For Services: Should such response require the services of
special personnel and equipment beyond the capabilities of the city fire
department to provide, the chief of the fire department is authorized to obtain
or to contract for the services of personnel or equipment sufficient to
contain, remove and dispose of such hazardous materials.
   C.   Responsibility For Costs: The costs incurred for the use of such
special personnel and equipment, in addition to the costs of the use of city
personnel and equipment, shall be charged to the person, firm or organization,
jointly and severally, in possession of, in the process of transporting or
otherwise responsible for the containment of any hazardous material spilled,
leaked or otherwise improperly released.
   D.   Costs Established: The amount of the costs incurred by the city from
the use of special personnel and equipment are the amounts to be charged the
person, firm or organization designated in subsection C of this section. In
addition, such person, firm or organization shall be charged for the use of
city personnel, equipment and materials as follows:
Pumper truck                 $500.00 per hour
Aerial ladder truck          $750.00 per hour
Communications unit          $500.00 per hour
Hazardous materials truck    $500.00 per hour
Off duty personnel call back Hourly overtime rate, plus 30 percent
Other personnel              Regular hourly rate
Materials                    Cost of replacement
Other equipment              Regular hourly rate
 
(Ord. 1570, 9-11-1995; amd. Ord. 2275, 7-20-2009; Ord. 3718, 4-12-2021)
6-1B-5: SPECIALIZED AND TECHNICAL RESCUE SERVICES:
   A.   Immediate Response Required: The city fire department is authorized and
directed to respond, immediately upon being notified, and to do all things
within its capabilities to safely and responsibly perform specialized and
technical rescue services including, but not limited to, structural collapse,
tactical rescue, high angle rescue, underwater rescue and recovery, confined
space rescue, below grade rescue and trench rescue within the corporate limits
of the city or within a reasonable distance thereof.
   B.   Contract For Services: Should such response require the services of
specially trained personnel and equipment required to perform specialized and
technical rescues beyond the capabilities of the city fire department, the
chief of the fire department is authorized to obtain or to contract the
services of personnel and/or equipment sufficient to perform such specialized
and technical rescue services.
   C.   Responsibility For Costs: The costs incurred for the use of specialized
personnel and equipment, in addition to the costs of the use of city personnel
and equipment, shall be charged to the person, firm or organization, jointly
and severally, requiring or responsible for the deployment and subsequent
operations of such specialized and technical rescue personnel and equipment.
   D.   Costs Established: The costs incurred by the city from the use of
specialized personnel and equipment are the amounts to be charged the person,
firm or organization designated in subsection C of this section. In addition,
such person, firm or organization shall be charged for the use of city
personnel, equipment and materials as follows:
Pumper engine                $500.00 per hour
Aerial ladder truck          $750.00 per hour
Technical rescue unit        $500.00 per hour
Communications unit          $500.00 per hour
Off duty personnel call back Hourly overtime rate, plus 30 percent
On duty personnel            Regular hourly rate
Materials                    Cost of replacement
Other equipment              Scheduled hourly rate
 
(Ord. 2282, 9-14-2009; amd. Ord. 3718, 4-12-2021)
6-1B-6: TRAINING:
   A.   Participation In State Training Act: The city hereby elects to
participate in the programs provided in the Illinois fire protection training
act.
   B.   Certification Required: Before any individual may commence regular full
time employment as a firefighter, he must have been certified by the Illinois
state fire marshal as a firefighter II, as having successfully completed an
approved training course as provided in the act.
   C.   Time For Completion Of Training: The firefighter II certification must
be completed by the trainee within his probationary period of twelve (12)
months or as soon as training schedules permit thereafter. Failure of any
trainee to complete such basic training and certifications within the required
period will render that individual and the city ineligible for reimbursement
funding for basic training for that individual in the fiscal year in which his
probationary period ends. The individual may later become certified without
reimbursement. (Ord. 2269, 7-20-2009)
6-1B-7: ARSON INVESTIGATOR:
   A.   There is hereby created within the Marion fire department the position
of "arson investigator".
   B.   The arson investigator shall be named by the chief of the fire
department and possess the following qualifications:
      1.   Be a full time sworn firefighter for the Marion fire department;
      2.   Be certified as a firefighter II or basic firefighter by the state
of Illinois;
      3.   To have successfully completed a course in fire and arson
investigation approved by the office of the state fire marshal pursuant to the
Illinois fire protection training act, 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 740/1 et
seq.;
      4.   To have completed a training program offered or approved by the
Illinois law enforcement training and standards board which substantially
conforms to standards promulgated pursuant to the Illinois police training act,
50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 705/1 et seq.;
      5.   To have completed an Illinois mandatory firearms training course
offered or approved by the Illinois law enforcement training and standards
board which substantially conforms to standards promulgated pursuant to the
Illinois police training act and the peace officer and probation officer
firearm training act.
   C.   The arson investigator shall have the following duties and powers:
      1.   To investigate, at the direction of the chief of the department and
in his absence the assistant chief, fires having an unknown origin and cause or
otherwise being suspicious in nature. In the absence of the chief or assistant
chief the next highest ranking officer shall be responsible for determining the
origin and cause of such fires;
      2.   To effect arrest when there exists probable cause to do so;
      3.   To apply for and secure warrants for arrest and searches;
      4.   To execute search warrants and seize such evidence described in the
search warrant;
      5.   To carry weapons as may be reasonably necessary during the course of
an investigation of the origin, cause, and circumstances of such fires or
explosions that are suspected to be arson or arson related crimes; and
      6.   To perform all other necessary and reasonable actions as directed by
the chief of the department.
   D.   The arson investigator is hereby classified as a peace officer.
   E.   The arson investigator shall be considered a member of the Marion fire
department and shall, in addition to the duties imposed by subsection C of this
section, discharge the duties of their assigned rank by the chief of the
department. (Ord. 3268, 7-16-2015)
CHAPTER 2
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
SECTION:
6-2-0: Department Of Emergency Management
6-2-1: Policy And Purpose
6-2-2: Definitions
6-2-3: Emergency Manager

6-2-5: Emergency Regulations
6-2-6: Emergency Management Functions
6-2-7: Emergency Operations Plan
6-2-0: DEPARTMENT OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT:
There is hereby established the department of emergency management, the purpose
of which is to plan for and prepare to manage the city response for carrying
out emergency functions necessary to contend with disasters or emergencies that
disrupt normal community activities or city services in order to preserve and
protect the lives and property of the citizens of Marion. (Ord. 3132, 10-28-
2013)
6-2-1: POLICY AND PURPOSE:
Because of the possibility of the occurrence of disasters, natural and
otherwise, which may result in injury to persons and damage to property in
order to assure preparations of the city will be adequate to cope with such
eventualities, it is hereby declared to be necessary:
   A.   To establish a department of emergency management for the planning and
preparation for emergency government operations in times of disasters.
   B.   To create the office of emergency manager, the occupant of which shall
administer the operations of the department of emergency management.
   C.   To comply with provisions of statutes which allow a local unit of
government to establish an organization for emergency management.
   D.   For the emergency manager to exercise such necessary powers as may be
required to facilitate the operation of the department as are authorized by the
city council and relative state and federal regulations.
   E.   To provide for the rendering of mutual aid between the city and other
units of government with respect to the carrying out of emergency preparedness
management subject to direction of the city council. (Ord. 3132, 10-28-2013)
6-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
DISASTER: Considered to be an occurrence that has resulted in injury to persons
or extensive damage to property for which customary resources for relief or
assistance within the affected area are insufficient to succor such injuries or
repair such damage after they occur.
EMERGENCY: A sudden condition or state of affairs calling for immediate action
to prevent injury to person or damage to property, or to call for immediate
response where injury to person or damage to property has occurred
precipitously.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: Considered to include preparation for and to carry out
emergency functions to prevent injury to persons and damage to property which
could result from a potential catastrophic or disastrous event. Emergency
management shall include providing necessary functions for the care of persons
afflicted and minimizing the effect of damage to property resulting from such
an event.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT FORCES: The total personnel resources engaged in emergency
management functions in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or any
rule or order hereunder. This includes personnel from city departments,
authorized volunteers, and private organizations and agencies.
EMERGENCY MANAGER: The staff element responsible for coordinating city planning
and preparation for disaster response. This position is a city liaison and
coordinates with federal, state and local jurisdictions relative to disaster
preparedness activities and assures implementation of federal and state program
requirements. (Ord. 3032, 1-30-2012; amd. 2013 Code; Ord. 3132, 10-28-2013)
6-2-3: EMERGENCY MANAGER:
   A.   Created; Appointment And Term; Compensation: There is hereby created
the office of emergency manager, the occupant of which shall administer the
operation of the department of emergency management and have responsibility in
cooperation with the superintendents of other city departments for the
organization and operation of emergency preparedness for response to a disaster
or emergency. The emergency manager shall be appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the city council. The emergency manager shall serve at
the will of the mayor and will receive salary and benefits as determined by the
city council. (Ord. 3132, 10-28-2013)
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The emergency manager, with the consent of the mayor, shall
represent the city on any city, regional, or state meetings or conferences
relating to emergency management.
      2.   The emergency manager shall develop proposed mutual aid agreements
with other political subdivisions of the state for reciprocal emergency
management aid and assistance in an emergency too great to be dealt with
unassisted, and shall present such agreements to the city council for its
action. Such arrangements shall be consistent with the state emergency plan.
      3.   The emergency manager shall make studies and surveys of the
manpower, industries, resources and facilities of the city as deemed necessary
to determine their adequacy for emergency management and to plan for their most
efficient use in times of an emergency or disaster.
      4.   The emergency manager shall establish the economic stabilization
systems and measures, service staffs, boards and subboards, if required, in
accordance with state and federal plans and directions, subject to approval of
the mayor and city council.
      5.   The emergency manager shall prepare a comprehensive emergency plan
for the emergency preparedness of the city including municipal and
unincorporated areas and shall present such plan to the city council for its
approval. When the city council has approved the plan by resolution, it shall
be the duty of all city agencies and all emergency preparedness forces of the
city to perform the duties and functions assigned by the plan as approved. The
plan may be modified in like manner from time to time.
      6.   The emergency manager shall coordinate the emergency management
activities of the city to the end that they shall be consistent and fully
integrated with the emergency plan of the federal government and the state and
correlated with emergency plans of other political subdivisions within the
state.
      7.   In accordance with the state emergency plan, the emergency manager
shall institute such training programs, public information programs and conduct
practice warning alerts and emergency exercises as may be necessary to assure
prompt and effective operation of the city comprehensive emergency management
plan when a disaster occurs.
      8.   The emergency manager shall utilize the personnel, services,
equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments and agencies of the
city to the maximum extent practicable. The officers and personnel of all such
departments and agencies shall, to the maximum extent practicable, cooperate
with and extend such services and facilities to the city emergency manager upon
request. The head of each department or agency, in cooperation with the
emergency manager, shall be responsible for the planning and programming of
such emergency activities as will involve the utilization of the facilities of
the department or agency.
      9.   The emergency manager shall, in cooperation with existing city
departments and agencies affected, assist in the organizing, recruiting and
training of such emergency management personnel that may be required on a
volunteer basis to carry out the emergency plans of the city and state. To the
extent that such emergency personnel are recruited to augment a regular city
department or agency for emergencies, they shall be assigned to such
departments or agencies and shall be under the administration and control of
said department or agency.
      10.   Consistent with the state emergency services law, the emergency
manager shall coordinate the activity of the municipal emergency management
plan within the city and assist in establishing and conducting training
programs as required to assure emergency operational capability in the various
emergency response and recovery services.
      11.   The emergency manager shall carry out all orders, rules and
regulations issued by the governor with reference to emergency management.
      12.   The emergency manager shall act as principal aide and adviser to
the mayor who shall be responsible for direction and control of all city
emergency operations during an emergency. The emergency manager's main
responsibility is to assure coordination among the operating departments,
nongovernmental groups, and with higher and adjacent governments.
      13.   The emergency manager shall prepare and submit such reports on
emergency preparedness activities as may be requested by the city council or
the mayor. (Ord. 3032, 1-30-2012)
      14.   The emergency manager shall be the liaison to and coordinator with
federal, state and other local jurisdictions with regard to disaster and
emergency preparedness and implementation of federal and state program
requirements. (Ord. 3132, 10-28-2013)
6-2-4: LOCAL STATE OF EMERGENCY:
   (a)   Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   EMERGENCY:
      (1)   A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual
force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power
to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law;
or
      (2)   Any natural disaster, epidemic, or manmade calamity, including
outbreak of disease, flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or
explosion, or eminent threat of any of those events within the corporate limits
of the city, resulting in or threatening the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare.
   CURFEW: A prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering,
standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant
premises within the corporate limits of the city except officials of any
governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to
said civil emergency.
   (b)   Declaration. Whenever an emergency, as defined in subsection (a) of
this section exists, the Mayor is authorized to declare the existence of a
Local State of Emergency by means of a written declaration of the Mayor, under
oath, setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency, describing the
nature of the emergency and declaring that a Local State of Emergency exists in
accordance with the definitions set forth in this section. This declaration
must be filed with the municipal clerk as soon as practicable after issuance.
   (c)   Curfew authorized. After proclamation of a Local State of Emergency by
the Mayor, he or she may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical
areas of the city or to the city as a whole, as he or she deems reasonable and
advisable, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he or she
deems necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare.
   (d)   Orders authorized. After the proclamation of a Local State of
Emergency, the Mayor may also, in the interest of public safety and welfare,
and to address the issues caused or threatened by the emergency, make take any
or all of the following actions by executive order during the state of
emergency:
      (1)   All actions reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency;
      (2)   Approve previously appropriated expenditures of the city for the
purpose of continuing the operations of the municipality; and
      (3)   In the event the Local State of Emergency extends beyond the
current fiscal year and a new budget has not been approved, the Mayor shall be
authorized to approve new spending by the City during the existence of the
Local State of Emergency.
      (4)   Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns
and private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating
liquor and beer is permitted;
      (5)   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer;
      (6)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away
gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
   (e)   Duration. The declaration herein authorized shall be effective for a
period of up to 30 days or until the adjournment of the next regular or special
meeting of the city council, whichever comes first, unless sooner terminated by
a proclamation of the Mayor, or, his or her interim emergency successor,
indicating that the local emergency no longer exists. The Mayor or his or her
interim emergency successor, shall have the power to re-proclaim the existence
of an emergency at the end of each 30-day period during the time said emergency
exists.
   (f)   Notice. Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the municipal
clerk shall notify the news media situated within the City, and shall cause at
least four copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency
and any curfew to be posted at the following places within the city: the city
hall, the police station, the post office, and in the area of any curfew.
   (g)    Violations. Any person violating the provisions of this section or
executive orders issued pursuant hereto shall be guilty of an offense against
the City and shall be punished as provided by section
1-4-1 of the City code.
   (h)   Effect on other ordinances. Nothing contained in this section shall be
construed to impair the powers contained in this Code, giving powers to the
police and fire departments, but shall be construed together with existing
ordinances now in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the
City. (Ord. 3032, 1-30-2012; amd. Ord. 36055, 3-25-2020)
6-2-5: EMERGENCY REGULATIONS:
   A.   Whenever necessary to meet a declared emergency or to prepare for such
an emergency for which adequate regulations have not been adopted by the
governor or city council, the council may, by resolution, promulgate
regulations, consistent with applicable federal or state law or regulation,
respecting:
      1.   The conduct of persons and the use of property during emergencies.
      2.   The repair, maintenance, and safeguarding of essential public
services, emergency health, fire, and safety regulation, drills, or practice
periods required for preliminary training, and all other matters which are
required to protect public safety, health, and welfare in declared emergencies.
   B.   Every resolution of emergency regulations shall be in writing; shall be
dated; shall refer to the particular emergency to which it pertains, if so
limited; and shall be filed in the office of the city administrator, which copy
shall be kept posted and available for public inspection during business hours.
Notice of the existence of such regulation and its availability for inspection
at the administrator's office shall be conspicuously posted at the front of the
city hall or other headquarters of the city or at such other places in the
affected area as the council or mayor shall designate in the resolution. By
like resolution, the council or mayor may modify or rescind any such
regulation.
   C.   The city council or mayor may rescind any such regulation by resolution
at any time. If not sooner rescinded, every such regulation shall expire at the
end of thirty (30) days after its effective date or at the end of the emergency
to which it relates, whichever comes first. Any resolution, rule, or regulation
inconsistent with an emergency regulation promulgated by the council or mayor
shall be suspended during the period of time and to the extent such conflict
exists.
   D.   During a declared emergency, the city, notwithstanding any statutory
provision to the contrary, is empowered, through its governing body acting
within or without the corporate limits of the city, to enter into contracts and
incur obligations necessary to combat such disaster by protecting the health
and safety of persons and property and providing emergency assistance to the
victims of such disaster. The city may exercise such powers in light of the
exigencies of the disaster without compliance with normal procedures and
formalities prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work,
entering rental equipment agreements, purchase of supplies and materials,
limitations upon tax levies, and the appropriation and expenditure of public
funds including, but not limited to, publication of resolutions, publication of
call for bids, provisions of personnel laws and rules, provisions relating to
low bids, and requirement for budgets. (Ord. 3032, 1-30-2012)
6-2-6: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS:
All functions hereunder and all other activities relating to emergency
management are hereby declared to be governmental functions. The provisions of
this section shall not affect the right of any person to receive benefits to
which he would otherwise be entitled under this chapter, or under the workers'
compensation law, or under any pension law, nor the right of any such person to
receive any benefits or compensation under any act of congress. (Ord. 3032, 1-
30-2012)
6-2-7: EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLAN:
All agencies shall abide by and cooperate fully with the provisions described
or referenced in the emergency operations plan attached to the ordinance
codified herein. All responsibilities of tasked organizations to prepare and
maintain standard operating procedures and commit them to training, exercising
and plan maintenance efforts needed to support the EP is declared. All tasked
organizations further agree to implement full compliance with all principals
and operational protocols in compliance with the national incident management
system (NIMS) to ensure effective cross jurisdictional cooperation between
multiple organizations when responding to incidents. (Ord. 3045, 4-9-2012)
CHAPTER 3
FALSE ALARMS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Responsibility For False Alarms
6-3-3: Notice Of False Alarms
6-3-4: Service Fees
6-3-5: False Alarms Prohibited
6-3-6: Penalty
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
ALARM SYSTEM: A device or assembly of equipment or devices designed or arranged
to signal the presence or existence of a hazard requiring urgent attention of
fire department personnel. These systems include:
   A.   Smoke, fire, sprinkler alarms and any other alarm which requires an
emergency response by the fire department;
   B.   Those systems terminating at a dedicated piece of equipment within the
Marion fire department or Marion police department;
   C.   Automatic devices which transmit voice reproductions or messages over
telephone lines; and
   D.   Systems which notify certain alarm stations which, in turn, notify the
Marion fire department or Marion police department of such alarms.
ALARM USER: Any person who owns, possesses, controls, or otherwise exercises
dominion over a premises or property, or who regularly supervises the operation
of any business thereon, on or in regard to which premises or property an alarm
system is maintained. A person owns or controls property if he is the grantee
under a deed, purchaser under a contract or a tenant.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system resulting in a signal or calls
when there is no threat to life, safety, or property requiring urgent attention
in, on, or at the property in regard to which the signal or call was sent. A
false alarm includes, but is not limited to, activation of an alarm system
caused by human error; a mechanical or system malfunction which results from
neglect or failure to maintain; or an intentional activation when no threat is
present.
Prior notification must be received by the fire department and police
department, from the responsible party, if the alarm system is being installed,
repaired, maintained, or tested. Failure to notify the departments in advance
of the activity in connection with the alarm system will result in a fee being
imposed for a false alarm.
PERSON: A natural person or a firm, organization, association, partnership or
corporation. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-2009)
6-3-2: RESPONSIBILITY FOR FALSE ALARMS:
The alarm user shall be responsible for all false alarms sent because of the
activation of an alarm system in, or in regard to, his property, or because of
the action or statement of any of his employees or agents, if such action or
statement is likely to result in the sending of an alarm, except when the agent
or employee making the statement, taking the action or sending the alarm does
so with the specific intention of sending a false alarm or causing one to be
sent, or does so without caring whether the alarm is false. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-
2009)
6-3-3: NOTICE OF FALSE ALARMS:
The fire chief or his designee shall notify the responsible person in writing,
by personal service or by U.S. postal service. The notification will inform the
person after the third occurrence of a false alarm to take corrective action in
regard to false alarms and inform him that any further false alarms will be
subject to the false alarm fee schedule. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-2009)
6-3-4: SERVICE FEES:
   A.   Fees Established: The fourth false alarm occurring and every false
alarm thereafter from or in regard to the same premises or property shall
result in the alarm user being assessed a service fee. The service fee for the
fourth false alarm shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00); the service fee for
the fifth false alarm shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00); with each
subsequent false alarm increasing an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Waiver Of Fee: The service fee may be waived by the fire chief or his
designee in cases where the false alarm is not reasonably attributable to the
alarm user or the alarm user's equipment. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-2009)
6-3-5: FALSE ALARMS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to send or give a false alarm. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-
2009)
6-3-6: PENALTY:
Any person who knowingly sends or causes to be sent a false alarm shall be
punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2271, 7-20-2009; amd. 2013 Code)

6-4-1: PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS:
6-4-1-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety, and
general welfare of the citizens of the City of Marion and to ensure the humane
treatment of animals by regulating the care and control of animals within the
City by guarding against the annoyance and injury caused by animals and to
protect them from neglect and abuse, and to discourage the unnecessarily
excessive multiplication of animals, which have a tendency to run at large.
(Ord. 3497, 3-7-2019; amd. Ord. 3902, - -2023)
6-4-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
           Fortified commercial product or home built shelter that protects an animal
ADEQUATE   from the elements, is properly ventilated to prevent suffocation, and is of a
SHELTER:   proper size to allow an animal to stand up, turn around, comfortably lay down,
           and move freely into and out of the structure.
ANIMAL     A person appointed by the Council, who is responsible for enforcing and
CONTROL    administering and performing such duties as prescribed by the provisions and
OFFICER:   requirements contained in this chapter. The animal control officer will report
           to the Chief of Police or his designee.
ANIMAL     An animal control facility used to house any stray, confiscated, homeless, or
CONTROL    abandoned animal.
SHELTER:
ASSISTANT  A full or part time employee who is responsible to the animal control officer
TO ANIMAL  who performs duties as assigned by the animal control officer, or his
CONTROL:   supervisors.
           Seizure of a person with teeth or jaws of any cat, dog or other animal capable
BITE:      of transmitting rabies; so that the human or animal seized has been nipped,
           gripped, wounded, or pierced, or has had contact of animal saliva with a break
           or abrasion of the skin.
           Any act or omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering, or death
           of an animal is caused or permitted, including failure to provide proper
CRUELTY:   drinking water, air, space, shelter or protection from the elements, a
           sanitary and safe living environment, veterinary care or nutritious food in
           sufficient quantity.
           Any individual dog which when either unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by
DANGEROUS  its owner, or custodian, in a terrorizing or menacing manner, approaches any
ANIMAL:    human being in a reasonably apparent attitude of attack upon any street,

DOMESTIC   Any dog, cat, domesticated sheep, horse, cow, goat, swine, fowl, duck, goose,
ANIMAL:    turkey, confined domestic hare and rabbit, pheasant, and other birds and
           animals raised and/or maintained in confinement.
           A fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, designed to prevent
           the escape of a dog from said structure and the entry of any young children,
           and suitable to confine a dangerous dog in conjunction with other measures
           that may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of the dangerous
           dog within the enclosure. Such fence must be in compliance with any other
           ordinance(s) regarding fences and adopted and made part of a code enforced by
ENCLOSURE: the City of Marion. The enclosure shall be securely enclosed and locked and
           designed with secure sides, top, and bottom and shall be capable of preventing
