North Van Buren Street The alley extending westwardly from the     Westerly
                       northeast corner of the public square
                       The alley extending westwardly from the
South Van Buren Street southwest corner of the public square       Westerly
                       (sometimes known as West Paradise Avenue)
 
(1977 Code §§ 10.12.030, 10.12.040, 10.12.060, 10.12.070, 10.12.080, 10.12.090)
   C.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this section
shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). (2013 Code)
7-5-5: ADDITIONAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS IN PUBLIC SQUARE:
Vehicular traffic entering the public square from the east or from the west
shall have precedence over traffic entering the public square from the north or
the south. (1977 Code § 10.12.120)
7-5-6: SIGNS POSTED:
Appropriate signs shall be posted at the appropriate locations indicating the
traffic restrictions set out in this chapter. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 6
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
7-6-1: Right Of Way
7-6-2: Use Of Roadways
7-6-3: Soliciting Contributions
7-6-4: Pedestrian Control Signals
7-6-5: Standing On Sidewalks
7-6-6: Pedestrians With Disabilities
7-6-1: RIGHT OF WAY:
   A.   Where traffic control signals or pedestrian control signals provided in
chapter 2 of this title and section
7-6-4 of this chapter are not in place or in operation, the driver of a vehicle
shall yield the right of way, slowing down or stopping if need be, to a
pedestrian crossing the roadway or street within any marked crosswalk or within
any unmarked crosswalk.
   B.   Whenever stop signals or flashing red signals are in place at an
intersection or a marked crosswalk between intersections, the pedestrian shall
have the right of way over drivers of vehicles; and at such marked places,
drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk, and any
pedestrian within or entering the crosswalk at either edge of the roadway shall
have the right of way over any vehicle so stopped.
   C.   The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk when
any vehicle proceeding in the same direction is stopped at such crosswalk for
the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross. (1977 Code § 10.24.010)
7-6-2: USE OF ROADWAYS:
   A.   Pedestrian Crossings:
      1.   At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the
most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at any place other
than a crosswalk, he shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the
roadway. (1977 Code § 10.24.020)
      2.   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are
in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
      3.   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than at a crosswalk in any
business district. (1977 Code § 10.24.050)
   B.   Pedestrians Walking Along Roadways:
      1.   Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to
walk along and upon an adjacent roadway.
      2.   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the
roadway or its shoulder facing traffic and, upon meeting a vehicle, shall step
off to the left.
      3.   No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a
ride from the driver of any vehicle. (1977 Code § 10.24.060)
      4.   No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a
safety zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1977
Code § 10.24.020)
7-6-3: SOLICITING CONTRIBUTIONS:
   A.   City Approval Required: No solicitation of persons in vehicles by
persons standing upon a public street or highway shall be undertaken without
the prior consent of the mayor or the commissioner of public health and safety.
(1977 Code § 9.32.040)
   B.   Conditions: No person shall stand on a public street or highway for the
purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except
under the following conditions:
      1.   When the solicitation is made at intersections where all traffic is
required to come to a full stop. (1977 Code § 9.32.010)
      2.   When the solicitation is made at the intersection of Market Street
and Main Street within the public square. (2013 Code)
   C.   Qualifications Of Solicitor: Any person engaged in the act of
solicitation shall be sixteen (16) years of age or more and shall be wearing a
high visibility vest. (1977 Code § 9.32.030)
   D.   Liability Of Soliciting Agency: The soliciting agency shall be liable
for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is
causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
(1977 Code § 9.32.020)
   E.   Penalty: Every person convicted of a violation of this section shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code § 9.32.050; amd. 2013 Code)
7-6-4: PEDESTRIAN CONTROL SIGNALS:
At intersections where traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop and
go signal, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway other than
with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of
traffic. (1977 Code § 10.24.030)
7-6-5: STANDING ON SIDEWALKS:
It is unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near as
reasonably possible to the building line or curb line if such standing
interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other pedestrians. (1977 Code §
10.24.040)
7-6-6: PEDESTRIANS WITH DISABILITIES:
The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian with
clearly visible disabilities. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 7
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
SECTION:
7-7-1: Driving Unsafe Vehicles Prohibited
7-7-2: Clear Vision
7-7-3: Lights
7-7-4: Signals Lamps And Signal Devices
7-7-5: Brakes
7-7-6: Horn And Warning Devices
7-7-7: Noise Control
7-7-8: Tires; Nonskid Devices
7-7-9: Size, Weight And Load
7-7-10: Prohibited Conditions
7-7-1: DRIVING UNSAFE VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or move, or for the owner to cause or
knowingly permit to be driven or moved, on any street or highway any vehicle or
combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any
person or property, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all
times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and
adjustment as required by statute, or which is equipped in any manner in
violation of the statutes. (1977 Code § 10.44.040; amd. 2013 Code)
7-7-2: CLEAR VISION:
   A.   It is unlawful to operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a
condition that the operator does not have a clear vision of all parts of the
roadway essential to the safe operation of the vehicle.
   B.   Any vehicle with the view of the roadway to the rear so obstructed
shall be equipped with a mirror so attached as to give him a view of the
roadway behind him. (1977 Code § 10.44.010)
7-7-3: LIGHTS:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   It is unlawful to operate or park on any street or highway any
vehicle not equipped with adequate lights conforming to the requirements of
state law; provided, that vehicles may be parked at nighttime without lights on
any street or portion thereof designated by ordinance as a place where vehicles
may be so parked at nighttime. (1977 Code § 10.44.090)
      2.   During the period from sunset to sunrise, or at any other time when
visibility is so limited as to require the use of lights for safety, every
motorcycle operated on any street or other public place in the city shall carry
and exhibit one lighted lamp, commonly known as a driving light, and every
motor vehicle two (2) such lighted lamps showing white light, or lights, of a
yellow or amber tint, visible at least five hundred feet (500') in the
direction toward which each motorcycle or motor vehicle is proceeding, and each
motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer shall also exhibit at least two (2)
lighted lamps which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible for at
least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse direction; provided, that every
trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000) pounds or less,
including the weight of the trailer and maximum load, shall be equipped with
two (2) lighted lamps, one on each side of the rear of such trailer which shall
be so situated as to throw a red light visible for at least five hundred feet
(500') in the reverse direction. (1977 Code § 10.44.190; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Bicycles: Every bicycle, when upon a street during the period from
sunset to sunrise, shall be equipped with at least one lighted lamp exhibiting
a white light, or light of a yellow or amber tint, visible from a distance of
five hundred feet (500') to the front of the bicycle and with at least one
lighted lamp exhibiting a red light or a red reflector visible from a distance
of five hundred feet (500') to the rear. (1977 Code § 10.44.180; amd. 2013
Code)
7-7-4: SIGNAL LAMPS AND SIGNAL DEVICES:
   A.   Every motor vehicle and trailer having a gross weight of three thousand
(3,000) pounds or less, including the weight of the trailer and the maximum
load, shall be equipped with a signal lamp or signal device which is so
constructed and located on the vehicle as to give a signal of the intention to
stop, which shall be red or yellow in color, and signals of intention to turn
to the right or left, all of which signals shall be plainly visible and
understandable in normal sunlight and at night from a distance of one hundred
feet (100') to the rear, but shall not project a dazzling or glaring light;
except, that a stop signal need be visible only from the rear.
   B.   All mechanical signal devices shall be self-illuminated during the
period from sunset to sunrise or when visibility is limited as to require the
use of lights for safety. (1977 Code § 10.44.130; amd. 2013 Code)
7-7-5: BRAKES:
It is unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon a street unless such vehicle is
equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good working condition, as required
by the state traffic law, or to operate any vehicle which is so loaded that the
operator does not have ready access to the mechanics operating the brakes of
such vehicle. (1977 Code § 10.44.060)
7-7-6: HORN AND WARNING DEVICES:
   A.   Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a good and sufficient
audible signaling device in efficient working condition. Such signaling device
shall be sounded when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of a
vehicle. (1977 Code § 10.44.070; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   No motor vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, shall be equipped
with a siren or gong signaling device. (1977 Code § 10.44.070)
7-7-7: NOISE CONTROL:
   A.   Muffler Required; Cutout Prohibited: No motor vehicle shall be operated
on any street unless such vehicle is provided with a muffler in efficient
actual working condition, and the use of a cutout is prohibited. (1977 Code §
10.44.100)
   B.   Unnecessary Noise Prohibited: It is unlawful to operate a vehicle which
makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise. (1977 Code § 10.44.030)
   C.   Noise From Engine Braking System:
      1.   Definition: For the purpose of this subsection, "compression/release
engine brake" is defined as any engine brake, compression brake, or mechanical
exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle by
converting engine power to compressed air which results in excessive, loud, or
unusual noise from such vehicle, or otherwise known as jake braking.
      2.   Excessive Noise Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the driver of
any vehicle to operate or cause to be used any engine braking system that emits
excessive noise, which shall include the use of engine compression brakes, also
known as jake brakes, on any street, highway, or road within the city limits.
      3.   Exemptions For Emergencies: This subsection shall not apply if the
driver used an engine braking system that emits excessive noise in an emergency
to avoid a collision with a person or another vehicle.
      4.   Signs Posted: The street superintendent shall order and post signs
at locations where streets enter the city which state: "Excessive Engine
Braking Noise Prohibited". Such signs shall be erected and placed in accordance
with rules adopted by the Illinois department of transportation. (Ord. 2165, 9-
17-2007)
      5.   Penalty: The fine for violating the provisions of this subsection
shall be not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2165, 9-17-2007; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   Sound Amplification Systems: No operator or person in possession of a
motor vehicle within the city shall operate or permit the operation of any
sound amplification system which can be heard outside the vehicle more than
fifty feet (50') unless such system is being operated from an authorized
emergency vehicle to warn of a situation hazardous to life, limb or property,
or to request assistance in dealing with an emergency. Any violation of this
subsection shall be a petty offense punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1818, 9-24-2001; amd. 2013 Code)
7-7-8: TIRES; NONSKID DEVICES:
   A.   Tires: It is unlawful to operate on any street any motor vehicle which
is not equipped with tires conforming to the requirements of the Illinois state
traffic law. (1977 Code § 10.44.140)
   B.   Nonskid Devices: It is unlawful to operate upon any street any motor
vehicle equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or
nonflexible portion thereof comes into contact with the pavement or roadway.
(1977 Code § 10.44.110)
7-7-9: SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD:
   A.   Dimensions Of Vehicles And Loads:
      1.   The maximum width, length and height of any vehicle and its load
shall not exceed the limits expressed in the Illinois state traffic law.
      2.   No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets with a
load extending beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of the vehicle
nor extending more than six inches (6") beyond the line of the fenders on the
right side thereof.
      3.   No part of the load of a vehicle shall extend more than three feet
(3') in front of the extreme front portion of the vehicle.
      4.   No combination of vehicles coupled together shall consist of more
than two (2) units, but such limitation shall not apply to vehicles operated in
daytime when transporting pipes, poles, machinery and other objects which
cannot be readily dismembered, nor to such vehicles operated at nighttime by a
public utility when engaged in emergency repair work, but such loads carried at
night shall be clearly marked with sufficient lights to show the full
dimensions of the load. (1977 Code § 10.44.120)
   B.   Weight:
      1.   It is unlawful to drive on any street any motor vehicle with a
weight, including load, in excess of that permitted by the state traffic law
for driving on improved highways, or with weight distributed in a manner not
conforming to such law, or in violation of special weight limits provided for
by ordinance and signposted. (1977 Code § 10.44.150)
7-7-10: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
   A.   Emissions: It is unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense
smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of
persons or as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles. (1977 Code §
10.44.020)
   B.   Spilling Loads: No vehicle shall be so loaded that any part of its load
spills or drops on any street or alley in the city. (1977 Code § 10.44.050)
CHAPTER 8
SKATEBOARDS AND BICYCLES
SECTION:
7-8-1: Definitions
7-8-2: Prohibitions
7-8-3: Seizure And Forfeiture
7-8-4: Penalties
7-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
Words and phrases, for the purposes of this chapter, shall have the meanings
set forth in this section, unless normal construction in context shall clearly
indicate to the contrary:
BICYCLE: Every device propelled by the feet acting upon pedals, having two (2)
or more wheels.
NEGLIGENT MANEUVER: Any maneuver that may cause injury to a person, including
the rider, and/or damage to property, and/or any maneuver that threatens such
injury or damage.
RIDING A SKATEBOARD: Standing with one or both feet touching the skateboard,
crouching, sitting or lying upon the skateboard, or standing on hands upon the
skateboard while it is in motion and/or propelling a skateboard.
SKATEBOARD: Has its ordinary meaning and includes a board of any material with
wheels affixed to the underside, designed to be ridden by a person. For the
purposes of this chapter, the term "skateboard" shall include the terms
"scooter" and "coaster". (Ord. 3172, 4-14-2014)
7-8-2: PROHIBITIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a skateboard or bicycle in any area
of the city designated herein as an area where skateboarding or bicycling is
prohibited and/or operate a skateboard or bicycle in a negligent manner as
provided herein.
   A.   Skateboarding and bicycling shall be prohibited in the city at the
following areas:
      1.   City hall and city hall grounds including sidewalks, parking areas,
driveways, stairs and rails, yards, and all areas associated with the city
hall;
      2.   The Tower Square, including the tower area, its sidewalks, benches,
rails and common area;
      3.   Municipal parking areas including sidewalks, parking areas,
driveways, stairs and rails, yards, and all areas associated with the parking
lots;
      4.   The Marion Carnegie Library including sidewalks, parking areas,
driveways, stairs and rails, yards, and all areas associated with the parking
lots;
      5.   The Pavilion of the city of Marion including sidewalks, parking
areas, driveways, stairs and rails, yards, and all areas associated with the
parking lots;
      6.   The Marion Cultural And Civic Center including sidewalks, parking
areas, driveways, stairs and rails, yards, and all areas associated with the
parking lots.
   B.   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to ride a
skateboard or a bicycle in a negligent manner within the city.
   C.   In areas of the city where skateboarding or bicycling is not
prohibited, it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to ride a
skateboard or bicycle in a manner contrary to traffic and/or pedestrian
regulations.
   D.   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any skateboard or bicycle
to be out of the direct physical control of the owner or user while it is in
motion anywhere within the city. Any skateboard or bicycle in violation of this
subsection is subject to seizure and forfeiture as provided in section
7-8-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 3172, 4-14-2014)
7-8-3: SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE:
Whenever a law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that a
skateboard or bicycle was used or is intended to be used in violation of any
section of this chapter, such skateboard or bicycle is subject to seizure and
forfeiture. If the skateboard or bicycle is seized, then the owner may seek for
its return by application to the city council or in a court of law. (Ord. 3172,
4-14-2014)
7-8-4: PENALTIES:
Upon the admission or determination of responsibility for a violation of this
chapter, the responsible person shall be assessed the following civil fines and
costs:
 
First violation          $ 50.00
Second violation         150.00
Third or more violations 300.00
 
and all costs incurred by the city in enforcement and prosecution including
actual attorney fees. Violators shall be responsible for reimbursement/
restitution for any damage caused by the violation. In the event that the
individual that violates this chapter is a minor, then the parents of that
child shall be assessed the fines stated herein. (Ord. 3172, 4-14-2014)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Streets
8-1-2: Excavations
8-1-3: Repair Or Replacement Of Sidewalks, Curbs And Driveway Entrances
8-1-4: Closure Of Streets, Sidewalks, Bridges And Culverts During Construction,
Repair Or Replacement
8-1-5: Damaging, Injuring Public Ways
8-1-6: Obstructions
8-1-7: Visibility At Intersections
8-1-8: Metal Tired Vehicles On Public Ways
8-1-9: Penalty
8-1-1: STREETS:
   A.   Specifications:
      1.   Compliance Required:
         a.   No dedication of a plat of a subdivision or part thereof will be
accepted unless there is compliance with the conditions of this section.
         b.   No city service will be available for an unplatted residential
development unless there is compliance with the conditions of this section.
      2.   Application And Interpretation:
         a.   The conditions set forth in this subsection shall apply to any
proposed street that would be an extension of any existing city street.
         b.   The provisions of this subsection take precedence over any
ordinance or part thereof in conflict herewith. (Ord. 1704, 10-19-1998)
      3.   Specifications: Any street proposed or offered to become a city
street shall have a right of way fifty feet (50') in width with a street
surface of a minimum of twenty seven feet (27'). Such street shall have a six
inch (6") compacted rock base and a surface of at least three inches (3") of
asphalt or six inches (6") concrete; either type surface to meet the standards
for such surfaces established according to standards of the Illinois department
of transportation.
      4.   Curb And Gutter Required: All streets constructed after the
effective date hereof shall have an eighteen inch (18") curb and gutter
abutting either side of the street. A "V" type curb and gutter will be
permissible after approval by the city. (Ord. 1704, 10-19-1998; amd. 2013 Code)
      5.   Stormwater Drainage: A plan for stormwater drainage or, if
necessary, stormwater impoundment, prepared by a licensed professional
engineer, must be submitted with any plat proposed for dedication to the city.
The same condition shall apply to any street proposed for dedication to the
city. (Ord. 1704, 10-19-1998)
   B.   Street Lighting:
      1.   New Subdivisions:
         a.   The developer of any subdivision shall include in the plan for
development the suggested appropriate location for installation of
streetlights.
         b.   Upon receipt of the suggested location for streetlights, the city
shall determine if such streetlights are warranted.
         c.   In the event it is determined such streetlights are warranted, it
shall be the responsibility of the developer to pay to the providing utility
the cost of such installation.
         d.   The city shall have the responsibility to pay the monthly price
for the operation of each streetlight installed.
      2.   Existing Developments: Upon approval by the city of a request for a
streetlight in a developed area, the person making the request shall pay the
cost of installation of the streetlight. The city shall pay the cost of the
pole and light and shall be responsible for the monthly cost of operation.
(Ord. 2175, 11-13-2007)
8-1-2: EXCAVATIONS:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
apply:
    APPLICANT: Any person applying for a permit from the city to: 1) cut,
excavate or bore under the surface of a city street, right of way, and/or
sidewalk, and/or 2) extend a tap into a city water line or sewer.
   DESIGNEE: An employee of the city of Marion authorized by a city
superintendent to act on his or her behalf.
   EASEMENT: A written consent by the city council allowing the use of city
real estate for a limited specified purpose.
   EXCAVATION: The making of a hole, bore, trench or ditch in the surface of a
city street or other city real estate by removing material from there.
   PERMIT: A written form provided by the city giving consent to excavate or
bore under a city street or other city real estate.
   PERMITTEE: Any person to whom a permit has been issued.
   PERSON: Any individual, business entity or one acting in a representative
capacity for any purpose.
   STREET: Any public way or thoroughfare owned by the city for use by
vehicular traffic by the public.
   STREET CUT: A trench, ditch, bore or hole cut in the surface of a city
street, alley, sidewalk or right of way.
   STREET SUPERINTENDENT OR DESIGNEE: The person employed by the city council
to supervise and administer the construction and maintenance of city streets,
alleys, sidewalks and the city stormwater drainage system.
   UTILITY: Any corporation or entity that provides, but is not limited to,
electric, gas, telephone, internet, fiber optic or television service.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT SUPERINTENDENT: The person employed by city council to
supervise and administer the construction, maintenance and all aspects involved
in the treatment of wastewater for the citizens of Marion.
   WATER SUPERINTENDENT: The person employed by the city council to supervise
and administrate the construction, maintenance and all aspects involved in
distribution of water to the citizens of Marion.
   B.   Permits:
      1.   Any person who desires to make a street cut or bore or otherwise use
city real estate or right of way must make application to the director of the
water office or her designee for a permit. The application shall be referred to
the appropriate superintendent(s) who shall review and determine if a permit
should be issued. The application must be signed off by each superintendent of
the affected city departments before any excavation may begin. No street cut or
other similar use of city real estate shall be made unless a permit has been
issued.
      2.   The application for such permit shall state the purpose of the
proposed cut or bore, the location and the dimension of the cut.
      3.   Before the permittee begins a cut of the surface of city property,
i.e., city street, alley or other city owned real estate, or involving a city
owned utility, the permittee must notify the designated superintendent(s) of
the time and day he intends to commence. Unless the designated superintendent
(s) determines there is reason to delay, the permittee may proceed.
      4.   When the permittee has completed the purpose for which the cut is
made, the superintendents of each affected department shall be notified by the
permittee, before the hole, trench or ditch is backfilled. The designated
superintendents shall inspect the project to ensure the tap/extension/cut is
completed to the city requirements.
      5.   Application for such permit shall be accompanied by a permit fee in
the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and the further sum of seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) as security deposit (security deposit does not
include water or sewer tap fees; see section
9-2-2 of this code) which will be refunded to permittee after superintendents
of said departments have confirmed to the director of the water department, the
completion of the project in compliance with the city requirements.
For ongoing projects, such as the laying of substantial lengths of line/cable,
a blanket cashiers' check in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00),
in lieu of the seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) security deposit, must be
submitted with the permit application.
      6.   No extension or tap of a city water line or sewer main shall be made
except by a licensed plumber, with the state of Illinois, after the permit to
do so has been issued. The city requires a copy of the plumber's license and
insurance bond.
   C.   Excavation And Cuts:
      1.   Any concrete or asphalt street surface to be disturbed for
excavation shall have the edges of the area to be excavated saw cut.
      2.   Excavation for any water/sewer extension or tap shall not be filled
until the superintendents of water/wastewater treatment or designees have
inspected the extension or tap and given approval.
      3.   All excavation backfill shall consist of granular crushed stone
compacted in eight inch (8") lifts to compaction of ninety percent (90%).
Backfill shall be made to eight inches (8") of the surface. Then concrete eight
inches (8") thick shall be put in place for the surface.
      4.   If necessary to preserve the safety of pedestrians and vehicular
traffic, barricades or other traffic control devices should be put in place.
The permittee shall notify the street superintendent for direction or
assistance.
      5.   Before commencing any cut the permittee shall notify JULIE of the
proposed area to cut.
      6.   The permittee shall be liable for all damage inflicted on any real
or personal property as a result of undertaking to make a cut or bore.
      7.   The permittee shall be responsible for removing from the site and
disposing of all material excavated from the site. Permittee shall be
responsible for cleanup of the site otherwise.
      8.   As nearly as can be done responsibly, permittee shall use all
precaution to prevent obstruction of flow of stormwater at the site of
excavation.
   D.   Restoration Of Street Cuts:
      1.   Backfill of an excavation and resurface of the street cut shall be
completed in compliance with subsection C2 of this section. Such completion
shall be done within no more than three (3) days and must meet the approval of
the street superintendent or his designee. All traffic control devices shall
remain in place for the safety of the public until the removal of material and
cleanup is completed.
   E.   Inspection:
      1.   Upon completion by the permittee of all requirements pertaining to a
street, sewer, or water excavation, cut or bore, the permittee shall notify the
designated superintendent(s) who shall inspect the site. If the said
superintendent determines the requirements have been met, he shall approve the
work and sign off on the project completion. The permittee shall take the
signed permit to the director of the water office or her designee who will
refund the security deposit of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Should
any of the designated superintendents determine the work has not been completed
as required, the amount of such refund will be used to reimburse the city for
repairs. If the cost of repairs exceeds the deposit the permittee will be
responsible for actual cost of repairs.
   F.   Violation: Any person violating any provision of this section may be
subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) together
with any attorney fees incurred by the city. Each day a violation continues
shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 3305, 3-14-2016)
8-1-3: REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT OF SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND DRIVEWAY ENTRANCES:
The street department may replace or repair sidewalks, curbs and driveway
entrances upon the following conditions:
   A.   Request For City To Do Work:
      1.   Notice Of Replacement Or Repair: The owner of the real estate
adjacent to the sidewalk, curb or driveway entrance shall notify the street
superintendent of the desire to have such sidewalk, curb or driveway entrance
replaced or repaired.
      2.   Estimate Of Costs: Upon being so notified, the street superintendent
shall cause an estimate to be made of the cost of materials including, but not
limited to, concrete, required to effect such replacement or repair. A copy of
such estimate shall be given to the real estate owner.
      3.   Fee: Should such owner accept and agree to such estimate, a fee in
the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) will then be due and payable to the city
in addition to the estimated cost of materials as aforementioned.
      4.   Records Kept: The street superintendent shall keep and maintain a
list of those owners who desire replacement or repair of a sidewalk, curb or
driveway entrance, the owner's names being kept in the order in which the fifty
dollar ($50.00) fee and acceptance of such estimate is received.
   B.   Work Done By Owner: Anyone who desires to replace or repair a sidewalk,
curb or driveway entrance without city assistance must receive approval by the
street superintendent of the plan for replacement or repair, as proposed, as
well as approval of the individual, firm or organization expected to make such
replacement or repair.
   C.   Authority Of City To Repair Or Replace: The street superintendent may
repair or replace a sidewalk, curb or driveway entrance at any time upon making
a determination such repair or replacement is necessary to preserve and protect
the public safety, anything herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.
(Ord. 1703, 10-19-1998)
8-1-4: CLOSURE OF STREETS, SIDEWALKS, BRIDGES AND CULVERTS DURING CONSTRUCTION,
REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT:
   A.   Closure Authorized; Safety Precautions: At any time a city street,
sidewalk, bridge or culvert is being built, repaired or replaced, the street
superintendent or his designee may close to traffic such street, sidewalk,
bridge or culvert or such part thereof necessary to preserve the safety of the
public and to allow sufficient area for the efficient and expeditious
completion of such building, repair or replacement; and the street
superintendent, or his designee, shall erect suitable barriers to prevent
traffic access to such street, sidewalk, bridge or culvert. (Ord. 1703, 10-19-
1998)
   B.   Damage To Safety Devices Prohibited: Whenever any public street, or
bridge or culvert thereon, or sidewalk within the city has been closed as
provided in subsection A of this section, no person shall wilfully deface,
injure or remove any such barrier so placed or erected, nor walk, ride or drive
upon any part of any such street, or bridge or culvert thereon, or sidewalk so
closed to traffic. (1977 Code § 12.08.020)
8-1-5: DAMAGING, INJURING PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person, firm or corporation shall, within the
corporate limits of the city, wilfully injure or tear up any public pavement,
sidewalk, fireplug or any part thereof, or dig any hole, ditch or drain in such
public pavement or sidewalk, or dig or remove any sod, stone, earth, sand or
gravel from any public street, alley or sidewalk within the city without first
having obtained the written permission of the superintendent of streets to do
so. (1977 Code § 9.36.010; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Malicious Damage Prohibited: No person shall wilfully and maliciously
tear up, injure, deface or destroy any public sidewalk, curbing, street paving,
street surface, fire alarm, sewer, drain, bridge, or culvert within the
corporate limits of the city. (1977 Code § 9.36.020)
8-1-6: OBSTRUCTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person, firm or corporation shall, within the
corporate limits of the city, encumber or obstruct any public street, alley, or
sidewalk in the city, or any part thereof, with building materials, vehicles,
implements, boxes, or any article or thing whatever without first having
obtained written permission from the mayor of the city. (1977 Code § 9.36.030)
   B.   Structures On Public Ways Prohibited: No person, firm or corporation
shall make, erect, place or construct any structure, enclosure, fence, gate,
stairway, or building encroaching, in whole or in part, upon any public street,
alley, or sidewalk within the city. (1977 Code § 9.36.040)
   C.   Obstructing Sidewalks:
      1.   Prohibited Generally: No person or other entity shall place upon any
city sidewalk any object that in any way obstructs the sidewalk.
      2.   Exemptions:
         a.   The prohibition mandated in subsection C1 of this section shall
not apply to sidewalk sales conducted by an organized merchant group recognized
by the city, provided such sales are limited to three (3) consecutive days on
no more than three (3) separate occasions in each calendar year, and further
provided, the items included in such sales are so placed as not to create or
pose a hazard to the safety of the public or to prevent use of the sidewalk by
the public.
         b.   The prohibition of subsection C1 of this section shall not apply
to temporary barricades or other paraphernalia intended to warn or alert the
public to a potentially hazardous condition. (Ord. 1743, 6-28-1999; amd. 2013
Code)
8-1-7: VISIBILITY AT INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   No person, firm, group or company shall plant, install, erect or
construct any object at or near the intersection of one city street with
another or with any drive used by the public in such a manner as to obstruct
the view of approaching motor vehicular traffic on one such intersecting street
or drive by the operator of a motor vehicle approaching such intersection on
the other intersecting street or drive. (1977 Code § 12.04.010)
   B.   Any object that is planted, installed, erected, or constructed at or
near the intersection of two (2) city streets or the intersection of a drive
used by the public and one city street in such manner that the operator of a
motor vehicle is required to drive such motor vehicle or any part thereof
beyond the curb line of the street or drive intersecting the street upon which
such vehicle is operated before the operator thereof can obtain a clear view of
approaching motor vehicular traffic on such intersecting street or drive shall
be deemed to be in violation of this section. Each day such violation continues
shall be considered a separate violation. (1977 Code §§ 12.04.020, 12.04.030)
8-1-8: METAL TIRED VEHICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
No metal tired vehicle, including tractors, motor trucks, traction engines and
other similar vehicles, shall be operated or driven upon or over any paved or
hard surfaced public street within the city if such vehicle has, on the
periphery of any of the road wheels, any block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug
or any projection of metal or wood which projects radially beyond the tread of
traffic surface of the tire; except, that this section shall not apply to
tractors or tractor engines equipped with what is known as "caterpillar
tractors" when such caterpillar does not contain any projections of any kind
likely to injure the surface of the road; provided, however, that tractors,
traction engines and similar vehicles may be operated upon the aforementioned
public streets which have upon their road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other
cleats arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the road
surface; further provided, that the gross weight upon such wheels per inch of
such cleats in contact with the road surface, when measured in the direction of
the axle of the vehicle, does not exceed eight hundred (800) pounds. (1977 Code
§ 12.12.010)
8-1-9: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, violation of any provision of this chapter shall
subject the violator to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). For instances in which the
violation is continuous, each day shall be considered a separate violation.
(2013 Code)
CHAPTER 2
STREET NAMES AND BUILDING NUMBERS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Numbering Structures And Lots Required; Specifications
8-2-2: Street Name Requirements
8-2-3: Street Name Signs
8-2-4: Assignment Of Addresses
8-2-5: Naming Dedicated Streets And Streets In Subdivisions And Annexed Areas
8-2-6: Authority To Rename Streets
8-2-7: Enforcement
8-2-8: Notice Of Changes To Provisions
8-2-1: NUMBERING STRUCTURES AND LOTS REQUIRED; SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Structures:
      1.   The owner or occupant of each structure or building, be it
residential, commercial, multi-family or multi-business or otherwise, within
the city shall display in a prominent place, clearly visible from the street,
the address number assigned to the lot or tract upon which such structure is
situated. Each address number shall be a minimum of three inches (3") in height
and shall be of a color in contrast to the color of the background against
which the number is placed.
      2.   In a multi-family or multi-business complex, each unit in such
complex shall have prominently displayed thereon its assigned number or letter.
Each assigned unit number or letter must be a minimum of three inches (3") in
height and shall be of a color in contrast to the color of the background
against which the number or letter is place. (Ord. 2180, 1-28-2008)
      3.   The developer or owner of any multi-family or multi-business complex
shall coordinate with the city water department office manager in determining
and assigning identifying numbers in conjunction with street address numbers
for each unit of any such complex; each unit in such a complex shall have
prominently displayed thereon its assigned identifying number. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-
1994)
   B.   Public Square: The public square shall be numbered consecutively,
beginning at the northeast corner thereof at the former city hall building,
which shall be number 100, from thence proceeding west across the north side of
the public square to the northwest corner thereof, thence south to the
southwest corner thereof, thence east to the southeast corner thereof, thence
north to the place of beginning.
   C.   Location Of Even And Odd Numbers: All of the even numbers shall be
placed on the north and west sides of the streets and the odd numbers on the
south and east sides. (Ord. 12, 12-2-1929; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2-2: STREET NAME REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Determination Of Names: The streets running east, west, north and south
from the public square, known as East and West Main Streets and North and South
Market Streets, respectively, shall be considered as base lines, and all
numbers shall begin from the public square along these streets and from these
streets east, west, north and south on all other streets. (Ord. 12, 12-2-1929)
   B.   Map And Alphabetical List:
      1.   The city clerk shall keep in the clerk's office a current map of the
city designating the name of each street within the city.
      2.   The city clerk shall prepare and maintain a list of all street names
which will be arranged in alphabetical order. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
8-2-3: STREET NAME SIGNS:
   A.   There shall be set up and maintained at the convenient corners of the
street crossings within the city good, substantial and suitable signs or
markers designating the names of the streets. (Ord. 12, 12-2-1929)
   B.   The developer of a new subdivision or other real estate development
within the city that includes streets, whether or not dedicated to the city,
shall erect at the intersection of any street with another street a street name
sign bearing the names of such streets, such signs to conform in quality, color
and lettering to street name signs erected by the city. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
8-2-4: ASSIGNMENT OF ADDRESSES:
The city water department office manager shall assign street address numbers to
all platted lots within the city in a manner that will be consistent with the
orderly implementation and operation of the city's enhanced 911 emergency
service system. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
8-2-5: NAMING DEDICATED STREETS AND STREETS IN SUBDIVISIONS AND ANNEXED AREAS:
   A.   The city council will not accept the dedication of a street or the plat
of a subdivision or real estate development containing streets if the name of
any such street would duplicate the name or would be likely to be confused with
the name of an existing street either visually when printed or phonetically
when pronounced.
   B.   Any unnamed street annexed to the city shall be named by the city
council following the criteria set forth in subsection A of this section;
street address numbers for such a street will be assigned pursuant to the
provisions of section
8-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
8-2-6: AUTHORITY TO RENAME STREETS:
The city council may rename a street upon its own initiative or upon request,
provided it is determined the public interest will be best served thereby and
the criteria set forth in subsection
8-2-5A of this chapter is followed. (Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
8-2-7: ENFORCEMENT:
Failure to have address numbers properly displayed as prescribed will result
in:
   A.   Notification to the owner by personal service or by U.S. postal service
of noncompliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The owner shall have thirty (30) days from the date of notification to
comply with the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   If such compliance is not accomplished within such thirty (30) days,
the owner shall be in violation of the provisions of this chapter and shall be
subject to a fine not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). (Ord. 2180, 1-28-2008)
8-2-8: NOTICE OF CHANGES TO PROVISIONS:
The city clerk shall notify the United States postal service and each emergency
service department or organization served by the city's enhanced 911 emergency
service system of new street names, change of street names, assigned street
address numbers, and identifying numbers assigned to each unit in a multi-
family or multi-business complex. Such notification shall be given promptly.
(Ord. 1498, 4-4-1994)
CHAPTER 3
CITY CEMETERIES
SECTION:
8-3-1: Provisions Adopted
8-3-2: Definitions
8-3-3: General Rules
8-3-4: Lots And Lot Owners
8-3-5: Correction Of Errors
8-3-6: Descent Of Titles
8-3-7: Interments And Disinterments
8-3-8: Fees
8-3-9: Landscaping And Maintenance
8-3-10: Decorations And Floral Arrangements
8-3-11: Memorials; Monument Companies Regulated
8-3-12: Exemptions, Suspensions And Modifications
8-3-13: Enforcement
8-3-1: PROVISIONS ADOPTED:
The rules and regulations of this chapter for the orderly and efficient
administration of the city cemeteries are hereby adopted. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-
2011)
8-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
CEMETERY OFFICE: The main office maintained east of Goddard Chapel.
CITY: The city of Marion.
CITY CEMETERY: A designated area set aside and controlled by the city for the
burial of human remains by earth interment or by interment in a mausoleum,
crypt or urn, administered by the cemetery superintendent.
DEED OF CONVEYANCE: The certificate of ownership issued by the city, executed
by the mayor and delivered to the original purchaser of a city cemetery plot or
lot showing ownership thereof.
GRASS MARKER: A memorial flush with the ground.
INTERMENT: The permanent disposition of human remains by burial, entombment, or
inurnment after cremation.
LOT: Applies to numbered divisions as shown on the record plat which consists
of one or more plots.
LOT MARKER: Any means or device used, erected or implanted by city cemetery
personnel to indicate the corners of a plot or lot.
MEMORIAL: Includes a monument, marker, tablet, headstone, private mausoleum or
tomb for family or individual use, tombstone, lot enclosure, urn and crypt and
niche place.
MONUMENT: Includes a tombstone or memorial of granite or marble which shall
extend above the surface of the ground.
PLOT: Applies to a space of sufficient size to accommodate one adult.
Interments are approximately three feet by eight feet (3' x 8').
SUPERINTENDENT: The person duly appointed by the city of Marion for the purpose
of conducting and administering the city cemeteries in a manner consistent with
city ordinances and state law. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
8-3-3: GENERAL RULES:
   A.   Hours: The cemetery office will be open from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
until three o'clock (3:00) P.M., Monday through Friday, except holidays (New
Year's Day, Good Friday, nationally recognized Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day,
Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, Friday after Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and
Christmas Day).
   B.   Employee Work Restrictions: City cemetery employees are not permitted
to perform work for a lot owner outside their regular responsibilities unless
authorized to do so by the cemetery superintendent for good cause.
   C.   Payment Of Fees And Charges: All fees or charges for services shall be
paid at the cemetery office. Such payment shall be made to the cemetery
superintendent or a city cemetery employee authorized to receive such fees or
charges.
   D.   Pedestrian Traffic: Pedestrians within a city cemetery shall use only
the avenues, roads and indicated walkways.
   E.   Damage To Property Prohibited: Persons visiting a city cemetery or
attending funerals are prohibited from picking flowers, wild or cultivated,
breaking or injuring any tree, shrub or plant, or from writing upon, defacing
or injuring any memorials, fence, or other structure within city cemetery
grounds.
   F.   Vehicle Restrictions: All vehicles must be kept under complete control
at all times. When meeting a funeral procession, every vehicle must stop until
the procession passes. Vehicles must not pass a funeral procession going the
same direction. Mufflers must not be opened nor the horn sounded within a city
cemetery.
   G.   Prohibitions: The following are prohibited:
      1.   The operation of a motor vehicle in a city cemetery at excessive
speed. A speed greater than twenty (20) miles per hour shall be considered
excessive.
      2.   The operation of a motor vehicle in any part of a city cemetery not
designated an avenue or road.
      3.   The operation or parking of a motor vehicle within a city cemetery
on any avenue or road in such a manner as to prevent another vehicle from
passing.
      4.   Making a complete or partial reverse turn of any motor car or
vehicle on any road or driveway within a city cemetery.
      5.   Loud or boisterous conduct.
      6.   Idling or loafing within a city cemetery or the buildings thereof.
      7.   Bringing into and consuming any food or beverage while in a city
cemetery.
      8.   Peddling or soliciting the sale of any commodity.
      9.   Placing of signs, notices or advertisements of any kind within a
city cemetery.
      10.   Bringing dogs into a city cemetery or any of the cemetery
buildings. Exceptions are made for specially trained dogs used by disabled
persons.
      11.   The presence of children under the age of fifteen (15) years unless
accompanied by a responsible adult.
      12.   Any conduct unbecoming a sacred place.
   H.   Certain Items Prohibited: The placing of boxes, shells, toys, metal
designs, wire figures, ornaments, chairs, settees, vases and similar articles
upon plots will not be permitted as they hinder maintenance efforts and present
a safety hazard. Items left on the ground (during mowing season, April 1
through November 1, excluding the week of Memorial Day) and flowers not in
approved containers will be removed by city cemetery employees. Approved
containers consist of vases attached to the monument, hanging baskets, and
monument saddles. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
8-3-4: LOTS AND LOT OWNERS:
   A.   Purchase Of Lots; Issuance Of Deed Of Conveyance:
      1.   City cemetery lots shall be purchased at the cemetery office. The
cemetery superintendent or his designated representative is authorized to
conduct the sale of such lots. No burial will be allowed on such lot until the
purchase price is paid in full.
      2.   After the payment of the purchase price, the city will issue a deed
of conveyance describing the purchased lot.
   B.   Authority Of City Regarding Cemetery Property: A city cemetery is owned
and maintained by the city. Therefore, the city retains the right to enlarge,
reduce, replat or change the boundaries or grading of a city cemetery, or a
section or sections, from time to time, including the right to modify or change
the locations of roads, drives, or walks, or any part thereof. The city retains
the right to lay, maintain and operate, or alter or change pipelines or gutters
for sprinkling systems, drainage, etc., as well as the right to use city
cemetery property not sold to individual plot owners for city cemetery
purposes, including interment of the dead, or for anything necessary,
incidental or convenient thereto. The city reserves to itself and to those
lawfully entitled thereto a perpetual right of ingress and egress over plots
and lots for the purpose of passing to and from other plots and lots. (Ord.
2355, 5-16-2011)
   C.   Descriptions Of Lots: Descriptions of lots will be in accordance with
city cemetery plats which are kept on file in the superintendent's office.
   D.   Protection Of Lots And Owners; Disclaimer Of Liability: The city will
provide all reasonable precautions to protect plot and lot owners and the
property rights of plot owners within a city cemetery from loss or damage.
However, the city disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage from causes
beyond its control. For example, damage caused by the elements, an act of
nature (ground cave in), common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious
mischief makers, explosions, invasions, insurrections, riots, or order of any
military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral.
Damages caused by private businesses such as monument or vault companies shall
be the responsibility of said company; the city shall be held harmless in such
situations.
   E.   Limitations Of General Care By City: The general care assumed by a city
cemetery shall in no case mean the maintenance, repair or replacement of any
memorial, tomb, or mausoleum placed or erected upon lots; nor the doing of any
special or unusual work in a city cemetery; nor does it mean the reconstruction
of any marble or granite work on any section or lot, or any portion or portions
thereof, in a city cemetery caused by the elements, an act of nature, common
enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious mischief makers, explosions,
unavoidable accidents, invasions, insurrections, riots, or by the order of any
military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral, other
than as herein provided. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
   F.   Agreement Between City And Lot Owner: The instrument of conveyance of
these rules and regulations and any amendments hereto constitute the sole
agreement between the city and the lot owner. The statement of any employee or
agent, unless confirmed in writing by the superintendent, shall in no way bind
the city. All plots and lots conveyed by deed and owners of plots are subject
to these rules and regulations. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
8-3-5: CORRECTION OF ERRORS:
The city reserves and shall have the right to correct any errors that may be
made thereby either in making interments, disinterments or removals, or the
description, transfer or conveyance of any interment property, either by
canceling such conveyance and substituting in lieu thereof a conveyance of
another lot for interment of equal value and similar location as far as
possible, or as may be selected by the superintendent, or, in the sole
discretion of the superintendent, by refunding the amount of money paid on
account of said purchase. In the event such error shall involve the interment
of the remains of any person in such property, the city reserves and shall have
the right to remove or transfer such remains so interred to such other property
of equal value and similar location as may be substituted and conveyed in lieu
thereof. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
8-3-6: DESCENT OF TITLES:
The laws of the state of Illinois govern the descent of title to city cemetery
lots as well as other matters pertaining to assignments, conveyances, devises,
and trust deeds. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
8-3-7: INTERMENTS AND DISINTERMENTS:
   A.   General Requirements For Interments, Disinterments And Removals:
      1.   All interments, disinterments, and removals must be made at the time
and in the manner determined by the superintendent and for the fees established
by the city.
      2.   Besides being subject to these rules and regulations, all
interments, disinterments, and removals are made subject to the orders and laws
of the properly constituted public authorities.
      3.   The right is reserved by the city to insist upon at least twenty
four (24) hours' notice prior to any interment and at least a one week's notice
prior to any disinterment or removal. Disinterments will be done during times
of favorable ground conditions only. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
   B.   Additional Interment Requirements:
      1.   Hours: A city cemetery will open for interments from ten o'clock
(10:00) A.M. until two thirty o'clock (2:30) P.M., daily (an overtime fee will
be charged for funerals arriving after 3:30 P.M.) with the exception of Good
Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas
Day and New Year's Day. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   Burial Permit Required: Funeral directors, upon arrival at a city
cemetery, must present the necessary burial permit from the local health
office.
      3.   Location: When an interment is to be made in a lot, the location of
such interment shall be designated by the lot owner. Should the lot owner fail
or neglect to make such designation, the city reserves the right to make the
interment in a location agreed upon by the funeral director and the cemetery
superintendent.
      4.   Authority To Open Lots: The cemetery superintendent and the
employees of a city cemetery are the only persons permitted to open plots.
      5.   Payment Of Charges: All charges for interment or services in
connection therewith shall be paid to the cemetery superintendent who will
issue a receipt. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
      6.   Prior Payment Required: Arrangements for the payment of any and all
fees, costs or other charges due the city must be made before interment will
proceed. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
      7.   Grave Liners: All interments will require the use of a concrete,
fiberglass or metal grave liner.
      8.   Disclaimer Of Liability:
         a.   The city will not be responsible for any order given by telephone
or for any mistake occurring from the want of precise and proper instructions
as to the particular space, size of plot, and location in a lot, where
interment is desired.
         b.   A city cemetery will not be responsible for the interment permit
nor for the identity of the person sought to be interred. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-
2011)
      9.   Rules Of Barham Cemetery:
         a.   There is an area to the south of Goddard Chapel in the Rose Hill
area of the cemetery known and designated as the "Barham Cemetery". After all
of the lots in the Barham Cemetery had been assigned to members of the Barham
family, the cemetery was transferred to the city. The city cannot sell or
transfer any title to any plot or lot in the Barham Cemetery nor does the city
have the authority to determine ownership of any such plot or lot. (Ord. 2355,
5-16-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
         b.   All requests to open a plot for an interment in the Barham
Cemetery must be in writing by an individual who presumptively has authority to
make such a request.
         c.   While the city will provide the same degree of maintenance and
care in the Barham Cemetery that is provided the rest of the cemetery, the
Barham Cemetery and the owners of plots and lots therein shall be subject to
these rules and regulations (including mausoleum, monument and marker
restrictions) and any changes or modifications thereof. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
8-3-8: FEES:
The fees for excavation of graves in the cemetery shall be determined from time
to time by the city council, and a schedule thereof shall be kept on file at
all times in the office of the city clerk and the office of the cemetery
superintendent. (1977 Code § 2.72.010; amd. 2013 Code)
8-3-9: LANDSCAPING AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   The city will undertake to maintain, as may be practicable, the
planting of trees and shrubs and to preserve and maintain landscape features
within city cemetery grounds. If a lot owner wishes to plant an "in memory of"
tree, the superintendent or his/her designee may provide a location for such
planting. All efforts will be made to place the planting as close as possible
to the desired location, but in most cases, the planting may not be allowed to
be placed on the individual plot or lot. If a memorial plaque or marker is to
be placed at the base of such planting (at the owner's expense), the cemetery
or staff will not be responsible for said planting, plaque or marker. If an
unauthorized planting is made, the cemetery will have the right to remove said
planting.
   B.   There shall be no individual beds of shrubbery or flowers or
personalized landscaping allowed on individual lots. This includes the
installation of copings, rock, mulch, bark, trees, bushes, grasses, toys,
boxes, and metal or glass containers of any kind. If said landscaping material
is discovered, it will be removed by cemetery employees at the owner's expense.
An attempt will be made to contact the family in reference to the violation. A
registered letter outlining the violation will be sent to the last known
address of a family member. If no response (from the family) is received within
five (5) working days of the letter being sent, the cemetery superintendent and
the commissioner in charge of the cemetery department will determine what
action should be taken.
   C.   All landscaping on the grounds prior to the effective date hereof will
be allowed to remain (grandfathered) until such time the landscaping design
becomes dilapidated and/or unsightly. At that time, the landscaping will be
removed by cemetery staff. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
8-3-10: DECORATIONS AND FLORAL ARRANGEMENTS:
   A.   Decorations are allowed in vases permanently attached to the monument,
hanging baskets, and monument saddles. A straight shepherd staff with a single
hook approximately five feet (5') tall is the only allowable shepherd staff
within a city cemetery. This is in accordance with the rules and regulations
set forth by the city. One shepherd staff per single plot lot is allowed; a
maximum of two (2) shepherd staffs are allowed for multiple plot lots. All
shepherd staffs not by monuments or without flowers on them are subject to
removal. No metal of any kind that protrudes aboveground will be allowed to be
set in concrete. This means shepherd staffs and metal set in the foundations of
monuments.
   B.   No floral decorations are allowed on the ground during mowing season,
April 1 through November 1, excluding the week of Memorial Day. Memorial Day
decorations that remain on the ground will be removed after seven (7) calendar
days.
   C.   There shall be no jars, glass, metal receptacles, or other containers
used on the premises for the holding of floral bouquets. All such forms of
decoration shall be in approved containers. Approved containers are described
as vases attached to the monument, hanging baskets, and monument saddles.
   D.   The city shall not be responsible for any kind of plantings damaged by
the elements, vandals, thieves or other causes beyond its control. The
superintendent shall have the authority to remove all floral designs, flowers,
weeds, and trees as, in his judgment, they become unsightly, dangerous,
detrimental, or diseased, or when they do not conform to the rules and
regulations as stated herein.
   E.   A city cemetery shall not be liable for floral pieces, baskets, or
frames placed on or near gravesites that are damaged or stolen. (Ord. 2355, 5-
16-2011)
8-3-11: MEMORIALS; MONUMENT COMPANIES REGULATED:
Specifications are necessary to permit the sound operation of a city cemetery
in the interest of all lot owners and the community the cemetery serves. These
specifications are the result of careful study, and reasonable application of
the memorial violators will be notified promptly and a remedy of the situation
will be expected as soon as practicable.
   A.   Family Monuments:
      1.   To avoid the appearance of congestion, only one central or family
memorial should be placed on a family lot (a family lot will constitute 4 or
more plots).
      2.   Anything above grass level will be considered a monument (with
reference to placement on the plot/lot).
      3.   All information panels (on monuments) will be placed on the side of
the monument where the interment will be made. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-2011)
   B.   Mausoleums:
      1.   Mausoleums or tombs, either wholly or partially aboveground, will be
constructed only in lots designated by the city council. No mausoleum will be
erected on any city cemetery lot purchased after August 3, 1992, other than in
the Rose Hill 8th Addition, unless the city council specifically designates
additional mausoleum sites by city ordinance. Mausoleums are limited to six
feet (6') in height. Any structure higher than six feet (6') must be approved
by the cemetery superintendent.
      2.   Plans, specifications and location of the mausoleum or tomb on the
lot are subject to approval of the cemetery superintendent. (Ord. 2355, 5-16-
2011; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Materials And Specifications:
      1.   Quality Materials: To properly perpetuate memory, all monuments,
markers, mausoleums and tombs shall be of quality granite, marble or other
natural stone.
      2.   Responsibility Of Monument Retailers: Monument retailers and
independent stone setters shall set monuments and markers in conformity with
city cemetery requirements and in accordance with the trade standards of proper
methods of handling and settings.
      3.   Monument Specifications (Maximum Sizes Indicated):
a.
Lot Size Lot Dimensions,  Length And Width Of Foundation Height
         Length And Width
