11-13-6: DESIGN OF LOADING FACILITIES:
If provided, all off street loading facilities shall conform to the following
minimum standards:
   A.   Size Of Space: Every off street loading space shall be at least twelve
feet (12') wide and sufficiently long to accommodate the type of vehicle
expected to use the space. In no case shall a vehicle being loaded or unloaded
overhang into the public right-of-way.
   B.   Accessway: Every off street loading space shall have a safe means of
vehicular access to a street or alley. Such accessway shall be at least twelve
feet (12') wide.
   C.   Surfacing: Every off street loading area shall be improved with a
compacted stone base at least seven inches (7") thick. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987,
eff. 6-1-1987)
CHAPTER 14
NONCONFORMITIES
SECTION:
11-14-1: Purpose
11-14-2: Nonconforming Lots
11-14-3: Nonconforming Structures
11-14-4: Nonconforming Uses
11-14-5: Existing Permits
11-14-1: PURPOSE:
The requirements imposed by this title are designed to guide the use of land by
encouraging the development of structures and uses that are compatible with the
predominant character of each of the various districts. Lots, structures, and
uses of land or structures that do not conform to the requirements of the
district in which they are located tend to impede appropriate development. For
example, nonconformities are frequently responsible for heavy traffic on
residential streets, the overtaxing of parking facilities, the creation of
nuisances, and/or the lowering of property values. The regulations of this
chapter are intended to alleviate such existing/potential problems by
encouraging the gradual elimination of nonconformities. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987,
eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-2: NONCONFORMING LOTS:
   A.   Any vacant lot that does not conform to one or more of the lot size
(area, dimensions) requirements of the district in which it is located may,
nonetheless, be developed for any use permitted in that district if such vacant
lot:
      1.   Was recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds prior to
the effective date hereof; and
      2.   Is at least thirty feet (30') wide.
   B.   If two (2) or more lots or combinations of lots with continuous street
frontage were of record and in common ownership on the effective date hereof,
and if one or more of those lots does not meet the minimum lot width, depth, or
area requirements of the district in which it is located, the land involved
shall be considered an undivided parcel. No portion of any such parcel shall be
developed (used) except in compliance with this title, nor shall any such
parcel be divided so as to create a lot that does not meet the requirements of
this title. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-3: NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES:
Any otherwise lawful structure which exists on the effective date hereof but
which could not be erected under the terms of this title because of
requirements/restrictions concerning lot size, height, setbacks, or other
characteristics of the structure or its location on the lot may lawfully
remain, subject to the following provisions:
   A.   Maintenance: A nonconforming structure may be maintained by ordinary
repairs.
   B.   Enlargement, Alterations: A nonconforming structure may be enlarged
and/or altered; provided, that:
      1.   Such enlargement and/or alteration is confined within the lot lines
of the property in question as such lot lines existed on the effective date
hereof; and
      2.   Such enlargement and/or alteration does not increase or worsen the
nonconforming characteristics of the structure.
   C.   Reconstruction:
      1.   A nonconforming structure that is damaged or destroyed may be
rebuilt; provided, that:
         a.   Reconstruction commences within one year from the date of damage/
destruction and is diligently pursued to completion; and
         b.   The structure, when reconstructed, will not be more nonconforming
than it had been.
      2.   If reconstruction does not commence within one year or is not
diligently pursued to completion, as determined by the administrator, the
damaged structure shall be considered abandoned. Reconstruction at that point
shall be allowed only if the structure will be rebuilt in conformity with the
provisions of this title which are applicable to new structures.
   D.   Relocation: A nonconforming structure shall not be moved to another lot
unless, after relocation, it will conform to all the regulations of the
district where it will be situated. (Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-4: NONCONFORMING USES:
Any otherwise lawful use existing on the effective date hereof that would not
be permitted under the terms of this title may lawfully continue, subject to
the following provisions:
   A.   Expansion/Intensification:
      1.   A nonconforming use which does not occupy a structure (such as a
plant nursery) may be expanded/intensified, but only within the confines of the
lot lines as such lot lines existed on the effective date hereof.
      2.   A nonconforming use which occupies a structure may be expanded or
intensified, but only within that structure and/or within any conforming
addition to said structure. (For rules concerning expansion of nonconforming
structures, see subsection
11-14-3B of this chapter.)
   B.   Reestablishment: A nonconforming use which is destroyed or damaged may
be reestablished. However, if the owner of said damaged/destroyed use proposes
to expand, relocate, or change it, then the other pertinent provisions of this
section shall control. Moreover, if no significant steps have been taken to
reestablish the use within one year from the date the damage occurred, then the
use shall be considered abandoned and subject to the provisions of subsection E
of this section.
   C.   Relocation: A nonconforming use shall not be moved, in whole or in
part, unless, upon relocation, it will conform to all pertinent regulations of
the district in which it will be relocated.
   D.   Change Of Use: A nonconforming use may continue, but shall not be
changed except to a use that is permitted under the applicable district
regulations.
   E.   Discontinuance: When a nonconforming use is discontinued for a period
of twelve (12) months, it shall not thereafter be resumed. Any subsequent use
shall conform to the uses permitted in the applicable zone district. (Ord.
1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
11-14-5: EXISTING PERMITS:
The regulations of this chapter shall not affect the terms of any permit issued
prior to the effective date hereof or any pertinent amendment hereto; provided,
that the work authorized by such permit is completed within a reasonable time.
(Ord. 1148, 4-27-1987, eff. 6-1-1987)
TITLE 12
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL SUBDIVISION PROVISIONS
SECTION:
12-1-1: Definitions
12-1-2: Jurisdiction
12-1-3: Compliance Required
12-1-4: Variances
12-1-5: Severability
12-1-6: Disclaimer Of Liability
12-1-7: Penalty
12-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this title, certain terms used in this title are defined as
set forth in this section.
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The city code enforcement officer.
IMPROVEMENTS: Water and sanitary sewer systems, streets and alleys, storm
sewers and drainage systems.
LARGE TRACT SUBDIVISION: The division of a tract or parcel of land into two
(2), three (3), or four (4) lots, plots, sites, or other divisions of land, or
the consolidation of the same number of parcels into a lesser number, for the
purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building
development when:
   A.   The smallest resulting parcel is ten (10) acres or more;
   B.   No new street construction is required; and
   C.   No new easement of access is required.
LOT: A parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership on building
development, whether immediate or future. A lot shall have frontage on a public
street.
PLAN COMMISSION: The city plan commission.
PROJECT INSPECTOR: The inspector present during construction of improvements.
STREET: Any street intended to serve or provide access to the properties in the
subdivision.
SUBDIVISION: The division of a tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more
lots, plots, sites, or other divisions of land, or the consolidation of
parcels, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership
or building development; provided, however, that this definition shall not
include bona fide large tract subdivisions which result in parcels of ten (10)
acres or more not involving any new street construction or easement of access.
(1977 Code §§ 16.08.010 - 16.08.080; amd. Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; 2013 Code)
12-1-2: JURISDICTION:
The rules and regulations governing plats and subdivisions of land contained in
this title shall apply to that land located within the corporate limits of the
city and to land located within one and one-half (11/2) miles of its corporate
limits. (1977 Code § 16.04.010)
12-1-3: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Within the territorial limits of this title, no person, firm or
corporation shall change, resubdivide, or rearrange the boundary or division
line of any lot or parcel of land, or divide the same into building lots for
the purpose of sale, or for lease for a period of more than five (5) years,
without meeting the requirements of this title. Nor shall any such person, firm
or corporation begin with any construction work in a proposed subdivision,
including grading, without complying with the provisions of this title and
before obtaining the approval of the plat of the proposed subdivision as
provided in this title. (1977 Code § 16.04.020)
   B.   Unless the plat is so approved, no subdivision shall be entitled to
record in the county recorder's office, nor have any validity; the code
enforcement officer will not issue building or repair permits for any structure
on a lot in any such subdivision; and the city will not permit any public
improvements or allow any city service to be extended to any such subdivision.
(1977 Code § 16.04.020; amd. 2013 Code)
12-1-4: VARIANCES:
The general principles of design and minimum requirements for the laying out of
subdivisions, set forth in chapter 4 of this title, may be varied in a
particular case where the subdivider can show that, by reason of exceptional
topographic or other physical conditions, strict compliance with any
requirement of this title could cause practical difficulty or exceptional and
undue hardship. Such variation shall be made by the city council only upon
receiving from the plan commission a recommendation that such variation be
allowed. Before making such recommendation, the plan commission must find that
such relief may be granted without detriment to the public good and without
impairing the intent and purpose of this title or the desirable general
development of the neighborhood and community. (1977 Code § 16.24.010; amd.
2013 Code)
12-1-5: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this title is declared unconstitutional or invalid by a
court of proper jurisdiction, that decision shall not affect the validity of
the remainder of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-1-6: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
Except as may be provided otherwise by statute or ordinance, no official, city
council member, agent, commission or board appointee, or employee of the city
shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may occur to persons
or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of
duties under this title. Any such person made a party to a civil action, civil
rights or constitutional rights damage action, or antitrust action by reason of
the discharge of said duties shall be held harmless and indemnified by the city
for all damages and attorney fees incurred; provided, that: a) the person makes
a timely disclosure of the litigation or threatened litigation to the city; and
b) the person authorizes the city to provide primary representation through the
city attorney in such litigation or threatened litigation and cooperates with
the city in the primary presentation. The city will not indemnify such person
for punitive damages assessed against the person nor pay attorney fees incurred
by the person for counsel not retained by the city. Said indemnification shall
be against all judgments, fines, amounts paid in settlements, and reasonable
expenses incurred resulting from any such action or proceeding, or any appeal,
to the fullest amount permitted by the laws of the state of Illinois. The
foregoing statement of indemnification is deemed to be a contract between the
city and each city official, city council member, agent, commission or board
appointee, or employee with explicit or implied responsibilities under the
provisions of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-1-7: PENALTY:
For the violation of any of the provisions of this title, the one so violating
shall, upon conviction, be fined in any amount up to and including the amount
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code § 16.16.080; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SUBDIVISION PLAT; APPROVAL PROCEDURE
SECTION:
12-2-1: Compliance Required
12-2-2: Procedure For Approval
12-2-3: Improvements
12-2-4: Required Information On Plat
12-2-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
In planning and developing a subdivision, the general principles and
requirements set forth in chapter 4 of this title shall be observed, and in
every case, the procedure set forth in this chapter shall be followed. (1977
Code § 16.12.010)
12-2-2: PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL:
   A.   Application For Approval; Fee:
      1.   The subdivider shall submit to the plan commission application for
approval of the plat of the proposed subdivision which shall have attached
thereto two (2) copies of the plat and two (2) copies of the construction
plans, if any, for public improvements or improvements for future dedication to
the city to be installed conforming with the requirements set forth in chapter
3 of this title. The application shall be filed with the plan commission at
least two (2) weeks prior to a meeting thereof. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
      2.   At the time of filing an application for approval, the subdivider
shall pay to the city clerk a fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each lot in the
subdivision, which shall be deposited into the city general fund to be used to
defray the expenses for the administration of this title. (1977 Code §
16.12.110; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Code Enforcement Officer Review: The commission chair, immediately upon
receipt of such application, shall deliver one copy of the application to the
code enforcement officer who will make an on site inspection of the area to be
subdivided, review the application, plat and plans, and report his
recommendations and advice within ten (10) days to the plan commission. (1977
Code § 16.12.030; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Plan Commission Decision: The plan commission, upon receipt of the code
enforcement officer's report, shall approve or disapprove the application
within two (2) weeks.
   D.   City Council Approval: If the application is approved by the
commission, the commission will recommend approval of the plat by the city
council at its next meeting following the action of the commission. Approval of
the plat by the city council will authorize the subdivider to proceed with the
proposed improvements in accordance with the general standards set forth in
chapter 3 of this title, unless waived by the city council. The commission will
return one copy of the plat and plans to the subdivider with the date of
approval. One copy will be kept by the commission for the use of the code
enforcement officer. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013 Code)
   E.   Disapproval: If the application is disapproved by the commission, the
subdivider must be furnished with a letter stating the reason for disapproval
and in what manner the plat and/or plans fail to conform with this chapter or
other city ordinances or regulations. Such letters shall be given to the
subdivider within the two (2) week period mentioned in subsection A1 of this
section. (1977 Code § 16.12.060)
12-2-3: IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Permit Or Security Required For Streets And Sanitary Improvements: The
subdivider, after approval of the application, may: 1) secure from the proper
city authorities the necessary permits to proceed with the street and sanitary
improvements, or, in lieu of this, 2) post with the commission a surety bond,
or other security, in the form prescribed by the city council, sufficient to
cover the full cost of improvements based upon estimates submitted to and
approved by the code enforcement officer, unless waived by the city council.
(Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Inspection Of Improvements; Issuance Of Certificate: Upon the
satisfactory installation of improvements in accordance with this title, the
code enforcement officer will make a twofold certificate showing that the
technical details of the plat itself have been checked and found satisfactory
and all required improvements have been satisfactorily completed, or, in lieu
thereof, a surety bond has been posted with the commission assuring their
installation. (1977 Code § 16.12.080; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   City Council Approval: When the improvements have been certified as
provided in subsection B of this section, or when a surety bond or other
security has been provided or waived as so specified in subsection A of this
section, the commission will transmit the plat to the city council for
approval. Such plat shall bear an official notation reading:
Recommended for approval and acceptance this                  day of
             . (Signed)                      Chair of the Plan Commission.
Thereupon, the city council may approve and accept the plat. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-
1987; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   Maintenance Bond Or Security Required: The subdivider shall post a
maintenance bond or other security acceptable to the city council covering ten
percent (10%) of the cost of any improvement to be accepted for maintenance by
the city unless waived by the city council. Such bond shall be held by the city
clerk and shall become effective upon acceptance of the plat by the city,
unless otherwise stipulated. Maintenance bonds shall run for one year on such
improvements. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-2-4: REQUIRED INFORMATION ON PLAT:
The plat shall be drawn at the scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" =
100') or less, and shall clearly show the following features and information:
   A.   Legal description of the property, including reference to the section,
township and range; section lines and corners; quarter section lines.
   B.   Names and addresses of the owner or owners of record, the subdivider,
and of the registered Illinois land surveyor who prepared the plat.
   C.   The proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate or
closely approximate the name of any other subdivision in the city or environs.
   D.   Names and locations of adjoining subdivisions.
   E.   Lots numbered in numerical order, and blocks also numbered in numerical
order; the proposed lots to have dimensions indicated.
   F.   The layout, proposed names and widths of proposed streets and alleys,
and the width of easements.
   G.   Proposed front yard setback or other setback lines.
   H.   All parcels of land intended to be dedicated or reserved for public
use, or to be reserved in the deeds for the common use of property owners in
the subdivision, with the purpose, conditions, or limitations of such
dedication or reservation indicated.
   I.   Existing sewers, water mains, culverts, and other underground
structures within the tract and immediately adjacent thereto, with the pipe
sizes and grades indicated.
   J.   North point, scale and date.
   K.   The accurate location and material of all permanent reference
monuments. There shall be located at each of the extreme corners of the
subdivision a concrete cylinder or rectangular prism not less than four inches
(4") in diameter or square, and twenty four inches (24") long. There shall be
located at all street corners, at all points where street lines intersect the
plat boundary lines, steel rods not less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in
diameter and twenty four inches (24") long. At all lot corners, there shall be
one-half inch (1/2") square iron pins, twenty four inches (24") in length.
   L.   Dedication.
   M.   Certification by the registered Illinois land surveyor who prepared the
plat to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him, that all
monuments indicated thereon actually exist, and that their location, size and
material are correctly shown.
   N.   Other certificates required by law, including certificate of title
showing ownership of the tract of land included in the subdivision; also
certificate from the county clerk showing that all taxes have been paid. (1977
Code § 16.20.010)
CHAPTER 3
IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
12-3-1: Required; Review And Approval Of Plans
12-3-2: Construction And Completion Requirements Generally
12-3-3: Streets
12-3-4: Water Supply
12-3-5: Sewer System
12-3-6: Utilities
12-3-7: Monuments
12-3-1: REQUIRED; REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF PLANS:
   A.   Minimum improvements must be installed, unless a surety bond is filed,
prior to approval and acceptance of the plat, in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter. (1977 Code §§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020)
   B.   The code enforcement officer shall review the construction plans for
improvements with the superintendents of the city water, sewer and street
departments upon the delivery of such plans to him from the plan commission.
(1977 Code §§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Such plans shall be revised by the subdivider as may be necessary to
comply with this chapter and all other city ordinances. Failure to make such
revisions will be grounds for nonapproval and nonacceptance of the plat. (1977
Code §§ 16.16.010, 16.16.020)
12-3-2: CONSTRUCTION AND COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS GENERALLY:
   A.   All the improvements required by this chapter shall be constructed or
installed in accordance with the plans submitted to and approved by the plan
commission.
   B.   None of the improvements will be installed or constructed unless there
is an inspector present on the project. Such project inspector shall have been
previously approved by the superintendent of the city department under whose
jurisdiction the particular improvement falls. The expenses of the project
inspector shall be borne by the subdivider. (1977 Code § 16.16.030)
   C.   All such improvements shall be completed prior to approval and
acceptance of the plat; or in lieu of the completing the required improvements,
the subdivider must furnish the plan commission with a surety bond, sufficient
to cover the cost of any or all of the required improvements not then
completed, based upon an estimate submitted to and approved by the code
enforcement officer, thereby to secure the construction or installation of such
improvements within one year after the acceptance of the plat. (1977 Code §
16.16.030; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   When the construction or installation of the improvements has been
completed, the subdivider shall file an affidavit with the commission
certifying that such improvements have been completed without variation from
the plans previously approved. (1977 Code § 16.16.030)
12-3-3: STREETS:
   A.   Streets shall be planned and constructed taking into account the best
possible manner of disposal of surface water and the location of water mains
and sanitary sewers.
   B.   All streets shall have an improved surface at least twenty seven feet
(27') in width.
   C.   The streets shall have a crushed rock or stone base of six inches (6")
when compacted for streets with asphalt surface.
   D.   There shall be curb and gutter on each side of the street in compliance
with subsection
8-1-1A4 of this code. (1977 Code § 16.16.040; amd. 2013 Code)
12-3-4: WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   Every subdivision shall be provided with a complete water distribution
system adequate to serve the area being platted, including appropriately spaced
fire hydrants, with steam nozzles. The spacing of the hydrants is to be
approved by the city fire chief, and the entire water system shall be designed
to meet the approval of the Illinois department of public health and the
superintendent of the city water department.
   B.   All water mains in the distribution system shall be flushed and
sterilized in the presence of the project inspector, and they shall not be put
into use until approved for use by the Illinois department of public health.
   C.   All water mains in the distribution system shall be subjected to a
pressure test whereby the mains will be under ordinary main pressure plus fifty
(50) pounds per square inch for a period of eight (8) hours without
interruption. The mains must maintain such pressure for such period, the
prescribed allowance for leakage being permitted, before the mains will be
considered as completed.
   D.   No water shall be used from the city system for flushing, sterilizing
or testing without prior approval of the superintendent of the city water
department. (1977 Code § 16.16.050)
12-3-5: SEWER SYSTEM:
   A.   Required: In every subdivision, provision shall be made for the
satisfactory disposal of sanitary sewage. (1977 Code § 16.16.060)
   B.   Use Of City Sanitary Sewer System:
      1.   Where a city sanitary sewer main is accessible, the subdivision
shall be provided with a complete sanitary sewage collection system connected
to such sewer main. Such collection system shall be adequate in size to serve
the area platted and/or the most advantages for future development of adjacent
tracts. The entire system, including layout, construction plans, profiles and
specifications, shall be designed to meet the approval, first, of the
superintendent of the city sewer department, and second, the environmental
protection agency.
      2.   All sewer mains in the collection system shall be subjected to
either infiltration or exfiltration leakage tests for an uninterrupted period
of twenty four (24) hours in the presence of the project inspector. The
prescribed allowance for leakage must be met before the mains will be
considered complete. The system shall not be put into use until approved for
use by the superintendent of the city sewer department and the environmental
protection agency. (1977 Code § 16.16.060; amd. 2013 Code)
      3.   The sewer collection system shall include a connection for each lot,
extended from the main sewer to the lot line. The superintendent of the city
sewer department shall be furnished with a complete and accurate record, by
measurement, of the location of the point of intersection of the extended lot
connection and the lot line, for a permanent record. (1977 Code § 16.16.060)
   C.   Use Of Private System: Where a city sanitary sewer main is not
accessible, proper provision shall be made for the collection and disposal of
sanitary wastes, subject to the approval of the environmental protection
agency, the Franklin and Williamson bi-county health department and the
superintendent of the city sewer department. (1977 Code § 16.16.060; amd. 2013
Code)
12-3-6: UTILITIES:
Poles or underground conduits for electric lights, telephone lines or other
utilities must be placed in easements provided along rear or side lot lines,
wherever this is practicable. (1977 Code § 16.16.070)
12-3-7: MONUMENTS:
Monuments must be placed in accordance with the requirements of section
12-2-4 of this title. (1977 Code § 16.16.070)
CHAPTER 4
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
12-4-1: Compliance Required
12-4-2: Streets And Alleys
12-4-3: Blocks
12-4-4: Easements
12-4-5: Lots
12-4-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
In laying out a subdivision, the subdivider must comply with the general
principles and requirements set forth in this chapter. (1977 Code § 16.28.010)
12-4-2: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
The street layout of the subdivision must, in general, conform with the most
advantageous development of adjoining areas and the entire neighborhood. The
criteria for such layout shall be as follows:
   A.   Where appropriate to the design, proposed streets shall be continuous
and in alignment with existing planned or platted streets with which they
connect. (1977 Code § 16.28.020)
   B.   Proposed streets shall extend to the boundary lines of the tract to be
subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or
unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, such extension is not necessary
or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with
existing layouts for the most advantageous future development of adjacent
tracts. Dead end streets (courts) of reasonable length may be approved where
topography necessitates or where they are appropriate for the type of
development contemplated. (1977 Code § 16.28.020; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Proposed streets should intersect one another as nearly at right angles
as topography and other limiting factors of good design permit. Not more than a
ten percent (10%) deviation from a right angle will be allowed without prior
written permission of the plan commission.
   D.   Wherever there exists, adjoining the tract to be subdivided, a
dedicated or platted and recorded half width street or alley, the other half
width shall be platted.
   E.   Alleys shall be platted in the rear of all lots to be used for business
and in the rear of residential lots fronting on primary streets as a means of
safe access to such lots. (1977 Code § 16.28.020)
12-4-3: BLOCKS:
   A.   Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two (2) tiers of lots
of appropriate depth, unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, prevented
by exceptional topography or other physical conditions.
   B.   In any block over nine hundred feet (900') in length, the plan
commission shall require that a crosswalk or pedestrianway not less than ten
feet (10') wide be provided near the center and entirely across such block.
(1977 Code § 16.28.020; amd. 2013 Code)
12-4-4: EASEMENTS:
   A.   Right Of Way Easements:
      1.   Streets: The right of way for all streets shall be forty feet (40').
All dead end streets shall terminate in a circular runaround having a minimum
right of way diameter of one hundred feet (100'). (1977 Code § 16.28.030; amd.
2013 Code)
      2.   Alleys And Service Drives: The right of way for alleys and service
drives shall be twenty feet (20').
   B.   Utilities Easements: Utilities easements, where required, shall be at
least fifteen feet (15') wide centered on rear or side lot lines. (1977 Code §
16.28.030)
12-4-5: LOTS:
   A.   The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the
location of the proposed subdivision and for the type of development
contemplated, the zoning ordinance requirements to be complied with in all
respects.
   B.   Excessive depth in relation to width ordinarily shall be avoided.
   C.   Every lot must abut upon a street.
   D.   Lots for residence purposes must be at least sixty feet (60') wide at
the building setback line.
   E.   Corner lots for residential use shall be ordinarily platted wider than
interior lots.
   F.   Double frontage lots and reversed frontage lots will be ordinarily
avoided.
   G.   Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles to the right of
way line of the street on which the lot fronts. Not more than a ten percent
(10%) deviation from a right angle will be allowed without prior written
permission of the plan commission. (1977 Code § 16.28.040)
CHAPTER 5
LARGE TRACT SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
12-5-1: General Requirements
12-5-2: Approval Procedure
12-5-3: Injunctive Relief
12-5-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
Within the territorial limits of this title, a parcel or tract of land may be
divided into two (2), three (3), or four (4) lots, plots, sites or other
divisions of land, or consolidation of the same number of parcels into a lesser
number, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership
or for building development when: a) the smallest resulting parcel is ten (10)
acres or more; b) no new street construction is required; and c) no new
easement of access is required. Large tract subdivisions are subject to the
procedures and standards set forth in this chapter and are exempt from the
procedures and standards for subdivisions as established in other sections of
this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
12-5-2: APPROVAL PROCEDURE:
   A.   Authority Of Code Enforcement Officer: The code enforcement officer is
authorized to receive applications for large tract subdivisions, review said
applications, and approve large tract subdivisions for recording.
   B.   Application For Subdivision; Fee: Applications for large tract
subdivisions will be filed with the code enforcement officer on a prescribed
form. The fee for said filing shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). The
application will include a legal description of the proposed subdivision with
reference provisions to sections, townships and range. A scaled sketch of the
proposed subdivision shall accompany the application that contains sufficient
information for the code enforcement officer to determine: 1) that the smallest
resulting parcel is ten (10) acres or more; 2) that no new easement of access
will be required; 3) that no new street construction will be necessary; and 4)
that the resulting subdivision will comply with the current provisions of title
11 of this code.
   C.   Review And Approval Of Application:
      1.   If the code enforcement officer determines it appropriate and
necessary to the review of the application, the services of a registered civil
engineer may be secured, at the expense of the subdivider, to assist in the
verification of the standards stated above.
      2.   Upon determination of the application's compliance with the
provisions of this title, the code enforcement officer may approve the
application and authorize recording without further action by the city.
      3.   All review functions of the code enforcement officer pursuant to
this chapter shall be conducted and concluded within thirty (30) calendar days
of the date of the receipt of the application.
   D.   Request For Additional Information: Should the code enforcement officer
determine that insufficient information exists to make a final decision on the
application, a formal request for the additional information will be forwarded
to the applicant. The review period may be extended an additional fifteen (15)
calendar days upon request of additional information by the code enforcement
officer.
   E.   Denial Of Application; Appeals: Incomplete applications and/or
applications that fail to meet all of the qualifications for a large tract
subdivision will be denied by the code enforcement officer. Applicants may
appeal any decision of the code enforcement officer pursuant to this chapter to
the city council. The city council will hear and decide the appeal at the next
meeting. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987; amd. 2013 Code)
12-5-3: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
No penalties shall be imposed for violation of this chapter; except, that the
city council may seek injunctive relief to stop or prevent violations within
the jurisdictional boundaries of this title. (Ord. 1162, 7-14-1987)
TITLE 13
FLOOD CONTROL
CHAPTER 1
DEVELOPMENT IN FLOOD HAZARD AREAS
SECTION:
13-1-1: Purpose
13-1-2: Definitions
13-1-3: Base Flood Elevation
13-1-4: Duties Of The City Codes Officer
13-1-5: Development Permit
13-1-6: Preventing Increased Flood Heights And Resulting Damages
13-1-7: Protecting Buildings
13-1-8: Subdivision Requirements
13-1-9: Public Health And Other Standards
13-1-10: Carrying Capacity And Notification
13-1-11: Variances
13-1-12: Disclaimer Of Liability
13-1-13: Penalty
13-1-14: Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
13-1-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this City of
Marion by the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2,
5/11-30-8 and 5/11-31-2) in order to accomplish the following purposes:
   A.   To prevent unwise developments from increasing flood or drainage
hazards to others;
   B.   Protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood
damage;
   C.   To promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare
of the citizens from the hazards of flooding;
   D.   To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control, repairs to
public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
   E.   Maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the
potential for creating blight areas;
   F.   Make federally subsidized flood insurance available; and
   G.   To preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses
and floodplains in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve
water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat,
provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance
community and economic development. (Ord. 1033, 3-10-2008)
13-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
               The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or exceeded in
BASE FLOOD:    any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood. The base

               13-1-3 of this chapter.

               7.   Storage of materials including the placement of gas and liquid storage
               tanks, and channel modifications or any other activity that might change the
               direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface waters.
               "Development" does not include routine maintenance of existing buildings and
               facilities, resurfacing roads, or gardening, plowing, and similar practices that
